Full text: - Angela Merkel, the chancellor, leads a grand coalition of the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU)-along with its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU)-and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD). At the September federal election, Mrs Merkel will step down from her 16-year tenure as chancellor, marking the end of a political era. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the election will lead to a CDU/CSU-Greens coalition, which we expect to be less fractious than the current coalition, leading to increased political stability. Policymaking will remain centrist and consensus-oriented. The parties share similar views on economic and climate change policies, and on policy towards Russia. Frictions can be expected on fiscal policy, however, where the CDU/CSU will seek to take a more hawkish stance, and on relations with China, where The Greens will be more openly critical.

Germany--highlights: Business environment outlook

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.

- Germany's score in our business environment model rises from 8.15 in the historical period (2016-20) to 8.31 in the forecast period (2021-25). The country rises to second place among its regional peers, behind only Switzerland. The improvements largely reflect three factors: effective mitigation of the economic shock of the coronavirus pandemic; ongoing reform efforts; and a bounce-back in real GDP and trade volumes from the 2020 slump. Constraints on the ranking include a high tax burden on labour income and on firms, alongside high administrative costs. Key strengths of the business environment are political stability, a skilled labour force, openness to trade and investment, and a strong research and innovation framework.

- We expect the German economy to make a quicker recovery than the west European average, after a less severe hit to growth in 2020. This reflects the large industrial sector, which was less affected by lockdown measures than the services sector, and growing demand in China and other Asian markets, which is benefiting export-oriented businesses. Government support and stimulus measures have been generous, and as the vaccination programme progresses we expect a return to robust economic activity, from the second half of 2021. A poor demographic outlook will increasingly constrain growth; policy priorities for the medium term include responding to technological disruption in the automotive sector (especially electric vehicles) and boosting green and digital capabilities.

- The pandemic in 2020 resulted in a higher death rate, lower net immigration and slightly fewer births than in 2019, and hence there was no population growth for the first time in nine years. We forecast that the population will increase marginally in 2021-22 as the impact of the pandemic recedes, before beginning a longer-term trend of decline. As elsewhere in Europe, the population is ageing, with the old-age dependency ratio expected to rise throughout the forecast period and the working-age population already in decline, putting pressure on pension and healthcare costs.

- Germany will remain the world's fourth-largest economy at market exchange rates in 2025, and the largest EU economy. It is the largest consumer market in Europe by population, but demand is constrained by a substantial tax wedge and high savings rates. The pandemic severely disrupted parts of the retail sector, and a shift towards e-commerce will continue after restrictions are eased. The changing age profile will do much to shape demand. The consumer market will remain characterised by a preference for inexpensive goods for most day-to-day needs and high-quality purchases in special circumstances.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.

- Our forecast for the economy's long-term average annual growth rate is 1.5%, slowing from 2% in 2021-30 to 1.3% in 2031-50. The poor demographic outlook is the main driver of this weakening overall growth rate, as total factor productivity will remain supportive of growth, as will capital spending. The picture looks slightly more favourable on a per-head basis. Germany has many attributes that are conducive to sustainable long-term growth, including a highly skilled workforce, stable institutions and openness to innovation. Its openness to trade will ensure continued efforts to protect the multilateral trading system.

Background: The modern German state was founded in 1870. After the second world war (1939-45), Germany was divided into two parts: a liberal parliamentary democracy in the west and a totalitarian communist regime in the east. On October 3rd 1990, after the end of the Soviet Union's hegemony in central and eastern Europe, Germany was reunified.
Political structure: Germany is a federation of 16 states, or Länder, each of which has its own constitution, government and parliament. The states are primarily responsible for policing and education. The federal parliament comprises the directly elected Bundestag (the lower house) and the Bundesrat (the upper house) of representatives of the state governments. The federal chancellor, the head of the executive, is elected by the Bundestag and can be brought down only by the election of a successor. In March 2018 a grand coalition was once again formed, comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD).
Policy issues: Short-term priorities focus on the response to the coronavirus pandemic, the resulting economic crisis and the rollout of the vaccination programme. Medium-term priorities include managing the transition of the automotive sector towards lower-emission vehicles; building industrial sovereignty and increasing the resilience of supply chains; managing rising tensions with Russia and China; implementing the rollout of fifth-generation (5G) technology, alongside continuing progress on the Industry 4.0 initiative; and transitioning the energy sector away from coal and nuclear power. Investment spending will increase in our forecast period (2021-25) compared with recent years.
Taxation: The federal corporation tax rate was cut from 25% to 15% in 2008. The effective corporate tax rate, including a municipal trade tax and a solidarity tax, is about 30-33%. The solidarity tax will be phased out from 2021. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45%. Social security contributions are shared equally between employers and employees. The main value-added tax (VAT) rate is 19%, but was temporarily reduced to 16% during the second half of 2020.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus came to US$248.4bn in 2019, with export earnings at almost US$1.5trn and import costs at just over US$1.2trn. Germany's single largest goods export market is still the EU, but the country has been more successful than most in diversifying its markets and selling into fast-growing emerging markets over the past decade.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Germany is a federal democracy, with major powers delegated to the 16 states (Länder). In March 2018 the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) re-formed their grand coalition following a protracted coalition-building process. Initial efforts had focused on creating a coalition comprising the CDU/CSU, The Greens and the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP), but these floundered and the FDP withdrew, making this an option that the parties may be cautious about pursuing again following the 2021 election. The main opposition party is the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD), but political co-operation with the AfD is out of the question for the mainstream parties. The bicameral parliament comprises the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament), whose members are elected on a system of modified proportional representation, and the Bundesrat (the upper house), which consists of representatives of the 16 state governments. The coalition has a majority in the Bundestag, but not in the Bundesrat.

Political outlook: Political stability Angela Merkel, the chancellor, leads a grand coalition comprising the centre-right CDU-along with its Bavarian sister party, the CSU-and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD). At the September federal election, Mrs Merkel will step down from her 16-year tenure as chancellor-a turning-point for Germany's political landscape. However, policymaking will remain centrist and consensus-oriented.
Mrs Merkel's already high approval ratings have risen during the coronavirus pandemic, with voters reassured by her calm demeanour, respect for scientific advice and recognised ability to manage crises. Germany's response to the public health crisis has been notable for stronger testing than its European peers, and for a more localised response-both made possible by the country's decentralised administrative structure. Excess hospital capacity also proved an advantage. However, the second wave over the winter has seen tensions rise between federal and state-level authorities over the appropriate level of restrictions. Social unrest and "pandemic fatigue" have also emerged, with protests against social distancing and mask-wearing rules, especially in Berlin, the capital. Nevertheless, all 16 German states agreed to extend the lockdown into March, from its intended expiry on February 14th, owing to the threat posed by virus mutations in neighbouring countries.
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the September federal election will lead to a CDU/CSU-Greens coalition, with the CDU's chancellor candidate succeeding Mrs Merkel. Armin Laschet, the centrist governor of North Rhine-Westphalia, was chosen as the CDU's new party leader on January 16th (in line with our forecast), but will not necessarily become its chancellor candidate, given his unspectacular poll ratings. Markus Söder, the CSU leader and governor of Bavaria, has won increasing support among party members and the public during the pandemic. Although he has not yet declared his intention to run, we consider him the most likely choice. The decision on a candidate will be taken only after the state elections in March, either by the CDU/CSU leadership or its parliamentary deputies (there is no fixed process).
We would expect a CDU/CSU-Green coalition to be less fractious than the current coalition, leading to increased political stability. The parties share similar views on economic and climate change policies, and on policy towards Russia. Frictions could be expected on fiscal policy, however, where the CDU/CSU will seek a more hawkish stance, and relations with China, where The Greens will be more openly critical.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness The quality of administration is high, and the implementation of policies that have been passed by the federal parliament is sound. The federal structure of the government means that considerable responsibility falls on the 16 states that constitute the federal republic. An advantage of this is that many issues are decided with the closer democratic involvement of the electorate. States have a strong incentive to improve their own quality of governance, as comparisons with other states are easy to make, although one drawback is that the quality of public services such as education remains heterogeneous across states. Another disadvantage is that co-ordination can be difficult in policy areas in which the states have a large role. This has been the case in recent years. For instance, although the federal government had allocated additional funds for infrastructure investment, lower governments were often unable to use these for additional investment owing to capacity constraints. More recently, the coronavirus pandemic elicited different responses in different states, and caused a rise in tensions between the federal government (which was pushing for stricter restrictions) and state-level authorities (attuned to local business needs).
The design of the system also means that the constitutional powers enjoyed by the Bundesrat may, on occasion, limit the ability of the federal government to push through reforms in the face of opposition at state level (state interests are represented in the Bundesrat). However, the upper house does not have the right of veto on all aspects of legislation, and the proportion of laws requiring its approval was reduced in 2006. In exchange for this loss of influence over federal legislation, the states gained greater influence over the implementation of federal laws and some additional powers, particularly in education.
Majority governments are the norm in Germany at both the federal and the state levels. This generally ensures smooth policymaking, as the coalition agreement usually sets out in advance what the government will be working on throughout its term. The current grand coalition endured considerable internal frictions in the first half of its term, with the SPD's efforts to differentiate itself more clearly from the CDU hampering policymaking. However, the pandemic put an end to this by pushing the government on to a crisis footing. We expect another majority coalition after the September election, with considerable policy overlap between the governing parties, resulting in a continuation of effective policymaking in Germany.
Political outlook: Election watch The next federal election is scheduled for September 26th, and will result in a change in chancellor for the first time since 2005. State elections in Baden-Württemberg and Rhineland-Palatinate in March give early insights into voter support for the CDU, the SPD and The Greens. Poor results for the CDU in these elections increase the likelihood of Mr Söder being chosen as chancellor candidate over Mr Laschet.
At the federal level, opinion polls have been fairly consistent in recent months, with the CDU/CSU polling around 35%, the Greens 19%, the SPD 16%, the Alternative for Germany (AfD) 9%, and the Left Party and the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP) each on 7%. This suggests that the CDU/CSU should be able to win a majority with The Greens. However, there are two "known unknowns". First, the impending departure of Mrs Merkel, who remains Germany's most popular politician, might not yet be reflected in the CDU's polling numbers. Second, continued slow progress in Germany's coronavirus vaccination programme could weaken the CDU's popularity.
Voter fragmentation will continue in 2021, but parties on the political extremes (the Left Party, and the AfD on the far right) are likely to remain excluded from mainstream debate and from any governing coalition. An SPD-Green-Left Party coalition might be a mathematical possibility, but the uncompromising stance of the Left Party makes this unlikely. Should the CDU/CSU-Greens fail to win a majority, they could be joined by the FDP or perhaps the SPD-although the latter is keen to avoid another grand coalition.
Political outlook: International relations The European economic recovery fund clears the way for joint debt issuance (worth EUR750bn) to be channelled to EU member states with lower living standards and those hardest hit by the pandemic. From mid-2021 about EUR390bn is to be transferred in grants and the remainder through loans. The size of the fund is modest, but it will help to increase fiscal space in highly leveraged countries; Germany's U-turn on joint debt issuance in May 2020 was crucial to the agreement. The fund is a landmark step for the bloc, as it establishes a precedent for the EU to issue debt to fund common needs.
We expect US-EU relations to improve under the new US president, Joe Biden. Mr Biden will prefer diplomacy to tariffs, reducing the threat of a US-EU trade war. He is already returning the US to a number of multilateral platforms, including the Paris Agreement on climate change. However, on other issues-including OECD-level negotiations on a digital services tax, and EU links with China-relations will remain strained.
Other EU external relations came under strain in late 2020. The poisoning of Alexei Navalny, a Russian opposition activist, prompted an unusually hawkish German response. We do not expect Germany to halt construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in the near term, but it may take other punitive measures against Russia. Following the expulsion of European diplomats (including Germans) from Russia, Germany expelled Russian diplomats in early February, sending EU-Russian relations to their lowest point since Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014. The EU and China have agreed in principle to conclude negotiations on a Comprehensive Agreement on Investment, but ratification by the European Parliament will be challenging, given European concerns about human rights and labour standards, and restrictions on allowing Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, to build fifth-generation (5G) telecoms infrastructure.

The economy will remain resilient, with effective mitigation of the pandemic Germany's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment model rises from 8.15 in the historical period (2016-20) to 8.31 in the forecast period (2021-25). The country jumps three places in our global ranking to fifth, and rises to second place among its 17 regional peers, behind Switzerland. The improvements largely reflect three factors: the country's solid institutional framework and macroeconomic fundamentals, which helped to mitigate the economic shock of the pandemic; ongoing reform efforts aimed at strengthening network infrastructure, the financing environment and the economy's overall technological capacity; and a bounce-back in some indicators from the 2020 slump (especially GDP and trade data in the market opportunities category).
Germany's main strengths are its skilled labour force, stable political culture, openness to foreign trade and investment, established supply-chain linkages, and world-class research and innovation. It has strong legal and regulatory structures, a mature democratic system, efficient public administration and a broadly pro-business policy orientation. Parts of the financial sector are being tested by the pandemic fallout, but we expect the financing environment to remain resilient, in view of earlier macroprudential reforms and extensive policy support. Volatile global trading conditions will dampen the score for foreign trade and exchange controls. Policy towards greenfield foreign investment will remain broadly favourable, but an increasing focus on "protecting" national sovereignty will lead to tighter investment screening rules. Network infrastructure is extensive, but ageing in some areas and its quality lags that of many regional peers. The tax regime places a substantial burden on labour income, while a poor demographic outlook holds down the labour market score. A focus on climate change and efforts to phase out nuclear and coal use will have implications for tax policy, energy costs and automotive production.


Enlarge this image.
Business environment outlook: Germany's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Significantly increased levels of state involvement in the economy decline only gradually, with pockets of market distortion. Likely review (and gradual tightening) of recently loosened EU state aid rules amid "level playing field" concerns.
2023-25: Limited prospects for reforming regulated service professions. State intervention pushes green and digital goals.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Policy still broadly welcoming towards greenfield foreign direct investment, but further tightening of foreign takeover rules and investment screening (particularly for non-EU inflows), amid concerns over intellectual property leakage.
2023-25: Geopolitical fallout from the pandemic encourages support for "strategic sectors" and industrial sovereignty.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Moderate bounce-back in world trade, but pressure on German export sector eases only gradually, given subdued global demand, ongoing US-China trade tensions and supply-chain disruption. EU-Mercosur trade deal delays continue.
2023-25: Steady decline in post-Brexit UK-EU crossborder trade. EU makes further gradual progress on bilateral trade deals.
Taxes 2021-22: No changes planned to headline tax rates. New modest tax-relief measures in 2021 (higher tax-free allowance and benefits) amid wider accommodative stance. Value-added tax (VAT) cut in hospitality sector extended to end-2022.
2023-25: Increased focus on environmental taxes. Comparatively high labour tax burden persists. Possible new digital taxes.
Financing 2021-22: Monetary policy remains highly accommodative, holding down banks' funding costs but also margins and profitability. Most business lending risk during the pandemic assumed by state-backed loan-guarantee schemes.
2023-25: Operating conditions for banks remain challenging. Ongoing efforts to attract financial services firms from the UK.
The labour market 2021-22: The Kurzarbeit wage-subsidy scheme remains in place until at least end-2021. Gradual tightening of some parameters.
2023-25: Risk of unequal scarring effects hitting less-protected labour market groups, such as young and older workers, and part-time female cohort. Rising structural challenges posed by ageing demographics and increasing share of migrant workers.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Higher investment in healthcare. Focus on improvements to rail network and digital infrastructure, such as ultra-fast broadband. Ongoing energy transition focuses on emissions and coal-usage reduction, and improvement of power grid.
2023-25: Steady rollout of policy measures to meet medium-term climate targets, including gradual phase-out of coal.
Technological readiness 2021-22: The government prioritises upgrading the country's digital infrastructure and investing in artificial intelligence.
2023-25: Efforts continue on the Industry 4.0 initiative, which focuses on upgrading manufacturing prowess through increased use of automation and connected systems. Increasing threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
8.6 8.3 6 4 5 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Before the pandemic, domestic demand in Germany had been resilient, underpinned by robust job creation, real wage gains, historically low borrowing costs and wealth effects from a dynamic housing market. These conditions supported a firm expansion of most private-sector services and construction activity. The large export-oriented industrial sector had faced a more challenging backdrop, amid heightened world trade tensions, Brexit-related uncertainty and structural disruption in the automotive industry. The pandemic and accompanying synchronised slump in global trade delivered a severe shock to the economy-unevenly distributed across sectors-although the downturn was on a smaller scale than in other large European countries, partly owing to huge policy support and the exposure of the large manufacturing sector to the more quickly rebounding Chinese economy.
Scarring effects from the pandemic may constrain the business environment Germany's economic recovery will be gradual and uneven. The unprecedented scale of policy support deployed in response to the crisis has so far worked well to mitigate disruption in labour and financial markets, but there is a risk that scarring effects will emerge as support is wound down. Germany's still fairly strong macroeconomic fundamentals (in a regional context) work in its favour, with a high employment rate, resilient public finances, modest household debt, an external surplus and a large competitive export sector, backed by a strong institutional framework. Set against this, however, are structural weaknesses that could be exposed by the fallout from the pandemic. A period of low business investment and infrastructure spending, alongside ageing demographics and an increasingly protectionist global trading environment, does not augur well for productivity trends and potential growth. The disruptive impact of new technologies and rising environmental pressures on the country's large automotive and energy sectors will also pose major policy challenges, with implications for investment and regional disparities.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
8.3 8.3 13 12 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition is generally liberal, and will remain so, although state involvement in the economy has increased in response to the pandemic (as in most European countries) and will remain at a higher level than in the pre-crisis period. Private enterprise in Germany is supported by a robust institutional framework, a stable legal code, strong research and innovation capacity and an extensive network of global and regional supply chains. The competition authority, the Federal Cartel Office, is reasonably efficient. However, Germany fares less well in other areas, with restricted competition in services, a fairly complex corporate tax regime, only modest entrepreneurial activity and a high administrative burden for new firms. Overall, the regulatory framework for companies is reasonable, but lags some regional peers. Administrative processes for accessing utilities and credit, obtaining permits, enforcing contracts and resolving insolvency are fairly straightforward. In contrast, the number of procedures and costs to set up a new business is well above the high-income OECD average, tax administration is often complex and costly, and property registration can be protracted. A third Bureaucracy Relief Act was implemented in late 2019 to reduce business red tape and improve digitisation.

- Before the pandemic, levels of state involvement in the economy were moderate. The federal government's major holdings include the national railway operator, Deutsche Bahn (100%); the former telecommunications monopoly, Deutsche Telekom (32%); the former postal monopoly, Deutsche Post (21%); and the country's second-largest financial institution, Commerzbank (16%). We do not expect any sell-offs of state-owned stakes in the medium term. The state also plays a major role in the financing of firms and investments, via the wholly state-owned KfW (the largest national development bank in Europe, and an even more important player in the German private sector since the start of the pandemic) and a broad framework of public-sector savings banks, which are mostly owned by local authorities and geared towards small businesses.

The pandemic will result in a much larger state hand in the economy
- State involvement in the economy has increased significantly during the pandemic, in the form of a hugely expanded wage-subsidy furlough scheme (Kurzarbeit); direct grants to firms in the worst-affected sectors (such as hospitality, travel and tourism); extensive state-backed loan and export guarantees; a EUR100bn fund to recapitalise and acquire stakes in affected companies; and increased state aid (major recipients include Deutsche Bahn; Lufthansa, Germany's largest airline; and TUI, a travel group). A temporary relaxation of EU state-aid rules is expected to continue until at least 2022. Many support measures will be wound down as affected businesses and sectors become viable again. However, significant take-up of state-guaranteed financing and the expansion of state equity holdings and state-aid subsidies imply a sustained higher level of post-crisis state involvement, with a risk of market distortions in some sectors.
- In late 2019 the government published a new National Industrial Strategy 2030. Alongside broad objectives to strengthen innovation and improve competitiveness, there was a strong implied shift towards greater state intervention in industry sectors, support for "national and regional champions", and protection for firms deemed to be of "strategic importance" to the economy. This reflects concern over market access of foreign companies (particularly state-owned or heavily subsidised firms), related issues of intellectual property and cyber-security, and the ability of EU-based firms to compete with US and Chinese rivals. The fallout from the pandemic will intensify such concerns, implying a strong domestic policy focus on the "protection" of industrial sovereignty.
- Liberalisation of product markets has progressed gradually, but levels of regulation in services remain more restrictive than in most EU member states, with high barriers to competition in some utilities and transport sectors, retail, and business services such as architecture, engineering and legal. Significant improvements in this area are unlikely in the medium term.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
8.7 7.8 10 13 8 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards foreign direct investment (FDI) will remain fairly liberal (as in most EU countries), but screening procedures for FDI have been steadily tightened in recent years and this trend will continue, alongside a more interventionist stance on foreign takeovers. This reflects the global shift towards protectionism and hardening sentiment at the regional level towards non-EU inflows in 'strategic' sectors. Germany has attracted considerable inbound investment over recent decades, primarily from other European countries, the US and Japan. Inflows from China have risen steadily since 2015, albeit from a low base. On the whole, foreign and domestic investors are treated equally in terms of investment incentives and protection of real and intellectual property. Limitations on foreign control traditionally applied only to "sensitive" sectors, such as media, defence and some critical infrastructure. However, the tighter FDI screening provisions imply that more prospective foreign investments or acquisitions across a wider range of sectors will now be subject to review. Restrictions on hostile takeovers are considerable, whether the acquirer is foreign or domestic, and notice of strategic goals and "acting in concert" is mandatory for large investments. There are a range of federal and state-level incentives aimed at attracting FDI, with a focus on support for research and innovation. Germany Trade and Invest (GTAI) is the federal body responsible for FDI affairs, with the state-owned development bank, KfW, the main provider of financing support.
FDI screening has increased in recent years
- Germany was a strong advocate of a new EU-wide framework for tighter screening of non-EU FDI-fully implemented in October 2020-and in recent years has progressively strengthened the country's investment screening rules. This follows a period of increased Chinese (and other foreign) acquisitions of German firms, which has raised concerns over the involvement of state-backed foreign actors in strategic infrastructure assets and the transfer of technological knowledge and intellectual property. Historically, the government had the power to review (and potentially veto) new investment projects or acquisitions of equity stakes above 25% in German companies by non-EU investors if the transactions were deemed to pose a risk to national security. A series of amendments since 2019 have lowered this threshold to 10% for investments in "critical infrastructure", significantly expanded the range of sectors that this encompasses (to include many areas of energy, telecoms, transport, healthcare, finance and information technology) and also broadened its interpretation of "national security risk" to cover the potential impact on all EU member states. A further extension of the screening regime is planned later in 2021 to cover artificial intelligence, biotechnology, robotics and semiconductors. These tighter screening requirements will remain in place in 2022 and beyond.
- A global trend in recent years has been an increasing share of FDI activity reflecting "corporate reconfigurations"-changes in multinational ownership structures-that have a minimal impact on output, employment and capital in the host economy. We expect this to continue over the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
10.0 9.6 1 5 1 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany's high score in this category reflects its traditional openness to foreign trade and its membership of the EU, which provides for freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and persons within the bloc. The slight fall in the score and rankings reflects the country's relative exposure to the underlying deterioration in global trading conditions, amid increased protectionism, Brexit disruption, UK-EU vaccine rows and heightened US-China tensions. No tariffs or quotas are permitted within the EU and most other non-tariff restrictions have been abolished. The EU trades with Norway and Iceland under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), has a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland and a customs union with Turkey. Only agriculture is excluded from all these arrangements. Trade with other non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties. A range of bilateral and regional agreements provide for lower or zero tariffs and co-operation on non-tariff barriers.

- After a slump in 2020, Germany's large export-oriented industrial sector will benefit from a strengthening of global trade flows in 2021-22, although supply-chain disruptions will make the recovery uneven. The fallout from the pandemic will exacerbate existing geopolitical trends such as rising protectionism and the shift in economic power from West to East. This could lead to more regionalised "nearshoring" of supply chains. The EU's trading relations with China, the US and the UK will face significant challenges in the forecast period.

Trade talks will focus on bilateral deals in a more protectionist global context
- In recent years the EU has finalised free-trade agreements (FTAs) with Canada, Singapore, Vietnam and Japan, upgraded its deal with Mexico and launched trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. A provisional agreement was reached in 2019 between the EU and Mercosur (the South American trading bloc) that would create the world's largest free-trade market of almost 800m people. However, concerns in some member states over aspects of the deal (mostly related to agriculture and climate) have raised uncertainty over its future implementation. Little progress is likely in 2021.
- The EU and the UK finalised their Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA) in December 2020. This limited FTA in theory provides for zero-tariff, zero-quota trade, easing uncertainty for business (although future regulatory divergence could see new tariffs). The TCA implies a 'hard Brexit' with substantial new non-tariff trade barriers. Services trade is barely covered in the TCA and many regulatory issues remain unresolved, pointing to ongoing negotiations in 2021-25. We expect EU-UK relations to remain fraught in our forecast period.
- In late 2020 the EU and China agreed in principle on a Comprehensive Agreement on Investment. The deal is modest in scope and detail, mostly covering non-binding commitments, with limited benefits. The deal did not include any commitments from China on state subsidies or improved labour rights. Ratification by the European Parliament in 2021 is highly unlikely, but the prospects for this will improve during the French presidency of the EU in 2022.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.1 7.1 21 28 6 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The tax regime remains one of the weaker areas of Germany's business environment and, with only minor changes expected over the forecast period, the country falls back in the global and regional rankings. The tax/GDP ratio has risen gradually in recent years and was 41.7% in 2019 (latest comparable Eurostat data), close to the euro zone average. Direct taxes on personal income and net social security contributions (labour taxes) account for a higher than average share of tax receipts. A lower proportion of revenue is derived from taxes on corporate income, goods and services, such as value-added tax (VAT), the environment and wealth. A progressive income-tax system levies rates ranging from 14% to 42% on taxable income between EUR9,740 and EUR57,920 (in 2021). The 42% rate then applies to income up to EUR274,600, above which there is a 45% top rate. Since 1991 there has been an additional "solidarity surcharge"-a 5.5% levy on income to finance reunification costs-but in January 2021 this was abolished for most taxpayers, with a tapered scale for higher earners. Almost all employees must pay social security contributions into insurance funds covering pensions, healthcare, unemployment and long-term care. Contribution rates range from 18.6% of gross salary (split equally between employees and employer) for pensions to about 3% for long-term care and unemployment insurance. The standard VAT rate is 19%, slightly less than the EU average, with a reduced rate of 7% on certain goods and services.
Tax burden will remain high on labour income and companies
- Despite an extended pre-pandemic period of robust jobs growth in Germany, the tax system is not especially supportive of employment or private investment, with a relatively high tax burden on labour income and companies. In 2019 the average single worker faced a 'tax wedge' of 49.4%, the second-highest in the OECD. This high burden-particularly affecting low-income workers-and in some cases very high marginal tax rates act as a disincentive for second earners and contribute to Germany's relatively modest full-time employment rate for women. The effective tax burden for most companies is also elevated, despite a comparatively low headline federal corporation tax rate of 15%. After including the impact of a local trade tax (Gewerbesteuer) and other leveies, the effective average corporation tax rate is estimated at around 30%, compared with an EU average of about 21%. A new research and development (R&D) tax incentive took effect in early 2020. The overall tax regime for companies will remain fairly complex, contributing to high compliance costs and favouring debt over equity, constraining the venture-capital market.
- A temporary six-month cut in VAT rates (standard: 19% to 16%; reduced: 7% to 5%) in response to the pandemic expired at end-2020, along with the option to defer selected tax payments for individuals and businesses. The government has extended the period of a lowered VAT rate of 7% in the hospitality sector until end-2022 and expanded a corporate loss carryback facility.
- Coronavirus-related developments could trigger further near-term moves in tax policy, but there are no plans for changes in headline tax rates. The forecast period will see an increased focus on digital and environmental taxation (the latter will be especially the case should The Greens, as expected, enter the federal government, in late 2021). A new carbon pricing system was introduced in 2021, alongside various new "carrot and stick" tax-related measures affecting transport use and energy efficiency. The government plans to cut the renewable energy levy on households, but there will be upward pressure elsewhere on energy costs. Germany strongly supports OECD-driven efforts to establish global rules for corporate taxation, including digital levies on the US technology giants.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.8 8.9 13 2 5 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The German financial sector has handled the fallout from the pandemic reasonably well, reflecting its improved resilience over the past decade and the stabilising effects of huge monetary and fiscal support measures. The banking sector entered the crisis with reasonably strong capital buffers: at end-2019 the Tier 1 capital-adequacy ratio was 16.5%, and non-performing loans were just 1.1% of total loans. However, the crisis is amplifying existing vulnerabilities, such as weak revenue growth and low bank profitability, and balance sheets are coming under increased pressure from defaults and loan losses across the corporate and household sectors as policy support is wound down. Bank profitability in Germany has traditionally been among the weakest in the EU. A major factor is the expansive three-tiered structure of the banking system, with the large private commercial banks and the state-owned regional lenders (Landesbanken) operating alongside an extensive network of (mostly non-profit) small local credit co-operatives and public-sector savings banks (owned by local authorities) that primarily service the Mittelstand (small and medium-sized enterprises). Banks face pressure on margins from the low interest-rate environment, rising digitisation costs and litigation pay-outs. These factors have contributed to large-scale cost-cutting programmes and job losses over recent years at Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, the country's two largest commercial financial institutions. Internally generated funds account for an above-average share of corporate financing in Germany, reflecting firms' lower reliance on capital markets than in most peer economies. Equity capital accounts for the largest share of funding, but is below the EU average. Bank credit was traditionally the preferred financing channel, being relatively cheap and available at long maturities, but demand has weakened over the past decade amid deleveraging.
Support for the financial sector during the pandemic proved substantial
- Alongside monetary easing by the European Central Bank-in the form of asset purchases and expanded liquidity schemes-domestic policymakers have deployed a range of credit support measures during the pandemic. The largest have been two state-backed loan-guarantee schemes totalling almost EUR850bn, channelled via the KfW public development bank and a newly created economic stabilisation fund (with EUR100bn also allocated to recapitalise and buy equity stakes in affected companies). As of early 2021, firms had taken up a fairly modest 20-25% of available loan guarantees, leaving a substantial buffer still available. Other measures have included loan-repayment deferrals, a cut in banks' countercyclical capital buffer to 0%, and the temporary easing by regulators of banks' capital and liquidity requirements. Heightened profitability and solvency pressures in the continued low-interest-rate environment could lead to a tightening of lending conditions. The increase in credit risk assumed by the state via its loan-guarantee schemes could create moral hazard and spur credit misallocation.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.0 6.8 17 26 7 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany's labour market is comparatively robust in regional terms, with high employment and low unemployment, a well-qualified labour force, established employer-employee relations, a respectable trend of nominal earnings growth, a statutory national minimum wage and a well-respected apprenticeship system. A sustained period of solid headline labour market indicators before the onset of the pandemic was partly a reflection of healthy domestic demand, but can also be traced to the impact of (often contentious) liberalising reforms implemented by past governments. There are some less positive features of the labour market. Although the overall female employment rate is comparatively high, participation of women in full-time employment is modest, constrained by limited childcare availability (reforms since 2017 have aimed to strengthen this) and tax disincentives for second earners. There is a significant gap between the employment rates of female EU and non-EU nationals (more so than for men), implying transition issues into the labour market for those with a migrant background, and underused labour resources. Across the economy as a whole, the share of low-skill, low-wage employment has increased steadily over the past decade. The employment prospects (and the participation rate) of older workers have improved, but Germany's ageing population still poses challenges.
The Kurzarbeit scheme will continue to play an important role in 2021
- During the pandemic many countries have introduced wage-subsidy programmes similar to Germany's established short-time work scheme (Kurzarbeit), which played an important role in shielding the labour market during the global financial crisis, and since early 2020 has been instrumental in limiting job losses, and supporting workers' incomes and firms' liquidity, amid the economic downturn. It has allowed companies to retain workers with firm-specific skills, mitigating costs associated with lay-offs and future (re)hiring and training. The number of workers furloughed in the Kurzarbeit scheme peaked at just over 6m in mid-2020-about four times higher than during the global financial crisis in 2009. In early 2021 Germany's unemployment rate stood at 4.6% of the labour force, up by a relatively modest 1 percentage point (or around 500,000 people) from its pre-pandemic level. The Kurzarbeit as it stands will remain largely in place until end-2021 (a longer duration than in some peer countries), although some aspects will be tightened from mid-year. This will reduce the risk of a spike in joblessness, although a gradual increase in unemployment is likely.
- One of the notable features of the pandemic has been its highly unequal impact on different economic sectors and households, with a clear risk that this will lead to widening inequality. There is concern that the labour market impact will be disproportionately concentrated among certain groups, such as the young, the lower skilled, women (who comprise a majority of employees in the worst-affected contact-intensive sectors) and more elderly workers. This could lead to a decline in employment rates across such groups, with implications for labour supply in the future and for growth potential.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.8 8.3 16 14 10 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure is solid but ageing; greater capital investment needed The quality of infrastructure has traditionally been a strength of the business environment, but a lengthy period of subdued public and private capital investment has resulted in a gradual deterioration of standards, constraining progress in digitalisation and raising capacity concerns in the government's energy transition policy (Energiewende) towards renewables. We expect some improvement over the forecast period, with public investment plans targeted towards digital infrastructure, social housing, the electric vehicle (EV) sector and a ten-year rail network modernisation programme. But weaknesses will persist and plans could be impeded by the pandemic fallout and capacity constraints in the construction sector. Transport infrastructure is well developed, but years of spending restraint have heightened road congestion and repair backlogs, and poor co-ordination between different levels of government has hindered high-speed rail projects and the planned Fehmarn Belt link with Denmark. The Federal Transport Infrastructure Plan (FTIP) earmarks around 1,000 projects up to 2030, but implementation in most cases will remain dependent on attracting large private-sector investment (the record for which is mixed) and overcoming longstanding regulatory hurdles such as complex planning rules. The mobile telecoms and broadband markets are competitive, but coverage and take-up of ultra-fast broadband (and availability of 4G mobile services) lag most regional peers. Planned improvements to fibre coverage and ongoing 4G/5G network builds will narrow the urban-rural divide, but meeting a 2025 nationwide coverage target for gigabit-ready broadband will be challenging. Expanding digitisation-along with pandemic-driven shifts towards greater remote working and less business travel-and rising consumer demand will continue to drive improvements in mobile and broadband penetration.

- Following years of delays and budget overruns, Germany's new flagship airport, Berlin-Brandenburg, opened in late 2020. The airline sector has been hit especially hard by the pandemic and faces a highly uncertain outlook, even assuming a rebound in travel demand. The country's largest airline, Lufthansa, received a EUR9bn bail­out in mid-2020 and additional state support for the sector could be needed (and would be forthcoming).
- The post-Fukushima decision by the government in 2011 to phase out domestic nuclear power by 2022 has driven a strong shift towards renewables, subsidies for which have contributed to comparatively high household energy bills. Germany has significantly expanded renewables generation-mostly solar and wind-power-but progress towards climate targets has been hindered by sluggish power-grid development and continued high dependence on heavily polluting coal. The country's first major climate action law in late 2019 set firm 2030 emission targets and other objectives, and also included a new carbon pricing system and a planned exit date of 2038 from domestic coal-fired power generation. Progress will be challenging, however, given the influence of coal-mining regions and the automotive sector.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
9.2 9.4 4 3 2 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Germany scores highly on a regional and global basis for technological readiness, owing to the scope of its digital infrastructure, strong e-commerce and e-business penetration, above-average digital skill levels, the national Industry 4.0 initiative aimed at supporting digital manufacturing, and a well-developed framework for research and innovation. Weaker aspects are the comparatively slow pace of ultrafast broadband rollout, modest digital adoption (and innovation activity) by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), rising digital skills shortages and the limited scope of e-government services. Total investment in R&D was 3.2% of GDP in 2019, one of the highest ratios in the EU. R&D intensity has trended steadily higher over the past decade, driven primarily by large firms in medium- and high-tech manufacturing sectors (the automotive industry is a major driver). An official target is to raise total R&D investment to 3.5% of GDP by 2025. In recent years Germany has slipped from being an "innovation leader" to a "strong innovator", according to the European Commission's Innovation Scoreboard. Germany scores well in terms of business investment and public-private linkages, but lags its peers in entrepreneurship and financing support. Berlin is the largest hub for entrepreneurial dynamism in Germany, but national indicators of innovative high-growth firms, start-up activity and SME innovations have weakened over recent years. Germany has a National Cyber Response Centre and adopted its second national cyber-security strategy in 2016 (an update is expected in the next few years). According to the Global Cybersecurity Index, published by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) in 2019, Germany was ranked 22nd in terms of its commitment and capacity to deal with the threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
The rollout of 5G and investment in artificial intelligence will be priorities
- The current government's digital policy is largely a continuation of its predecessor's "Digital Strategy 2025". This envisages the deployment of a nationwide gigabit-capable infrastructure network by 2025. Coverage obligations based on the 5G auction completed in mid-2019 include a requirement to supply 98% of households with minimum speeds of 100 Mbps by end-2022 and national roaming rules for network sharing that seek to encourage new market entry. The government's main pandemic stimulus package in mid-2020 allocated EUR6bn to create a state-funded infrastructure company to aid high-speed network builds in rural "white spot" areas. In late 2020 Germany tightened security laws covering 5G network suppliers, giving regulators the option to ban Huawei, a large Chinese telecoms equipment manufacturer, from the country's 5G programme.
- In late 2018 the government published a new national artificial intelligence (AI) strategy that earmarked a relatively modest EUR3bn of spending over a six-year period, with the aim of leveraging private-sector funding. The mid-2020 stimulus package included an extra EUR4bn of funding allocated to AI and investment in quantum computing and sixth-generation (6G) technologies, alongside measures to strengthen e-government services.

Economic forecast: Policy trends As elsewhere in Europe, Germany is now well into the second wave of the pandemic, which has proved much more severe than the first wave, putting strains on hospital capacity and rendering the test and trace system ineffective. A new stringent lockdown has been in place since December 16th and has been extended to March 7th. From March, we expect a gradual phase-out of most restrictions in line with quicker progress in Germany's vaccination programme. The vaccine rollout has been sluggish: 4.4m doses had been administered as of February 16th (2.9m first doses and 1.5m second doses), equivalent to 5.11 per 100 people, which compares unfavourably to the UK's 23.75 and the US's 16.5. Nevertheless, we expect that 70% of the population will be vaccinated by September 2021.
The European Commission has temporarily relaxed its state-aid rules, given the exceptional circumstances. We do not expect their reimposition until 2022 or 2023. Germany's state-aid disbursements comprise about half of the EU total. Firms in receipt of state aid may come under pressure to promote sustainability and to pay taxes in Germany rather than in lower-tax jurisdictions.
Other ongoing areas of policy debate include how to build industrial sovereignty, raise the resilience of supply chains and support transformation of the automotive sector towards low-emission vehicles. With The Greens all but certain to join the next federal coalition, the CDU and the SPD will both present policy programmes with a green agenda in 2021. The government's decision to support electric vehicles but not the automotive sector more generally in 2020, despite the industry's large lobby and the fact that it accounts for about 830,000 jobs, is an indication of the policy direction.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)

Government debt 69.7 72.9 70.8 68.4 67.0 65.3
After six years of fiscal surpluses, the budget shifted into deficit in 2020. Germany's fiscal support and stimulus programmes are the largest in Europe, with key components including the following:

- the Kurzarbeit programme, a furlough scheme that allows firms to cut employees' working hours without having to lay them off, with the state paying at least 60% of the lost net wage payments until end-2021;
- a EUR50bn solidarity fund to help small businesses and the self-employed, and liquidity support for companies that need assistance in paying loans, irrespective of their size, totalling EUR500bn;
- a EUR3.5bn cash injection into the healthcare system, and transfers to local governments to help to manage the crisis;
- a value-added tax (VAT) cut from 19% to 16% for July-December 2020, and a reduction in VAT for the hard-hit hospitality sector to 7% until mid-2021 and until end-2022 for meals in restaurants and cafés.
- cash transfers to businesses that are forced to close under the winter lockdown, along with new tax deductions announced in February.

Germany's expansionary fiscal policy will persist during 2021; we forecast a deficit of 4% of GDP, compared with 4.8% of GDP in 2020. The Kurzarbeit programme will remain in place throughout the year and capital expenditure will be higher than before the pandemic. Over the next four years, investment will be channelled to a wide range of sectors, from artificial intelligence (AI), to the 5G rollout, to innovation in automotive manufacturers. The health fund will receive a significant boost and a large chunk of the money will go to Germany's national hydrogen strategy, as part of its energy transition.
We expect Germany's public debt to peak at just under 73% of GDP in 2021, from around 60% in 2019. The government is taking advantage of an exception clause in the constitutional debt brake for crisis periods, lifting limits on new borrowing. The brake will remain suspended this year, but fiscal consolidation will then return-bringing the public debt/GDP ratio back to about 65% by end-2025, which is likely to lead to renewed tensions with southern EU members.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Short-term interest rate (av) -0.4 -0.5 -0.5 -0.4 -0.4 -0.4
Long-term interest rate (av) -0.5 -0.4 -0.1 0.0 0.1 0.2
The monetary policy of the European Central Bank (ECB) will remain highly accommodative until at least the end of 2023. The overnight interbank rate (EONIA) has been negative since October 2014 and stood at -0.48% in January. With policy rates at their effective lower bound, monetary policy is now conducted primarily through quantitative easing (QE). The ECB restarted asset purchases in November 2019 at an average monthly pace of EUR20bn, as the euro zone economy was slowing. In 2020 the ECB adopted further stimulus measures to contain the economic disruption caused by the coronavirus: an extra round of QE worth EUR120bn, a EUR1.85trn pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP), liquidity injections at negative rates and easier capital and collateral requirements for banks. We expect the ECB to use the PEPP envelope in full; after EUR1.1trn of asset purchases in 2020, we expect purchases worth EUR1.1trn in 2021 and EUR460bn in 2022. The bank will maintain its QE programme into 2023, when we forecast that inflation will continue to undershoot its target of just below 2%. We do not expect policy rates to increase by the end of 2025.
The ECB's actions have prevented a credit crunch in the euro zone: borrowing costs for households and businesses are at historic lows and this will continue for the next few years, supporting the economic recovery. However, the pandemic poses challenges to credit markets: banks tightened credit standards for businesses in the third and fourth quarters of 2020 owing to increased risk perception, and collateral requirements have reached the highest value since the third quarter of 2009.

Economic forecast: Economic growth The impact of the coronavirus: global and regional assumptions The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that global output contracted by 4% in 2020 (an upgrade from a contraction of 4.3% in our previous forecasting round). In 2021 we expect global GDP to rebound by 4.5%, with growth in OECD countries reaching record-high levels. This sharp rebound will boost global GDP back to its pre-coronavirus level in late 2021. However, the pace of recovery will vary greatly across regions. Asia and North America will recover first, with real GDP back to pre-coronavirus levels as early as this year. The recovery will take longer in Europe and the Middle East and Africa region, stretching into 2022. Latin America will be a laggard, with real GDP returning to pre-coronavirus levels only in 2023.
The start of the rollout of several coronavirus vaccines in most developed economies has not altered our economic forecasts. In the coming months the vaccines will not be available in quantities large enough to be game-changing. Logistics and shipping will also be difficult. We therefore maintain our view that in most developed economies vaccines will not be widely distributed before late 2021 or early 2022. Access to the vaccine will be difficult initially as developed countries race to acquire sufficient quantities and poorer countries struggle to secure funding. The rollout in middle-income and emerging countries will take longer; we do not expect it to take place on a wide scale before at least end-2022. The picture appears even bleaker for low-income countries; we do not expect most of these states to have wide access to a vaccine before 2023, if at all. The slow pace of vaccine distribution creates significant risks for the global economy. This will hold back the global recovery and foster the emergence of new variants of the virus, which may prove resistant to current vaccines.
Europe was badly hit by the pandemic-induced economic downturn in 2020, with Spain and the UK suffering the largest recessions. Among the developed European economies, only Ireland is likely to have escaped a contraction, owing to its large multinational and pharmaceutical sectors. Year-on-year growth rates in 2021 will be misleading, as the economies that were worst-hit in spring 2020 (such as France) will grow the fastest, even as economic activity remains subdued, mainly because of base effects. We expect a more sustained pick-up among businesses and consumers in the second half of 2021, with EU real GDP returning to its 2019 level in 2022. This is a slower trajectory than we expect in the US, reflecting the EU's greater dependence on global export demand and a slower structural adjustment following the crisis. The second wave of the pandemic, during which cold winter temperatures and new variants have increased transmission rates, has been significantly worse than the first. In late 2020 many countries reimposed lockdowns and other restrictions such as curfews to prevent health services from being overwhelmed, and these remain in place across most major economies in western Europe in early 2021. Vaccination programmes are being rolled out, but there is a substantial variation in pace between countries, with the UK having administered at least one dose of a vaccine to 22% of the adult population by February 15th, while the EU average stood at around 4%.
The political and geopolitical effects of the crisis will be significant. The pandemic has resulted in an extraordinary expansion of executive powers, often with limited parliamentary oversight, and an unprecedented withdrawal of civil liberties. It has also become a testing time for central-local government relations, which have deteriorated in many countries owing to conflicts over power-sharing, policy responses and financial support. Elections have been cancelled or delayed in some countries, and have gone ahead in others in controversial circumstances. Governments' handling of the response will continue to face scrutiny. Public support for measures to combat the pandemic is fraying, and we expect social unrest to rise in 2021. Failure to address the social crisis triggered by the coronavirus could further erode trust in national institutions. The crisis may encourage support for the nation state, and a backlash against globalisation and open borders. It will also intensify the competition for global leadership between China and the US, and a realignment of geopolitical spheres of influence may ensue in Europe, Africa and other regions.

The economy contracted by 5.3% in 2020, the first annual fall since the 5.6% contraction in the wake of the global financial crisis. This was a less severe downturn than in the other major economies in western Europe; real GDP fell by 8.3% in France, 9.9% in the UK and 11% in Spain. Germany's better outturn reflects less stringent lockdowns, high levels of government support and a large manufacturing sector-equivalent to 20% of gross value added, and closely tied to the strongly recovering Chinese market-which was able to continue operating with social-distancing measures in place.
We expect real GDP to return to 98.2% of its 2019 size in 2021, a quicker recovery than the west European average, with annual growth of 3.7% in 2021 and 4% in 2022. The latter reflects strong carryover effects and improving macroeconomic conditions in emerging markets. The industrial sector has been hit less severely by the second lockdown and Germany's export-oriented manufacturing firms are benefiting from growing demand in China and other Asian markets. China overtook France as Germany's second-largest export destination in 2020, and our forecast of 8.5% GDP growth in China in 2021 will keep demand for German exports elevated. Construction was a bright spot in 2020, expanding as housebuilding continued. Consumers will maintain high precautionary savings this year, but much of the forced savings resulting from lockdowns and deferred investment will be drawn down to satisfy pent-up demand in the second quarter, once restrictions are lifted. The Kurzarbeit scheme has been extended to end-2021, which will support disposable incomes. However, in-person services will take longer to recover, and the immediate outlook is not promising. After a decrease in 2020, owing to deferred reporting obligations and massive government financial support, we expect a rise in bankruptcies this year.
We forecast 1.9% annual average growth in 2023-25. The poor demographic outlook will constrain potential growth as the working-age population declines, exacerbated by a fall in net immigration during the pandemic. Technological disruption to the automotive sector also represents a structural risk: Germany has been slow to shift emphasis towards electric vehicles. Efforts to reduce supply-chain dependence on China may see some reshoring of production, but as labour costs in Europe are higher, we do not expect this to bring a surge in job creation. Instead, automation and digitisation will gain pace, and linkages with existing suppliers in central and eastern Europe will strengthen.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Services account for about 70% of GDP, industry for almost 30% and agriculture less than 1%. The share of industry in the German economy exceeds those of all the other major economies in Europe, with the UK and France both below 20% and even Italy barely at 24%. This proved an advantage for Germany during the pandemic in 2020-21, as industrial production was less disrupted by social-distancing restrictions than contact-intensive services. Nonetheless, we expect a gradual reduction in the share of industry in the economy, to 28% in 2025. A decrease in the relative importance of manufacturing is the inevitable result of rising living standards: as people become wealthier, they spend a higher proportion of their income on services. However, it also reflects the changing nature of industry: Germany's industrial champions increasingly provide value added through services supplied in conjunction with manufactured products.
The automotive sector is currently managing a structural transition Germany's most important manufacturing sectors are automotive, electrical and mechanical engineering, chemicals, and food, drink and tobacco. Germany is the global leader in the production of premium cars, an industry that has benefited from robust competition between several domestic companies, ownership structures that have enabled firms to make long-term investments, and a host of innovative supplier companies in the mechanical and electrical engineering sectors. Germany's automotive sector is currently managing a structural transition towards electric and hybrid vehicles, having historically invested heavily in diesel technology and entered the electric market comparatively late. As major producers of capital goods, German firms were able to weather the years following the global financial crisis by profiting from rapid industrialisation in emerging markets such as China and India. China became Germany's second-largest export market in 2020; it is now also a rapidly growing competitor in the high-tech industrial sector.
Most industries derive competitive advantages from Germany's well-developed system of vocational training, good physical infrastructure and research base, and a tax system that encourages capital investment. Low interest rates and fiscal stimulus measures targeted towards infrastructure improvements and the green and digital transitions will continue to support construction, which is currently facing capacity constraints in the face of accelerating demand. Although we do not expect the EUR750bn Next Generation EU recovery fund to directly spur much infrastructure spending in Germany itself, sharp rises in other member states will result in spillover benefits for German companies.
The pandemic has had an asymmetric impact on the services sector The services sector is the largest component of GDP and comprises a broad range of activities, from retailing to financial services, logistics and healthcare. The pandemic has had a highly asymmetric impact on the services sector, with contact-intensive services such as retail, accommodation and foodservice heavily affected, while professional services that can be performed remotely have held up well. We expect this split to remain substantial even as the economy recovers, with many of the changes prompted by the pandemic-more remote working, less business travel, a rise in e-commerce at the expense of bricks-and-mortar retailers-enduring throughout our forecast period.
The financial services sector entered this crisis in a comparatively strong position, with high capital-adequacy ratios and low levels of non-performing loans. We expect the share of bad loans to rise now that a temporary moratorium on insolvencies has come to an end, while the phasing out of the Kurzarbeit scheme by end-2021 presents a further risk. Profitability-which was already low, amid a low-interest-rate environment-is likely to fall further, and market regulation-in the wake of the Wirecard accounting scandal-is likely to be strengthened. More positively, Germany's main financial hub, Frankfurt, has seen a modest rise in the number of registered companies as a result of Brexit.

Consumer prices rose by just 0.4% in 2020, reflecting low oil prices, the hit to demand from the coronavirus and the cut to the VAT rate in July-December. January 2021 saw a change in trend, with annual inflation rising to 1.6% as a consequence of the end of the VAT cut, new carbon emissions certificates raising transport and heating costs, and a minimum-wage rise. Annual price growth will remain slightly above the euro zone average in 2021 as a consequence of these changes in administered prices. We expect inflation to average 1.8% in 2021, before moderating to an average of 1.6% in 2022-25, allowing for a continuation of the ECB's accommodative monetary policy.

The euro experienced high volatility throughout 2020. A depreciation against the US dollar in the early months of the year, when the coronavirus forced European countries into lockdowns, was followed by a rapid appreciation after the EU announced the establishment of a new recovery fund worth EUR750bn. We forecast that the euro will stabilise at an average of US$1.21:EUR1 in 2021, supported by the weakness of the US dollar. In 2022-23 we expect depreciation against the dollar, owing to a protracted economic recovery, muted inflation and continued monetary accommodation from the ECB, which will maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy stance for longer than the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). The euro will strengthen from 2024 onwards, supported by the euro zone's structural current-account surplus and by the gradual unwinding of the ECB's asset purchases.

Germany's current-account surpluses were the largest in the world in nominal terms in the four years to 2019, and we expect them to be so again from 2021, after temporarily falling below China last year. They are underpinned by huge trade surpluses, reflecting the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector. This will continue to generate large domestic savings that are mainly invested abroad, leading to a solid primary income surplus.
We expect the 2020 recession to have caused a decline in Germany's trade surplus, as the fall in exports outstripped the fall in imports. We estimate the current-account surplus at the equivalent of 6.8% of GDP-down from an annual average of 7.8% in the previous six years. Trade and primary income surpluses will comfortably outweigh narrow structural deficits on the services and secondary income accounts throughout our forecast period. We expect the current-account surplus to recover in nominal terms in 2021. In 2022-25 we forecast that the external surplus will average 6.9% of GDP as world trade volumes and investment flows recover.
