Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multi-party democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. In 2015 Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari, who secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 7.5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Muhammadu Buhari, to stay in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. He will be under immense pressure to stabilise Nigeria, but myriad security threats will prove unmanageable. The military and police are overstretched and unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will be triaged, with military resources deployed to whichever is considered the most pressing.
This shaky system will keep the government in power but leave the country highly dysfunctional and, in many regions, extremely insecure. The government will remain embroiled in a conflict with Boko Haram and Islamic State of West Africa Province (ISWAP), two Islamist terrorist groups firmly ensconced in north-eastern Nigeria. As the region is a stronghold of the ruling party, the All Progressives Congress (APC), the president will be committed to asserting control, irrespective of how difficult this will be. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east-particularly Borno state-will remain a low-level conflict zone, and the campaign there will divert security forces away from other insecure parts of Nigeria.
One hotspot that is likely to be more neglected is the agricultural Middle Belt, where violent conflict between farmers and herdsmen over increasingly scarce land and water resources has killed thousands in recent years. Formal land-titling is often touted as a solution to the crisis; however, as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. As with the north-east, the direct effects of the conflict will be localised, but the entire country will feel the fallout in the form of reduced local food production and high prices.
The military and police will be poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping, particularly in the north-west. There is also evidence of terrorist groups operating more openly in the north-west, highlighted by a recent mass kidnapping at a school there. Over 2021-25 the region could begin to resemble the highly insecure north-east as, essentially, a "no-go" zone.
Nigeria's federal government has weathered severe but localised (largely rural) security problems for several decades without overall stability being jeopardised, but the near- to medium-term outlook is made more uncertain by the scars of recession in 2020 and by rising levels of unemployment and poverty. Declining living standards arguably exacerbated and prolonged protests over police brutality that broke out in cities across southern Nigeria in October 2020. Avoiding a repeat of these will be paramount for Mr Buhari's administration, and in practical terms this means that a pro-market reform agenda that made impressive headway in 2020-with subsidies relaxed on fuel and electricity-is judged to have wilted, and that should protests again break out, concessions would be expected.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next national elections are due in 2023. In the most recent presidential election, in 2019, the candidates of both main parties were from the north, and custom dictates that the candidates in 2023 will be from the south. This should lead to an improvement on the abysmally low turnout in 2019 in the south, which is a stronghold of the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP). Frustration with high prices, declining living standards and perpetual instability will be directed at the APC, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations Nigeria will remain a major player in Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Land borders that were closed to goods since late 2019 have reopened, but Nigeria's government is unlikely to show much enthusiasm over encouraging regional trade, beyond its obligations under the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCTFA). The trade pact compels Nigeria to eliminate 97% of tariff lines over the next five to ten years. This deadline will not be met early, given high prices in Nigeria and declining external competitiveness for industries that could otherwise benefit from regional market access. Protectionism (underpinned by foreign-exchange restrictions) also makes Nigeria's adoption of a common West African currency, the eco, highly unlikely.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Nigeria's government and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will aggressively promote local industry, but some elements of policy are contradictory and will contribute to macroeconomic imbalances. A theme of considerable importance for overseas investment will be management of the exchange-rate regime. A ban on foreign-exchange access for imports of certain manufactures and agricultural goods (which currently covers 45 items) is being enforced to protect local industry and support the naira, but has some major flaws. Most notably, restrictions are elevating inflation and undermining the currency regime through sustained real effective exchange-rate (REER) appreciation. Despite this, currency restrictions are expected to last throughout the forecast period, being central to the CBN's economic development strategy.
There are multiple exchange rates in operation, with the central bank essentially overvaluing the official rate and-to a lesser extent-the Nigerian autonomous foreign-exchange fixing (NAFEX) rate, which is used by exporters and investors. There is now a wide spread between these and the parallel-market conversion. The CBN has given mixed messages about unifying Nigeria's exchange rates. Although strides were made in 2020 to merge the official and NAFEX rates, the CBN has allowed a differential to return and lasting adoption of a market-determined currency is not expected over 2021-25, with the CBN adamant such a move would lead to an overshoot and an inflationary spiral.
Faced with hard currency shortages in 2020, the CBN has allowed a backlog of foreign-exchange orders from investors and importers to accumulate in preference to drawing down reserves. Market turnover has recently edged up, but the backlog will only be cleared slowly in 2021 to modulate capital outflows, further undermining the currency regime's international reputation. A pattern of inflexibility by the CBN in the wake of oil price shocks (with similarly severe foreign-exchange shortages in 2015-16) will have a long-term impact on confidence, and partly explains our projection for foreign direct investment to equal 1% of GDP or less throughout the forecast period.
Over time the contradiction between protectionism and the AfCFTA's principles will become increasingly conspicuous, but we do not expect an immediate change in strategy given that non-tariff barriers will be phased out over a long timeframe. Developing manufacturing and agriculture is likely to be viewed as a means of preparing for the eventual elimination of tariffs, with currency controls expected to play a role in hastening the process. However, an infrastructure deficit, REER appreciation and instability in agricultural heartlands mean that Nigeria will struggle to acquire new comparative advantages in 2021-25, leaving the fiscal and external accounts and the naira exposed to oil price swings.
Price controls will be another important area of economic policy. Astonishing strides towards the deregulation of petrol and electricity pricing were made in 2020, but electricity price increases have already been scaled down in the face of political pressure. A reinstatement of outright petrol price controls is made less likely by a new Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) that we expect to be passed in 2021. The legislation is likely to streamline sector-wide regulation in the process of creating a new, profit-oriented national oil company, which by definition could not be weighed down by subsidising the retail market. The downstream industry should become commercially viable from this reorganisation of the sector, allowing Nigeria to wean itself off petrol imports, with a new 650,000-barrels/day refinery expected to come on stream in 2022. The PIB will also encourage upstream oil investment by making fiscal terms clearer for multinationals. However, we do not expect the sustained electricity price increases that are needed for the power sector to become financially sound, and pricing in the sector remains regulated de jure. Electricity undersupply will therefore continue to hinder industrialisation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy We expect the fiscal account to stay in deficit in 2021-25. Receipts from crude oil make up more than 50% of the federal government's retained income, and an average world oil price of US$56/barrel in 2021-25 will be insufficient to balance the budget.
The federal government's tax take is among the worlds lowest, owing to widespread evasion and a large informal sector. Value added tax (VAT, currently of 7.5%) is viewed by the authorities as the most effective means of increasing fiscal receipts, and we expect three equal VAT rate increases, taking the rate to 15% by 2025. The first is expected in 2022, prior to the next elections but seemingly inevitable given a rising debt load. Further increases are expected in 2024 and 2025. Even then, our federal revenue projection peaks at just 4.9% of GDP in 2024.
Set against this, high debt-servicing costs, a large public wage bill and healthcare commitments-including procurement of coronavirus (Covid-19) vaccines-will elevate expenditure. Capital investment will also be emphasised from 2021 now that petrol subsidies (which were formerly taken from revenue) have ostensibly ended. The government justified price deregulation by promising to invest the savings in infrastructure, and will be under pressure to match rhetoric with action. Consequently, we expect the highest spending/GDP profile since the global financial crisis in the latter half of the forecast period.
Overall, we expect the fiscal deficit/GDP ratio to be broadly stable in 2021 compared with 2020, at 3.5%, given elevated healthcare costs and other spending pressures. This will decrease, reaching 2.7% in 2024 as revenue peaks, before widening again to 3% in 2025 as oil prices slide. The government has raised its public debt limit to 40% of GDP to incorporate higher budget shortfalls over the medium-term and to accommodate securitisation of CBN deficit financing as long-term debt. A debt/GDP ratio of 40% would be unmanageable given low revenue, but we expect the ratio to reach about 31% of GDP in 2025, with domestic borrowing prioritised by the government in the near term as real interest rates stay relatively low.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The CBN will fail to keep inflation below a target ceiling of 9%, and its policy decisions are likely to be erratic. In 2020, given a probable recession and limited fiscal firepower, it decided to cut the policy rate by a cumulative 100 basis-points. The rate has been kept at 11.5% despite an upward trend in annual inflation, which reached 16.5% in January. The strategy is to boost the supply side of the economy to control inflation. We believe this is misguided; high and rising inflation will frustrate an economic recovery, and issues such as inadequate public infrastructure, direct funding of the fiscal deficit, hard-currency shortages and rampant instability need to be addressed before the supply side can moderate the price level. We expect high inflation to persist, compelling the CBN to raise interest rates in 2022, despite still-weak economic growth. Easing will resume only in 2024 when inflation has fallen appreciably.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The economy is expected to exit recession in 2021 as the impact of lockdown in 2020 fades, but high inflation will impede improvements in business sentiment and dampen real purchasing power amid high levels of underemployment and low nominal wage growth. Fiscal stimulus will be an inadequate counterforce given budget constraints, and loosened monetary policy will pressurise the naira, creating a scarcity of foreign exchange and further undermining macroeconomic stability. Oil production will, however, rise slightly as quotas agreed by OPEC+ (comprising OPEC and a group of non-OPEC countries) are relaxed, and, given an uptick in oil exports, we expect growth of 1.1% in 2021.
The CBN is expected to tighten monetary policy from 2022, which will circumscribe but not halt the nascent economic recovery, but the exchange rate should stabilise and cause inflation to ease. As non-business financial penetration is low, private consumption will recover alongside disinflation even as interest rates rise. OPEC+ quotas will be raised from April that year and new refining capacity is expected to come on stream in earnest, boosting real exports (with some output for the regional market) and reducing imports. We therefore expect growth of 3% in 2022. As refinery output continues to ramp up, crude oil exports rise, inflation falls and real spending power recovers, growth will pick up to an annual average of 3.8% in 2023-24. However, these rates of growth are well below potential. The economy will continue to lack dynamism owing to high interest rates, low foreign direct investment (FDI), high unemployment, pervasive instability in agricultural regions and infrastructure deficiencies, particularly regarding stable power supply. A more challenging year is forecast for 2025 as oil prices fall and macroeconomic uncertainty rises, with growth slipping back to 1.6%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation In 2021 we expect inflation to average 17%, with increases on both core and non-core levels. Higher world oil prices will translate into increased prices at the petrol pump following deregulation in 2020, and this will combine with the lingering pass-through of raised electricity tariffs, foreign-exchange restrictions on various imported goods-including staple foods-and devaluation of the naira. Assuming that rising oil prices stabilise the exchange rate, and that the CBN eventually tightens monetary policy, we expect the annual inflation rate to fall to an average of 10% in 2024. Conflict in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-as well as foreign-exchange controls on imported goods will prevent a faster fall. Currency devaluation in 2025 will cause the average rate to increase again, to 12.5% that year.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates A stronger outlook for world oil prices has softened our devaluation forecast for 2021, but we expect the official exchange rate to slide from N379:US$1 at present to N422.5:US$1 by end-2021 (probably in two stages). The more market-determined NAFEX rate has been weakening despite a recent oil price uptick-trading at about N410:US$1 in mid-February-and foreign reserves have declined since late January. The CBN is yet to clear a backlog of hard-currency orders that has built up, indicating that the draw-down is caused by a net outflow on current transactions despite firmer oil prices. The CBN is publicly opposed to making the exchange rate more flexible, but we believe a currency adjustment is unavoidable. Based on higher oil prices and the impact of devaluation in 2021, we expect the current account to return to surplus in 2022-24, while monetary tightening in Nigeria will again attract hot-money inflows. This should allow the official exchange rate to be kept broadly stable in these years. Unceasing currency misalignment means that REER appreciation will nonetheless resurface and, with oil prices expected to slide again in 2025, another devaluation to N485:US$1 is expected.
Forecasting the naira Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of its data presentations, as this is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. The official rate also best represents exchange-rate policy. Indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued, which is in line with official calculations.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector An export slump due to low world oil prices and OPEC+ production quotas will keep the current account in deficit in 2021, for a third consecutive year (a stretch unseen since the early 1990s), with a shortfall of 0.9% of GDP expected in that year. This is despite a slight uptick in imports of goods and services as the economy recovers and pandemic-related travel restrictions imposed in 2020 are lifted, with a devalued naira restraining the increase. Over the remainder of the forecast period we expect a small current-account surplus. Oil prices are projected to rise in 2022-23, which will expand exports while lower petroleum import volumes (as new domestic refinery capacity comes on stream) constrain growth in the import bill (which is otherwise driven by real naira appreciation). Remittances from the large Nigerian diaspora should also increase as the coronavirus crisis passes globally. This will all contribute to an annual average current-account surplus of 0.7% of GDP in 2022-24. The surplus will then ebb to 0.4% of GDP in 2025 as falling oil prices push down export earnings and continued REER appreciation encourage imports. The deficit in 2021 will be financed largely by debt inflows, with investment inflows being limited by a dysfunctional foreign-exchange market in that year.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text: - The right-wing government of the president, Jair Bolsonaro, has built an alliance with centrist parties in order to bolster governability in Brazil's highly fragmented Congress and to advance his economic reform and socially conservative agenda. Tensions with the judiciary will simmer as the authorities investigate the affairs of the president's sons.
- Economic policymaking will be guided by the need to manage the health and economic impact of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Fiscal, monetary and credit stimulus will be hefty, leaving considerable consolidation challenges in the recovery period. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the fiscal deficit widened to almost 14% of GDP in 2020, lifting the public debt/GDP ratio to 90%. Assuming recovery and consolidation in the medium term, we expect this ratio to stabilise.
- GDP will only recover fully to pre-pandemic levels in 2022. After an estimated GDP decline of 4.3% in 2020, the economy will grow by 3.2% this year. GDP growth will average 2% annually in 2022-25. Despite policy accommodation, Brazil's productive capacity will be damaged by the crisis, impairing medium-term potential growth.
- Interest-rate normalisation will begin in March, lifting the Selic policy rate from 2% to above 5% by 2022. We expect inflation will be above the 3.75% mid-point target in 2021 owing to higher commodity prices and a weak currency. Inflation will then be around the declining mid-point target (3.75% in 2021, 3.5% in 2022 and 3.25% in 2023) over the medium term.
- Assuming that international risk aversion eases once the coronavirus pandemic abates, we expect the Brazilian Real to recoup this year's losses, trading at below R5:US$1 from 2022. Assuming a recovery in import demand, the current-account deficit will widen to beyond 3% by 2025.
- Following recession in 2020, the projected recovery will expand Brazil's large domestic market to above US$2trn by 2025. Despite some simplifications, the tax system will remain burdensome and one of the weakest areas of the business environment. Infrastructure investment through a concessions prog-ramme will help to ease logistical bottlenecks, but upgrades and extensions will materialise only slowly.

- Fiscal consolidation needs after hefty stimulus during the coronavirus pandemic and the 2022 electoral cycle will complicate government efforts to improve the business environment and enact structural reforms. Brazil's large economy is attractive, but poor government effectiveness, a burdensome tax system, archaic infrastructure, deficiencies in factor markets and skills shortages will impair business.

Country forecast overview: Brazil's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Vested interests slow economy ministry's ambitious privatisations programme, but some divestments materialise.
2023-25: Privatisations continue slowly. Fiscal pressures encourage private capital in infrastructure projects. Investment Partnerships Programme (PPI) advances further, with improved legal framework and regulatory agencies.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic hits foreign direct investment (FDI).
2023-25: Ideological issues within current government put nationalist politics before economic pragmatism in some cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Despite anti-globalisation moves in advanced economies, some bilateral and regional trade negotiations progress. Deal between EU and Mercosul (Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) not expected to be ratified by EU parliaments.
2023-25: Steps taken to make Brazilian Real a fully convertible currency.
Taxes 2021-22: Post-coronavirus consolidation needs may lead to higher taxes.
2023-25: Tax simplification unifies three federal, state and municipal taxes into one value-added tax (VAT).
Financing 2021-22: Financial system weathers pandemic; Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) provides emergency credit. BCB gains independence, improving efficiency and competitiveness, reducing borrowing costs. Credit resumes after crisis.
2023-25: Renewed growth in domestic equity and bond issuance as state banks dial back subsidised credit lines.
The labour market 2021-22: Unemployment surges owing to pandemic. Government implements further measures to reduce cost of labour.
2023-25: Steps to boost long-term labour productivity complicated by continued weak education policies.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Infrastructure concessions advance (through PPI), but coronavirus, and political and institutional constraints may cause delays. Corruption and recession weigh on established construction companies, opening industry up for newcomers.
2023-25: Industry newcomers' lack of experience causes project delays.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Fifth-generation (5G) frequencies to be auctioned in 2021. Quality of communications rises as demand expands.
2023-25: Building of 5G infrastructure network commences and is rolled out to consumers.

Background: A new constitution was ratified in 1988 after more than 20 years of military rule. The government of Fernando Henrique Cardoso (1995-2002) ended hyperinflation and advanced reforms to liberalise the economy. Under a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), Brazil reaped the benefits of the reforms and enjoyed a consumer-led, commodities-fuelled boom. When this cycle ended, discontent owing to a weak economy, corruption and poor public services led to street protests. Lula's successor as president, Dilma Rousseff (2011-16), nonetheless won a second four-year term in 2014, but was impeached in 2016 over budget irregularities. Her vice-president, Michel Temer (2016-18), finished her term. Jair Bolsonaro won the October 2018 election and took office as president in January 2019.
Political structure: The president executes policy approved by the 513-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and the 81-seat Senate (the upper house). Constitutional review is conducted by an independent judiciary. Although the president can resort to temporary decrees to push through legislation, the constitution gives Congress ample scope to check the executive. In the lower house, 30 political parties are represented and party discipline has traditionally been weak.
Policy issues: The benefits and entitlements established under the 1988 constitution have contributed to a doubling in central government primary spending, to over 27% of GDP. Congress passed a federal spending cap in 2016 and a robust pension reform in October 2019. However, the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic led to expansionary fiscal, monetary and credit policies to offset the hit to the economy and financial system; The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the public debt/GDP ratio rose to 90% in 2020. The Banco Central do Brasil (the central bank) cut the Selic policy rate to 2% in August 2020-a record low-but will soon begin rate normalisation.
Taxation: Brazil has a poorly structured revenue system characterised by a heavy tax burden, a narrow tax base, complicated levies and widespread evasion. Both foreign and domestic companies employ tax professionals and devote considerable resources to managing their tax affairs. The corporate and indirect tax systems are particularly complex, porous and unwieldy; the income tax system is considered to be relatively efficient, with a top rate of 27.5%.
Foreign trade: The pandemic-induced recession and a weaker Real narrowed the current-account deficit to an estimated 0.9% of GDP in 2020. Agricultural exports support a moderate structural trade surplus.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The political environment will be shaped by the deployment of coronavirus (Covid-19) vaccines and the efforts of the right-wing, populist president, Jair Bolsonaro, to build a platform for his re-election bid in October 2022. His position has been strengthened by the election in February of his allies in the centrão (a group of traditional centrist parties that have long held the balance of power in Brazil's fragmented political system and now back Mr Bolsonaro) to key leadership posts in both the upper and lower houses of Congress. The new leader of the lower house, Arthur Lira of the Progressistas party, is likely to shelve opposition calls to open an impeachment trial against the president. This was previously a risk owing to the president's confrontational attitude towards Congress and the Supreme Court last year and his poor handling of the pandemic. Even so, to ensure governability by retaining the centrão's support, Mr Bolsonaro will need to grant party members political favours, including govern-ment posts and budget allocations. Meanwhile, the opposition-more progressive centrist parties as well as parties on the left-has suffered a blow and will struggle to reorganise following defeat in the congressional leadership elections. However, Mr Bolsonaro's unpredictable leadership style-displayed in his recent firing of the chief executive officer (CEO) of Petrobras (the state-controlled oil company) following local fuel price rises-and his often confrontational politics, which will come more to the fore in the election campaign, will remain features of the political landscape, sustaining tensions.
Mr Bolsonaro's popularity dipped after emergency cash payments ended in January. According to a local CNT/MDA poll, his rejection ratings rose to 51% in February, from 43% in October 2020. Looking ahead, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Bolsonaro to try to retain the support of his core conservative voters and of his new-found lower-income voters (who are particularly concentrated in the populous Northeast) to boost his re-election chances, but he will struggle to do the latter. Retaining the support of low-income voters will largely depend on additional cash payments, which we expect will be re-introduced from March for four months, but at reduced levels and to fewer people (about half the 70m or so previous recipients). To rally his right-wing supporters, Mr Bolsonaro will seek to push forward his socially conservative agenda, although this will meet some resistance from opposition parties, who will seek to block the measures in Congress and via the Supreme Court.
Mr Bolsonaro's proximity to the military (he is a retired army captain) has fuelled tensions, especially with the judiciary. We expect calm relations for now, but tensions could resurface given the president's impetuousness and investigations into both him (relating to alleged political interference in the federal police in 2020) and his sons, Carlos (a local councillor, involved in "fake news" campaigns against political opponents) and Flávio (a senator, implicated in a local assembly graft scheme). Not only has the president put retired military officers in important cabinet positions (including Hamilton Mourão as vice-president), appointed them to run a third of Brazil's state-controlled companies and stacked lower-ranking officials in the state bureau-cracy, but in early 2020 he actively supported bolsonaristas who attacked opponents in Congress (as well as in the judiciary and media) and called for military intervention. Tensions around election time are likely. However, a rupture of constitutional rule is unlikely, as voters would protest; polls suggest that 75% of Brazilians support democracy as the best form of government. In addition, most high-ranking, active military officials are reluctant to be closely associated with Mr Bolsonaro.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The November local elections saw a boost in votes for traditional centrist parties, suggesting that, regardless of their opinion of Mr Bolsonaro, voters are unlikely to elect a left-leaning president in October 2022. The field for the presidential race will be large, but it looks likely to be a re-run of the 2018 vote, with Mr Bolsonaro probably competing against the leftist Fernando Haddad, the runner-up in 2018. A former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), the most prominent member of Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT), recently backed Mr Haddad as its candidate, although the continuation of PT support assumes that Lula, who was convicted of corruption, does not unexpectedly become eligible to stand. However, the PT performed poorly in the local elections, and leftist parties are unlikely to unite behind a single candidate, which could reduce the chances of the PT candidate (or other emerging leftist rivals) contesting a probable second-round run-off. The surprise factor could come from a centre-right candidate such as João Doria, the governor of São Paulo state, but this third way could prove unsuccessful if centre-right parties also fail to unite. Notwithstanding the advantages of incumbency, a strong centre-right candidate could present a tougher contest for Mr Bolsonaro in a run-off, as the president would not be able to capitalise on anti-PT sentiment as he did in 2018. It is too early to make a call; Mr Bolsonaro's standing could be affected by unexpected developments in Brazil's tumultuous political environ-ment. His recent interference in Petrobras has damaged his reputation among the business community, who may look to back a more market-oriented figure.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The president's anti-globalist rhetoric and facilitation of illegal deforestation in the Amazon rainforest is tarnishing Brazil's international standing. However, as one of the world's ten largest economies and a major commodity exporter, Brazil will remain a significant global player. Under the new US administration of Joe Biden, bilateral relations will be cooler while Mr Bolsonaro is president given their divergent stances, particularly regarding climate change and deforest-ation. The relationship got off to a bumpy start, as Mr Bolsonaro was the last major world leader to congratulate Mr Biden, but we assume that a pragmatic approach will prevail, with common ground on anti-Chinese sentiment.
Brazil will remain one of the battlegrounds in US-China rivalry; a fifth-generation (5G) licence auction scheduled for 2021 will prove tricky for the government given the local presence of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company. Anti-Chinese rhetoric by nationalist government figures is stirring bilateral tensions, but military figures will encourage the president to be pragmatic regarding China's acquisition of assets, as Brazil needs investments in major infrastructure and energy projects. Moreover, Brazil's reliance on the Chinese coronavirus vaccine, Sinovac, will also temper the government's anti-Chinese rhetoric. We do not expect a free-trade agreement (FTA) between the EU and Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) to be ratified soon, owing to EU concerns over Mr Bolsonaro's environmental policies. Now that there is also pressure from Mr Biden on environmental issues, Brazil's efforts to join the OECD face delays.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Policymaking in 2021 will focus on the Covid-19 vaccine rollout and the government's structural reform agenda, which has been overshadowed by the pandemic. Mr Bolsonaro's commitment to reforms, and to fiscal consolidation and privatisations, generally remains lukewarm and is driven by his re-election interests. Policymaking has recently taken a turn for the worse and will now be more unpredictable and populist as Mr Bolsonaro seeks to avoid unpopular measures ahead of the 2022 elections and panders to his various groups of supporters. This was evident in his recent interference in Petrobras (to appease truckers' unions, who paralysed the country during a strike in 2018) after the firm raised fuel prices in line with international increases. Market risks include a change in Petrobras's pricing regime and possible efforts to reduce electricity tariffs by changing some rules of the game. If the economy stumbles, a more expansionary fiscal stance than expected in the 2022 election year cannot be ruled out, although it would encounter resistance in Congress.
Following the landmark approval of formal central bank independence shortly after taking office as leader of the lower house, Mr Lira's next legislative priority will be to pass the (delayed) 2021 budget. Parties will look for ways to find fiscal space to extend last year's emergency cash payments via a new social relief programme, while keeping to Brazil's 2016 constitutionally mandated public-spending cap, which Mr Lira (and the president) have vowed to uphold. However, it seems increasingly likely that they will seek a solution that sidesteps the rules. Nonetheless, any cash transfer programme will be much smaller in scale than the huge 2020 stimulus package. Thereafter, attention will turn to public-sector reforms, which aim to increase budget flexibility (over 90% of government spending in Brazil is non-discretionary) and reduce the costly public-sector wage bill. Political consensus around these reforms, which require constitutional amendments (known as the Federal Pact PEC, the Emergency PEC and the Public Funds PEC), has increased recently, making their approval (requiring three-fifths majorities in both houses of Congress) more plausible.
Other economic reforms will encounter more difficulties, although we still expect some progress by end-2021. Among them is a revenue-neutral tax simplification reform to unify three or more consumption taxes into a single value-added tax (VAT). Likewise, progress on the privatisation agenda will be slow owing to weak support from the centrão, as many of its members have vested interests in state companies. If any privatisations move forward, we expect them to be of smaller, non-strategic assets, such as the state-owned postal service; privatisation of Eletrobras, the state electricity company, is unlikely, even though Mr Bolsonaro recently sweetened the deal politically by offering legislators development funds from privatisation proceeds.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy After surging to an estimated 90% in 2020 owing to pandemic-related support measures, currency depreciation and recession, the public debt/GDP ratio will inch up as fiscal revenue only partly recovers. Stopping a more substantial rise will require consolidation; otherwise, concerns about debt sustainability will re-emerge among investors, raising the country risk premium. The government will seek to avoid raising taxes ahead of the 2022 election, but tax increases thereafter cannot be ruled out. The "state of calamity" approved by Congress amid the pandemic allowed the government to sidestep constitution-ally mandated fiscal rules in 2020 and increase spending, but extending this into 2021 (a growing possibility albeit not currently our baseline forecast) would unnerve investors. The fiscal hit from the crisis is apparent in the widening of the 12-month rolling overall deficit, to 13.7% of GDP in November 2020. We expect measures to be mostly retracted in 2021; the deficit will narrow to 7.6% of GDP as revenue increases. Consolidation of these trends will keep the deficit smaller than 7% of GDP throughout 2022-25. We anticipate that public debt will stabilise within the forecast period, helped by privatisation proceeds and currency revaluation, but there is a risk that debt will exceed 100% if the president yields to an election-related increase in spending.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy As the economy recovers in 2021-25, we expect policy normalisation, beginning in March, to take the Selic policy rate from 2% to 5.5% by 2023 (a real interest rate of 2-3%, which we consider neutral, up from over -2% currently). The mid-point inflation target will fall by 25 basis points each year in 2021-23, from 3.75% to 3.25% (the 2024 target will be set in 2021 and could fall further). The most significant risk to the environment of low interest rates and inflation is an unexpected abandonment of spending cap rules, which could trigger a market sell-off that may force the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) to tighten policy by more than expected.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following an estimated 4.3% contraction in 2020, real GDP will recover partly in 2021, expanding by 3.2%. However, growth in 2021 overall will be mostly due to strong statistical effects from the 2020 rebound, as sequential growth will be limited by the withdrawal of most fiscal stimulus. Although low (albeit rising) interest rates and inflation will be supportive factors, along with a recovering global economy, lasting damage to the productive sector and jobs, and to corporate and household balance sheets, means that we do not expect output to return to pre-coronavirus levels until 2022.
We expect real GDP to contract in the first quarter of 2021 as cash transfers end and the public health crisis worsens. Growth will be limited in the second quarter, with a gradual pick-up thereafter, boosted by wider distribution of Covid-19 vaccines. Our forecasts assume the approval of fiscal reforms and progress on other microeconomic reform agenda items, but we recognise that governability risks could hamper advances.
On the demand side, the upturn in 2021-25 will be driven by stronger investment (buoyed by infrastructure concessions and notwithstanding a normalisation in interest rates) and by private consumption, supported by credit growth. The re-introduction of (more limited) emergency cash transfers for the poor in March-June will prop up consumption slightly until the jobs market strengthens later in the year. On the supply side, commodity exports will accelerate in 2021-25, in line with a recovery in global demand. Manu-facturing has already rebounded owing to stimulus for consumers and a weaker currency, which could continue to make goods more competitive against imports in 2021-25. Positive vaccine news should boost consumer and business confidence, but the recovery of the services sector will not materialise fully until vaccines have been distributed beyond vulnerable groups, which should happen from mid-2021.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A stronger policy framework than in the past will help to anchor inflation expectations, and minimum-wage increases are unlikely to be much above infla-tion (if at all). There is a risk that inflation expectations will become unanchored if the government's commitment to fiscal consolidation wavers. Inflation reached 4.6% in February; we consider that the rise in inflation since mid-2020-related to higher food and commodity prices, a weaker currency and higher demand created by emergency cash transfers last year-will be transitory. Assuming a gradual economic recovery in 2021-25, and barring periodic weather-related food shortages, an unexpected surge in oil prices or fiscal slippage, inflation should fluctuate close to the (lower) mid-point targets for 2021 (3.75%), 2022 (3.5%) and 2023 (3.25%).
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Swings in global conditions and jitters over fiscal risks will keep the Real volatile, but it should continue to regain some of its 2020 losses over the medium term. The Real made gains in late 2020 as coronavirus-induced risk aversion eased, and ended the year at R5.2:US$1-about 22% weaker than at end-2019-although it has faced renewed depreciation pressures this year amid deteriorating economic expectations and market jitters over fiscal risks. We expect the Real to strengthen to R4.85:US$1 by 2025, fluctuating in line with Brazil's terms of trade, interest-rate differentials and global risk sentiment. A deeper local capital market for long-term debt will discourage corporate external borrowing, reducing capital inflows. The main risk to the forecast is the possibility of a market sell-off if confidence in debt sustainability evaporates.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Risks to Brazil's external position will be assuaged by its modest current-account deficit and external debt ratio, comfortable reserves cushion and a Real no longer overvalued by high interest rates (as in the past). Public external debt is low, and most companies have some sort of currency hedge, despite moderate private external debt. The trade balance will post a large structural surplus in 2021-25, owing to stable commodity exports to China, but this will narrow gradually as imports rise following recession-related compression in 2020.
After narrowing in 2020, the current-account deficit will widen gradually in 2021-25, as imports recover in line with the economy, and will reach 3.4% of GDP in 2025. However, inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) will match this, averaging 3.6% of GDP in 2021-25, reflecting sizeable market opportunities.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; unless otherwise stated, The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data
Global data Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Oil prices: Dated Brent import price
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
US consumer price inflation: OECD
US$ effective exchange rate: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IFS, various issues
Budget balance: refers to nominal public-sector borrowing requirement
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Demographic indicators: IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
Exchange rate: IFS, various issues; market rates expressed as Reals per US$1
GDP growth by demand component: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; 1995 prices
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: UNCTAD, World Investment Report; IFS
Inflation: Índice de Preços ao Consumidor Ampliado (IPCA, a national consumer price index based on surveys in ten cities, December 1993=100), calculated by the IBGE; IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Brazil to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average PPP for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Real GDP growth per head: growth in real GDP divided by population growth
Total external debt: sum of long-term and short-term debt, plus arrears; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS, various issues; local currency GDP, converted to US$ at the estimated annual average PPP for consumer products
US$ GDP: IFS, various issues; in current prices, converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rates
Abbreviations FGV: Fundação Getúlio Vargas
IBGE: Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística
IFS: IMF, International Financial Statistics
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Abstract: The economic downturn in 2020 has led to the biggest credit growth boom in a decade, facilitated by Turkey's state banks and a politicised central bank and creating further sources of economic instability. Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+March+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-03-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The re-election of Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president, in June 2018 concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) to stay in power until at least 2023 (when the next pres-idential and parliamentary elections are due), maintaining a tight grip on national institutions and the media in order to continue to dominate Turkish politics.
- The economy has become less stable as a result of domestic political tensions, fraught international relations and unorthodox economic policies. This has jeopardised the hard-won improvements in macroeconomic stability on which the AKP built much of its previous electoral success. The economic downturn in 2020 has led to the biggest credit growth boom in a decade, facilitated by Turkey's state banks and a politicised central bank and creating further sources of economic instability.
- Turkey's foreign policy priorities have shifted under the AKP since the early 2000s. Declining trust in the US and the EU, a gradual shift to a multipolar world and an ambition to make Turkey a regional power have all incentivised the AKP to pursue a "Turkey first" approach to foreign policy. Turkey is at odds with its peers in the eastern Mediterranean over maritime borders and vast offshore gas reserves. The risk of military confrontation with Greece, in particular, has risen. Mediation of the conflict by Germany and the US will be vital to de-escalate the volatile situation. Turkey has openly backed Azerbaijan in its military conflict with Armenia over Nagorny Karabakh, and has deployed peacekeeping troops to the region, along with Russian troops.
- Poor government policies and the lack of credible institutions have created large external imbalances and triggered a lira sell-off in 2020. We believe that Turkey will avoid a balance-of-payments crisis, but risks have risen.
- After a slowdown in real GDP growth to an estimated 0.4% and a forecast recovery of 4% in 2021 and 4.1% in 2022, we expect average growth of 3.6% per year in 2023-25-short of the government's annual 5% target but close to Turkey's medium-term potential.
- Turkey's heavy reliance on often volatile, short-term capital inflows to fund lending and drive economic growth leaves the economy vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment. However, the country's location and its large consumer market make it an attractive place to do business.

- Turkey's business environment score deteriorates in the forecast period (2021-25). The country's global ranking drops by ten places to 55th, and it falls to last place in the regional ranking. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, a politicised central bank and high domestic inflation have raised uncertainty about the direction of economic policy.

Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Adverse market conditions delay any reform momentum and privatisation deals.
2023-25: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) has been a government priority, but macroeconomic instability, increased nationalism and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2023-25: Further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors could boost FDI inflows.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: The threat of sanctions from the US and the EU continues to hurt Turkey's trade and investment environment.
2023-25: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes 2021-22: To finance widening fiscal deficit, government raises income and value-added taxes, including on alcohol and tobacco.
2023-25: Tax collection capacity will improve, but tax evasion remains an issue. No tax rises in the 2023 election year.
Financing 2021-22: The Central Bank of Turkey continues to raise its policy rate in early 2021, before gradually returning to an easing cycle. Government lending policy leads to a sharp increase in contingent liabilities.
2023-25: The government reverts to relying on state banks to extend credit and support economic growth. Continued reliance on capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues. Contingent liabilities remain problematic.
The labour market 2021-22: Government measures to support employment and ban layoffs end. The inactivity rate continues to rise and the size of the shadow economy increases.
2023-25: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Next stage of Istanbul airport is operational. Slower progress made on other projects, including Istanbul Canal.
2023-25: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. New industrial zones become operational. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks may persist.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2023-25: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade. Under current political circumstances, EU accession will not be possible in 2021-25.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religious conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule. There was a failed coup in July 2016. Turkey has had a presidential system of government, in place since the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, changed the parliamentary system in 2018, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of Mr Erdogan, the AKP leader, who was re-elected for a second presidential term in June 2018.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira in the 2020 recession are the major policy challenges. The government rolled out a large fiscal stimulus to support the economy in 2020 and is using its state banks to expand credit growth. This has led to major external imbalances and a sharp lira sell-off. Negative real interest rates and high political risks have led to inadequate capital inflows into Turkey and increase the risk of a balance-of-payments crisis. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is an important challenge, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. In January 2020 the highest marginal tax rate was raised from 35% to 40% for incomes of more than TL500,000 (US$69,000). Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2019 goods exports totalled US$182.2bn and imports about US$199bn, creating a trade deficit of about US$16.8bn, but a rare current-account surplus of US$6.9bn (1.1% of GDP).

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president, and his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) have dominated Turkey's political scene since 2002. During this period they have tightened their grip on authority, replacing Turkey's parliamentary system with an executive presidential system in 2018. The economy has become less stable as a result of political tensions, fraught international relations and unorthodox economic policies. This has jeopardised the hard-won improvements in macroeconomic stability on which the AKP built much of its previous electoral success.
Mr Erdogan's approval ratings dipped in 2020, following a steep sell-off of the Turkish lira against all major currencies, high inflation and a weak labour market. To restore policy credibility vis-à-vis foreign investors, while also trying to reverse worsening popularity ratings in 2020, Mr Erdogan made changes to Turkey's top economic management team in mid-November. In February Mr Erdogan also announced that discussions on a new constitution would begin soon. Details are not yet available, but it could include processes to ensure that Mr Erdogan stays in power beyond 2028, when his second term as president ends, if he wins the 2023 presidential election. Mr Erdogan has also vowed to introduce a number of economic and judicial reforms for 2021 and to improve human rights and strengthen property rights to appease Western govern-ments and foreign investors. Despite Mr Erdogan's calls for legal reforms, The Economist Intelligence Unit remains sceptical. The government will continue to clamp down on domestic political opposition in the years to come. Some political opponents of the government will also remain in prison on alleged terrorism charges, including a number of Kurdish opposition politicians.
In order to distract from domestic economic and political woes, the AKP also resorted to a more assertive foreign policy in 2020, including in Azerbaijan, Syria and the eastern Mediterranean. This tactic received wide domestic backing in 2020. Given that the authorities are well aware that Turkey's economic imbalances could spell trouble in 2021, we continue to expect Turkey's foreign policy to be particularly assertive this year.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch Mr Erdogan was re-elected president in June 2018, with 52.6% of the vote. At the parliamentary election, held at the same time, the AKP lost its absolute majority, although it secured a coalition majority with the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared to be mostly free but largely unfair: opposition candidates received little or no media coverage.
Mr Erdogan and the AKP are likely to win the next presidential and parlia-mentary elections-scheduled to be held in 2023-because of the president's dominance of the media, a systematic clampdown on political opposition and their popularity among Turkey's conservative voter base. However, the AKP will face tough competition from the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP). According to a poll in early 2021 by MetroPoll, support for the AKP has fallen to its lowest point since 2002, at about 30%, and the CHP is polling at about 21%. The MHP is polling at just under 7%-below the 10% threshold to enter parliament. A new party founded by a former prime minister, Ahmet Davutoglu, and another by a former deputy prime minister, Ali Babacan, may also attract AKP supporters, as they target a similar conservative voter base, although not to levels that would threaten the AKP's hold on power. In the presidential election Mr Erdogan is currently neck and neck in the polls with Ekrem Imamoglu, the major of Istanbul and candidate for the CHP.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The AKP and Mr Erdogan want to bolster Turkey as a regional power, and the government has been pursuing a more assertive foreign policy stance. This policy has backfired and resulted in deteriorating relations with regional peers and the West.
Turkey has antagonised Greece through continuous deployment of an energy exploration research vessel in disputed waters in the gas-rich eastern Mediterranean. The EU has strongly condemned Turkey's assertive behaviour and has warned that it might impose sanctions, although we expect that these would be only light restrictions. Greek-Turkish exploratory talks, which entered the 61st round, resumed in mid-January in Istanbul, but have not resulted in a settlement between the two NATO allies, and we expect tensions to persist.
Turkey has openly supported Azerbaijan after a conflict erupted with Armenia over Nagorny Karabakh in late 2020. Under Russian mediation, a ceasefire agreement has come into force. Turkey has deployed peacekeeping troops to the region, along with Russian troops, securing Turkey's influence in the south Caucasus.
Turkey's purchase of the Russian-made S-400 defence system in 2019, its ties with Hamas, a Palestinian Islamist group, and its provocations in the eastern Mediterranean have strained Turkish-US relations. Following Turkey's purchase of the defence system, the US introduced sanctions (in mid-December), but these are relatively mild and target Turkey's defence procurement agency, in effect cutting Turkey off from US military hardware and technology. Under the presidency of Joe Biden, relations with Turkey could take another turn for the worse, but although Mr Biden might be prepared to take a tougher line than the Trump administration with Turkey, US policy will probably continue to emphasise the need to keep Turkey in the Western camp. Nevertheless, there is still a risk that the US may impose tougher sanctions (for instance, if Turkey fully activates the S-400 defence system). In a worst case scenario, Turkey could join other US-sanctioned countries (Iran, North Korea and Russia), and would be denied access to international financial institutions. Turkey is attempting to cool tensions and has proposed setting up a joint working group with the US on the defence system.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The economic downturn in 2020 has led to the biggest credit growth boom in a decade, facilitated by Turkey's state banks and a politicised central bank. This has kept inflation high through lira depreciation. However, in November 2020 Mr Erdogan changed course and replaced the central bank's governor, Murat Uysal, with the former finance minister, Naci Agbal. The Treasury and finance minister, Berat Albayrak (Mr Erdogan's son-in-law), announced his resignation and was replaced with Lutfi Elvan, a former deputy prime minister. These changes came after the lira approached TL8.5:US$1 in early November. Mr Agbal's appointment and the accompanying policy rate rises have pushed real rates into positive territory and strengthened the lira. Mr Agbal champions orthodox monetary policies and has the apparent consent of the president. Mr Erdogan has vowed that the central bank will deliver "price, financial and macroeconomic stability" and administer "bitter medicine" to the economy. This U-turn in the president's rhetoric marks a first step towards policy normality and transparency. However, there remains a risk that the central bank will come under political pressure to lower rates again, particularly if economic activity remains sluggish.
Although we remain sceptical that these new appointments will be sufficient to implement much-needed economic reforms, the risk of a financial crisis in 2021 has fallen. Reforms to address the structural imbalances that underlie its recurring boom-and-bust economic cycle are needed. If the government reverts to its preferred policy of unsustainable rapid credit growth, a sudden credit stop and a potential balance-of-payments crisis would follow in our forecast period. There is also a risk of US financial sanctions, which would further impede Turkey's ability to attract foreign-currency inflows and restrict Turkey's access to global debt markets.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy Under the AKP, the public finances have been one of the economy's most reassuring aspects, but this credibility is eroding.
The deficit reached an estimated 3.7% GDP in 2020 as coronavirus-related restrictions negatively affected revenue growth and the government deferred collection of some tax and social security premium payments. In 2021 the budget deficit will ease, to 3.1% of GDP. We expect Mr Elvan to introduce a more prudent approach to the public finances to restore policy credibility towards investors. Further increases in indirect taxes and a restructuring scheme for tax payments, social security arrears and other obligations to the state should also benefit the budget this year.
Ahead of the election year in 2023, we expect the budget deficit to stay elevated, averaging 2.8% of GDP per year in 2022-23. The deficit will then narrow, to an average of 1.8% in 2024-25, as the government tries to rein in spend-ing to reassure investors. Government debt is estimated at 33.8% of GDP this year, and will peak at 34.3% in 2022-23, before falling gradually to 31.3% in 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The Central Bank of Turkey implemented an ultra-loose policy in the early stages of the coronavirus crisis and cut the main policy rate by 300 basis points to 8.25% in the first half of 2020, pushing real rates firmly into negative territory. The central bank's accommodative policy had helped economic activity to recover, but also contributed to a lira sell-off, the rapid loss of foreign-exchange reserves and high inflation. From August 2020 the central bank reversed course and started to tighten policy, although the initial tightening was conducted via the back door. Only after it became apparent that the tightening measures were insufficient to stop the lira's slide did the central bank raise rates, by a total of 875 basis points to 17%, between September and December, compared with the annual rate of inflation of 14.6% recorded in December. Real positive interest rates have helped to restore Turkey's credibility with investors and will start to have a positive effect on curbing the dollarisation rate of lira deposits. The banking regulator abolished the "asset ratio" for banks, which previously forced lenders to extend credit and buy sovereign bonds, and which had been partly responsible for Turkey's credit boom.
The central bank left its main policy rate unchanged in January and February, but maintained its hawkish tone. Although the recent rate rises and the appointment of Mr Agbal are important signs that policy is becoming more orthodox, economic issues remain: the lira is weak, inflation remains high, large external imbalances have built up and foreign-currency reserves are low. We therefore expect the central bank to keep its rate unchanged in the first half of 2021, and to then ease it gradually towards the end of the year, cutting the policy rate to 15% by year-end as investor confidence returns and inflationary pressures abate.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth We estimate that Turkey's economy grew by 0.4% in 2020. The economy contracted in the first two quarters of the year (by 1.05% and 10.7% respectively quarter on quarter), but swift monetary loosening and rapid credit expansion led to an economic recovery of 19.1% in the third quarter. Expansionary monetary and credit policies were reversed in the fourth quarter, but high-frequency indicators (including industrial production and retail sales) point towards only a small contraction in the fourth quarter.
Coronavirus-related restrictions, which are dampening domestic demand, will result in subdued economic performance in the first few months of 2021. The Turkish government has ordered 50m coronavirus vaccine doses from China's Sinovac Biotech, and has already received 9.5m doses. The government has also agreed to procure 4.5m doses of the Pfizer (US)-BioNTech (Germany) vaccine, with an option to buy 30m additional doses. The vaccination programme only started in mid-January, but is among the fastest rollouts in the world; the authorities had administered 5.49 doses per 100 people as at February 16th-already ahead of most European peers.
To reduce economic imbalances, we expect that the authorities will keep fiscal, credit and monetary policy tight in the first half of 2021, but as the economy recovers gradually, we forecast full-year growth of 4%. A tight environment will constrain import growth in early 2021, and a stronger global macroeconomic backdrop this year will drive a partial recovery in export growth and support the external balance.
To restore investor confidence beyond 2021, additional reforms-such as guaranteeing the independence of the central bank and reducing government involvement in the banking sector-would be required. Nonetheless, despite its structural shortcomings, Turkey's catch-up potential is considerable and the economy is competitive, which underpins our view that growth will accelerate to 4.1% in 2022. In the 2023 election year we expect a stronger credit impulse to reappear, and real GDP growth of 3.9%. In 2024-25 we forecast average annual growth of 3.5%, which we believe is close to Turkey's medium-term potential.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation Inflation averaged a high 12.3% in 2020 as a result of the excessive lira deprecia-tion against the US dollar and the euro. We expect inflationary pressures to ease in 2021, with the rate declining to 11.1%, but to remain well above the central bank's official target of 5%, mainly because of high inflation expectations and rising global food and commodity prices. In 2022 we expect inflationary pressures to remain elevated at 9.5%, mainly because of higher oil prices.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates The lira, which depreciated to TL8.5:US$1 in the first week of November, from less than TL6:US$1 at the end of 2019, has since partly recovered, to about TL7:US$1 in mid-February. This follows the reversal of expansionary money and credit policies that had been introduced to combat the effects of the coronavirus pandemic. Overall, the lira weakened by about 19% on average in 2020, despite central bank interventions. Foreign-exchange reserves fell from US$77bn in February 2020 to about US$54bn at end-January. Central bank swap agreements with domestic financial institutions rose to US$56.4bn at end-2020, from US$19bn in January. This implies that net reserves held by the central bank are negative.
In 2021 we forecast that the lira will weaken slightly in nominal terms, to an average of about TL7.3:US$1. Investor confidence in Turkish policymakers still hangs by a thread, international relations are poor and geopolitical risks remain high. In order to prevent more lira volatility, we expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the first half of the year, before easing it thereafter.
In 2022-25 we forecast that the lira will follow a depreciatory path amid an elevated current-account deficit, high inflation and a gradual normalisation of monetary policy in the US and the euro area.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector We estimate a current-account deficit of 5.5% of GDP in 2020. We expect subdued domestic demand and the still relatively weak lira to temper imports in 2021, and forecast that the current-account deficit will narrow sharply to 1.9% of GDP this year as the economy begins to rebalance. Attracting sufficient capital inflows to cover the deficit, as well as to service foreign debt without further damaging the inadequate levels of foreign-exchange reserves, will require a continuation of more cautious economic and foreign policies. Conditions for borrowing from abroad have been improving since the return to orthodox monetary policy in November. The government raised a total of US$4.75bn through international bond issues in November and December, which was the first issuance since the outbreak of the coronavirus.
The Central Bank of Turkey has normalised policy by raising borrowing costs for lenders, curbing credit growth, minimising exchange-rate interventions and raising the repurchase (repo) rate. By keeping a tight policy, it will prevent a balance-of-payments crisis in 2021. These measures will help to increase the ability of Turkish bonds this year to attract sufficient capital inflows and meet the country's US$182.1bn external debt obligations, of which US$54bn are principal repayments. Banks' access to bond markets will remain constrained this year, but many may opt for short-term syndicated loans, which will allow them to roll over external debt. However, there is a risk that, if the authorities do not keep a tight policy in the next few months, Turkey will be unable to attract sufficient foreign-currency inflows this year. This could make capital controls necessary and prompt Turkey to ask the IMF for an emergency loan, despite Mr Erdogan's opposition to such a move.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Nigeria&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Nigeria+February+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-02-08&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Nigeria&amp;rft.issn=0966887X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The tenure of the president, Muhammadu Buhari, will last until 2023 and be blemished by a decline in living standards caused by low growth, a rise in unemployment and (paradoxically) high, policy-induced inflation.
- The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This potent mixture has the potential to cause protests that halt the advancement of pro-market reforms.
- A decline in living standards under Mr Buhari, whose tenure has been marked by two recessions, as well as frustrations over pervasive insecurity and poor governance means that the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP) is forecast to win the 2023 election.
- The Economist Intelligence Unit expects some reregulation of electricity pricing under a PDP government. Although this would be bad news for the power sector, we do not expect a return to distortive pricing in the petroleum sector.
- Low world oil prices will continue to exert pressure on the multiple-exchange-rate regime and, in 2021, force another devaluation of the official rate. Foreign-exchange supply is then expected to improve, allowing the market to stabilise in 2022-25.
- Low oil prices in 2021 will coincide with large recurrent fiscal spending commitments (including healthcare) and result in another substantial fiscal deficit, by Nigerian standards. The budget shortfall will then broadly edge down as external conditions improve, the domestic economy picks up and revenue rises.
- Given a crippling infrastructure deficit, high inflation, instability in crucial agricultural regions and high unemployment, we expect growth of just 1.1% in 2021. Only when the exchange rate and inflation stabilise will there be a more meaningful recovery.
- Inflation will stay high in 2021 as devaluation of the naira, price deregulation, instability in agricultural growing areas, monetary loosening and exchange-rate restrictions for staple imports feed into consumer prices. Monetary tightening is expected to start from 2022 to tackle the issue.
- We expect a current-account deficit for a third consecutive year in 2021 (something that has not been seen since the 1990s) despite a modest increase in oil prices. The current account will return to surplus in 2022-25 as the oil market recovers and petrol import volumes decline.
