- Nigeria's business environment score worsens slightly for the forecast period (2021-25) as the macroeconomic and security environment remains highly challenging. As a result, its global and regional rankings fall.

Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: The overarching policy objective is to promote self-sufficiency and local industrialisation through protectionism. As a result, the non-oil sector is be largely shielded from external competition.
2023-25: A new government (which is likely to be opposition-led) is likely to remain wary of opening up the economy.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: A reduction is made to royalties for offshore oil activity introduced in 2020 in an attempt to prevent divestment from oil majors operating in Nigeria. Outside the oil sector, concerns over the foreign-exchange regime deter investment.
2023-25: Energy firms remain hesitant about increasing their presence in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore, but concerted efforts are made to clean up the national oil company (which is in joint venture with oil majors).
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Movement of goods is highly regulated to prevent smuggling, but people will be allowed to cross land borders once the coronavirus pandemic is brought under control.
2023-25: A spread between the official and the parallel-market exchange rates persists as oil prices rise and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) is again able to defend an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxes 2021-22: The focus on boosting tax compliance intensifies, but the weak state of the economy and upcoming elections prevent tax increases.
2023-25: Post-election, value-added tax (VAT) is raised from 7.5% to cut the budget deficit and tackle the high stock of debt.
Financing 2021-22: The government returns to the sovereign debt market, and capital projects are restarted.
2023-25: Credit conditions become tighter as the CBN moves to control high inflation.
The labour market 2021-22: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2023-25: Employers continue to struggle to find qualified staff; unemployment stays high and the labour market loose.
Infrastructure 2021-22: A reduction in consumer subsidies (for petrol) frees up resources for higher public capital investment, but government spending remains small relative to the size of the economy, at under 7%.
2023-25: A large private refinery starts up, reducing Nigeria's near-total dependency on imported petrol.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Nigeria retains a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2023-25: Research spending remains low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multi-party democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. In 2015 Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari, who secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 7.5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The president, Muhammadu Buhari, will stay in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. He will be under immense pressure to stabilise Nigeria, but myriad security threats will prove unmanageable. The military and police are overstretched and unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will be triaged, with military resources deployed to whichever is considered the most pressing.
This shaky system will keep the government in power but leave the country highly dysfunctional and, in many regions, extremely insecure. The government will remain embroiled in a conflict with Boko Haram and the Islamic State of West Africa Province (ISWAP)-two Islamist terrorist groups firmly ensconced in north-eastern Nigeria. As the region is a stronghold of the ruling party, the All Progressives Congress (APC), the president will be committed to asserting control, irrespective of how difficult this will be. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east-particularly Borno state-will remain a low-level conflict zone, and the campaign there will divert security forces away from other insecure parts of Nigeria.
One hotspot that is likely to be more neglected is the agricultural Middle Belt, where violent conflict between farmers and herdsmen over increasingly scarce land and water resources has killed thousands in recent years. Formal land-titling is often touted as a solution to the crisis; however, as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. As with the north-east, the direct effects of the conflict will be localised, but the entire country will feel the fallout in the form of reduced local food production and high prices.
The military and police will be poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping, particularly in the north-west. A recent mass school kidnapping in Katisna state highlighted the danger posed by sophisticated armed groups and was later claimed by Boko Haram. This serves as further evidence of terrorist groups operating more openly in the north-west, which is a development that the US military has warned about. Over the course of the forecast period, the region could begin to resemble the highly insecure north-east as, essentially, a "no-go" zone.
Nigeria's federal government has weathered severe but localised (predominantly rural) security problems for several decades without overall stability being jeopardised, but the near to medium-term outlook is given added uncertainty by the scars of recession in 2020 and rising levels of unemployment and poverty. Declining living standards arguably exacerbated and prolonged protests about police brutality in cities across southern Nigeria in October 2020. Avoiding a repeat of these will be paramount for the Buhari administration, and in practical terms this means a pro-market reform agenda that made impressive headway in 2020, with subsidies partly lifted on fuel and electricity, is judged to have wilted, and should protests again break out, concessions would be expected.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next national elections are due in 2023. In the most recent presidential election, in 2019, the candidates of both main parties were from the north, and custom dictates that the candidates in 2023 will be from the south. This should lead to an improvement on the abysmally low turnout in 2019 in the south, which is a stronghold of the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP). Frustration with high prices, declining living standards and perpetual instability will be directed at the APC, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations Nigeria will also remain a major player in Sub-Saharan Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Exasperation over smuggling, which policymakers view as undermining local industry, led the government to close all of Nigeria's land borders to goods traffic in late 2019 and only open them in late December 2020. Given high local prices and thus declining international competitiveness for Nigerian agricultural produce there will be no rush to open the economy up to food imports, although the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCTFA), to which Nigeria is a signatory, will require 97% of tariff lines to be eliminated over the next five to ten years. Protectionism (underpinned by foreign-exchange restrictions) also makes Nigeria's adoption of a common West African currency, the eco, highly unlikely.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends As part of its response to the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, the government has sought about US$6.9bn (about 2% of GDP) from multilateral lenders. Not all the loans are low-conditionality, encouraging Mr Buhari to enact the boldest economic reforms of his tenure. A cap on pump prices was removed in September 2020, causing petrol prices to reach record levels (for Nigeria). Ending petrol price caps is essential for freeing up fiscal space, and new refineries that are either being built or at the planning stage (including a 650,000-barrel/day facility under construction) will require pricing to be suitable for supply to the domestic market. Electricity tariffs have also been raised. Moving towards cost-reflexivity is crucial to alleviate a burden of bad debts that run along the power supply chain, which has made the sector dysfunctional and resulted in regular outages.
However, political pressure means the government may well fail to keep prices liberal on a permanent basis, and there has already been a scaling-down of electricity price increases. A reinstatement of outright petrol price controls (despite rising crude prices in 2021) is made less likely by a new Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB), which has a good chance of passing through parliament. The legislation is likely to streamline sector-wide regulation in the process of creating a new, profit-oriented national oil company (which by definition could not be weighed down by subsidising the retail market). The downstream industry should become commercially viable from this reorganisation of the sector, allowing Nigeria to wean itself off petrol imports as new refinery capacity comes on stream (which we expect to happen by 2022). The PIB will also encourage upstream oil investment by making fiscal terms clearer for multinationals. However, electricity tariffs are likely to remain heavily regulated, and we do not expect the sustained electricity price increases that are needed for the power sector to become financially sound. This implies that electricity undersupply will continue to hinder industrialisation.
Another policy area of considerable importance will be management of the naira. Low foreign-exchange inflows-reflecting low global oil prices-has provided scope for unifying the overvalued official exchange rate (used for government transactions) and the more market-determined Nigerian autonomous foreign-exchange fixing (NAFEX) rate, used by exporters and investors. A wide spread between these and the parallel exchange rate underlines ongoing market distortions, however. Rather than let the naira weaken on a sustained basis (political considerations are likely to be paramount in this regard) or clear a large foreign exchange order backlog by depleting reserves, the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) has widened an array of currency restrictions and let market turnover contract, widening the spread between the NAFEX and parallel rates, to aggressively curb the pace of outflows. Such policies will sustain considerable foreign-exchange illiquidity into 2021 as oil prices stay low.
The government plans to manage the exchange-rate regime "sustainably" only in the long term, and a range of market distortions are expected to stay in place in 2021-25 to protect local industry. A ban on accessing foreign exchange to purchase various imports (currently covering 45 foods and manufactures) is central to this strategy. Over time, the contradiction between protectionism and the principles of AfCFTA will become increasingly conspicuous, but we do not expect an immediate change in strategy, given that non-tariff barriers will be phased out only slowly. Industrialisation is likely to be viewed as a way of preparing for the eventual elimination of tariffs, with currency controls expected to play a role in hastening the process. However, an infrastructure deficit and instability in agricultural heartlands mean that Nigeria will struggle to acquire new competitive advantages over 2021-25, leaving the fiscal and external accounts and the naira heavily exposed to oil price swings. From an investor perspective, the managed nature of the exchange-rate regime poses a risk of capital controls, especially when oil prices are low. Partly because of the impact on investor confidence, foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows are projected at 1% of GDP or less throughout the forecast period.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy We expect the fiscal balance to stay in deficit in 2021-25. Crude oil receipts comprise more than 50% of the federal government's retained income, indicating a continued revenue crunch as oil prices stay low in 2021. Even then, widespread tax avoidance and low oil prices (below US$60/b on average in 2021-25) will keep federally retained revenue below 4% of GDP throughout the forecast period.
Set against this, high debt-servicing costs, a large public wage bill and emergent healthcare commitments will elevate expenditure. Capital investment for the purposes of stimulus will also be emphasised in 2021 now that subsidies (which were formerly taken from revenue) have been reduced, freeing up resources. Even so, we expect economic growth to fall well short of official projections in 2021, and a revenue undershoot indicates underexecution of the capital budget, being the most flexible spending category. Overall, in 2021 we expect a deficit equal to 3.6% of GDP, down only slightly from 3.7% of GDP in 2020. Higher oil prices will lessen the deficit in 2022, despite a pre-election increase in spending. With a probable rise in value-added tax (VAT) rates (to curb a hazardously high debt-revenue ratio) after the 2023 elections, and oil prices continuing to rise, the deficit will shrink to an average of 2.8% of GDP in 2023-24, before widening to 3% of GDP in 2025 as oil prices fall.
As interest rates are currently low for the sovereign, domestic debt will be more attractive in the near-to-medium term. The 2021 budget revealed considerable direct lending to the government by the CBN as well, with financing facilities likely to be tapped whenever domestic debt issuance rises above budgeted levels. Some multilateral loans will also be secured, but we expect the government to return to the international capital market from 2021 in order to supplement this.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The CBN will fail to prevent inflation from exceeding its target ceiling of 9% over much of the forecast period, and its policy decisions are likely to be erratic. In the context of a probable recession and limited fiscal firepower, it decided to cut the policy rate by 100 basis points to 11.5% in September 2020 (after a 100-basis-point cut in May), despite an upward trend in annual inflation, which reached 15.7% in December. The strategy is to boost the supply-side of the real economy and thereupon control inflation. In our view this is misguided; high and rising inflation will frustrate an economic recovery, and issues such as inadequate public infrastructure, direct funding of the fiscal deficit, hard-currency shortages and rampant instability need to be addressed before the supply-side can moderate the price level. Our expectation is for high inflation to persist, compelling the CBN to raise interest rates in 2022, despite economic growth still being weak. Easing will resume only in 2024 when inflation has fallen appreciably.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The economy is expected to exit recession in 2021 as the impact of lockdown in 2020 fades, but high inflation will impede improvements in business sentiment and dampen real purchasing power amid high levels of underemployment and so low nominal wage growth. Fiscal stimulus will be an inadequate counterforce given budget constraints, and loosened monetary policy will pressurise the naira, creating a scarcity of foreign exchange and further undermining macroeconomic stability. Oil production will, however, rise slightly as quotas agreed by OPEC+ (comprising OPEC and a group of non-OPEC countries) are relaxed, and given an uptick in oil exports we expect growth of 1.1% in 2021.
The CBN is expected to tighten monetary policy from 2022, which will circumscribe the nascent economic recovery, but the exchange rate should stabilise and cause inflation to ease. As non-business financial penetration is low, private consumption will recover alongside disinflation even as interest rates rise. OPEC+ quotas will be raised from April that year and new refining capacity is expected to come on stream in earnest, boosting real exports (with some output for the regional market) and reducing imports. Consequently, we expect growth of 3% in 2022. As refinery output continues to ramp up, crude oil exports rise, inflation falls and real spending power recovers, growth will pick up to an annual average of 3.7% in 2023-24. However, these rates of growth are well below potential. The economy will continue to lack dynamism owing to high interest rates, low FDI, high unemployment, pervasive instability in agricultural regions and infrastructure deficiencies, particularly regarding stable power supply. A more challenging year is forecast for 2025 as oil prices fall sharply and macroeconomic uncertainty rises, with growth slipping back to 1.7%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation Monetary loosening in 2020 (which will lead to currency adjustments), combined with higher fuel and electricity tariffs, foreign-exchange restrictions on various imported goods, including staple foods, and devaluation of the naira will raise inflation to an average of 16% in 2021, with increases on both the core and non-core level. Assuming that rising oil prices stabilise the exchange rate, and the CBN eventually tightens monetary policy, we expect the annual inflation rate to fall throughout 2022-25, to 8.5% at end-2025. Conflict and agricultural supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-as well as foreign-exchange controls on imported goods will prevent a faster fall.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates The CBN is supplying hard currency to regulated trading windows but only fitfully, and there is a large backlog of unmet foreign-exchange orders for capital and current transactions. Assuming that oil prices stay low in 2021 and with low domestic interest rates sustaining capital outflow pressures, we expect a devaluation of the official rate in that year (following two adjustments in 2020). This will take the naira from N379:US$1 at end-2020 to N450:US$1 by end-2021. The official and NAFEX rates will be broadly unified in the process. For the remainder of the forecast period, the official exchange rate is expected to be kept relatively stable. Monetary tightening in Nigeria will again encourage hot money inflows, and higher oil prices will return the current account to surplus. Divergence between official and NAFEX rates is likely to re-emerge, but the CBN should be able to supply adequate liquidity to regulated foreign-exchange channels, broadly stabilising the market even as world oil prices (and so net foreign-exchange flows) fluctuate.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector An export slump owing to low world oil prices and OPEC+ production quotas will keep the current account in deficit in 2021, for a third consecutive year (a stretch unseen since the early 1990s), with a shortfall of 1.4% of GDP expected in 2021. This is despite a slight uptick in imports of goods and services as the economy recovers and coronavirus-related travel restrictions imposed in 2020 are lifted, with a devalued naira restraining the increase. Over the remainder of the forecast period a small current-account surplus is expected. Oil prices are projected to rise in 2022-23, which will expand exports, while lower petroleum import volumes as new domestic refinery capacity comes on stream will constrain growth in the import bill (otherwise driven by real naira appreciation). Remittances from the large Nigerian diaspora should also increase as the coronavirus crisis passes globally. This will all contribute to an annual average current-account surplus of 0.9% of GDP in 2022-24. The surplus will then ebb to 0.7% of GDP in 2025 as falling oil prices push down export earnings and continued real effective exchange-rate appreciation encourage imports. The deficit in 2021 will be financed largely by debt inflows, with investment inflows being limited by a dysfunctional foreign-exchange market in that year.

Full text: - At the federal election on September 26th Angela Merkel will step down from her 16-year tenure as chancellor, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a coalition to be formed between the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and The Greens. We expect Markus Söder, the minister-president of Bavaria and leader of the CDU's sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), to be chosen as the CDU's chancellor-candidate, rather than the CDU's new leader, Armin Laschet-who is substantially less popular with the German public.
- The top policy goal at present is to stimulate the economic recovery, which requires the pandemic to be controlled and vaccinations rolled out. Following the federal election, we expect policymaking to remain centrist, consensus-oriented and pro-Western, with a strong degree of continuity from the current administration. However, green policymaking will gain additional importance.
- After a 5.3% fall in real GDP in 2020, we forecast 3.7% growth in 2021, with the recovery gaining pace in the second half of the year and the economy returning to its 2019 size by 2022. Germany's large manufacturing sector, which has close export links with the rapidly recovering Chinese market, has proved a structural advantage during the pandemic. Forced savings, pent-up demand and an extended wage support scheme will boost private consumption once the lockdown ends. We forecast 2.4% annual average growth in 2022-25.
- Monetary and fiscal policy levers are being used to the full to limit the fallout from the crisis. The European Central Bank (ECB) has its policy rate set at -0.5%, and has expanded its net asset purchases to EUR1.85trn (over 10% of euro zone GDP) as part of its emergency programme.
- Germany's fiscal policy response in 2020 was the largest in Europe. Provisional data indicate a 4.8% of GDP deficit in 2020 (although this does not reflect substantial loan guarantees from the state development bank, KfW), and fiscal support will continue in 2021. We expect political pressure to ensure a return to fiscal consolidation from 2022, although rising pension and healthcare commitments will maintain small deficits (within 1% of GDP) in 2023-25.
- Germany's large-and often controversial-current-account surpluses will persist, owing to huge trade surpluses and large domestic savings invested abroad. The current-account surplus dipped slightly to an estimated 6.8% of GDP in 2020, and we expect it to remain broadly unchanged as a share of GDP.

- The business environment benefits from political stability, a skilled labour force, openness to external trade and investment, and well-developed (if ageing) infrastructure. The exposure to external shocks is a constraint.

Country forecast overview: Germany's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: The state maintains its involvement in the financial sector, railways and telecommunications, and rolls out aid packages to companies highly affected by the pandemic. Germany accounts for about half of new state aid in the EU.
2023-25: Limited prospects for reforming regulated service professions. State intervention pushes green and digital goals.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: The government generally welcomes foreign direct investment, but Germany has lobbied hard to increase scrutiny at the EU level, and takeovers of major German media, infrastructure and finance companies now meet political resistance.
2023-25: Investment from China is increasingly unwelcome, given concerns about intellectual property leakage.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Pressure on German export sector from coronavirus hit to global demand, ongoing US-China trade war and Brexit disruption. Risk of escalation in US-EU trade tensions. Possible delays in progress on EU-Mercosur trade deal.
2023-25: EU makes further gradual progress on bilateral trade deals. Decline in post-Brexit UK-EU crossborder trade.
Taxes 2021-22: Fiscal loosening as part of the crisis response includes higher spending on healthcare, direct aid to self-employed people and an expansion of unemployment benefits. A comparatively high labour tax burden persists.
2023-25: Modest reform of management of corporate tax. Possible introduction of digital tax.
Financing 2021-22: Highly accommodative monetary policy keeps banks' funding costs and liquidity in the sector high. The government assumes most of the risk in financing this year via state-backed loans to businesses.
2023-25: Operating conditions for banks remain challenging. Ongoing efforts to attract financial services firms from the UK.
The labour market 2021-22: Unemployment is higher than pre-pandemic, but contained by the expansion of the Kurzarbeit scheme to end-2021.
2023-25: Limited prospects for reform to address structural challenges arising from ageing demographics and increasing share of migrant workers. Increased provision of childcare facilities supports moderate rise in female participation.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Investment in healthcare infrastructure. Focus on maintenance of transport network and improved digital access. Energy transition focuses on a national hydrogen strategy, and the sector calls for improvement of the power grid.
2023-25: New policy measures to meet medium-term emission targets, including gradual phasing-out of coal generation.
Technological readiness 2021-22: The government prioritises upgrading the country's digital infrastructure and investing in artificial intelligence.
2023-25: Efforts continue on Industry 4.0, which focuses on upgrading manufacturing prowess through increased use of automation and connected systems. Increasing threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.

Background: The modern German state was founded in 1870. After the second world war (1939-45) Germany was divided into two parts: a liberal parliamentary democracy in the west and a totalitarian communist regime in the east. On October 3rd 1990, after the end of the Soviet Union's hegemony in central and eastern Europe, Germany was reunified.
Political structure: Germany is a federation of 16 states, or Länder, each of which has its own constitution, government and parliament. The states are primarily responsible for policing and education. The federal parliament comprises the directly elected Bundestag (the lower house) and the Bundesrat (the upper house) of representatives of the state governments. The federal chancellor, the head of the executive, is elected by the Bundestag and can be brought down only by the election of a successor. In March 2018 a grand coalition was once again formed, comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD).
Policy issues: Short-term priorities focus on the response to the coronavirus pandemic and the resulting economic crisis. Medium-term priorities include managing the transition of the automotive sector towards lower-emission vehicles; building industrial sovereignty and increasing the resilience of supply chains; managing rising tensions with Russia and China; implementing the roll-out of fifth-generation (5G) technology, alongside continuing progress on the Industry 4.0 agenda; and transitioning the energy sector away from coal and nuclear power. Investment spending will increase in our forecast period (2021-25) compared with recent years.
Taxation: The federal corporation tax rate was cut from 25% to 15% in 2008. The effective corporate tax rate, including a municipal trade tax and a solidarity tax, is about 30-33%. The solidarity tax will be phased out from 2021. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45%. Social security contributions are shared equally between employers and employees. The main value-added tax (VAT) rate is 19%, but will be temporarily reduced to 16% during the second half of 2020.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus came to US$247.5bn in 2019, with export earnings at US$1.5trn and import costs at US$1.2trn. Germany's single largest goods export market is still the EU, but the country has been more successful than most in diversifying its markets and selling into fast-growing emerging markets over the past decade.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability Angela Merkel, the chancellor, leads a grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU)-along with its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU)-and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD). The 2017 federal election delivered a fragmented political landscape that made coalition-building difficult, and the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) won seats in the federal parliament for the first time. At the federal election in September 2021 Mrs Merkel will step down from her 16-year tenure as chancellor-a significant turning-point for Germany's political landscape. However, policymaking will remain centrist, consensus-oriented and pro-Western under the next government.
Mrs Merkel's already high approval ratings have risen during the coronavirus pandemic, with her calm demeanour, respect for scientific advice and recognised ability to manage crises reassuring voters. Germany's response to the public health crisis has been notable for stronger testing and contact tracing than other European countries, and a more localised response-both made possible by the country's decentralised administrative structure. Excess hospital capacity also proved an advantage. Nonetheless, during the (much worse) second wave over the winter, tensions have risen between federal and state-level authorities over the appropriate level of restrictions. Social unrest and "pandemic fatigue" have also emerged, with protests against social distancing and mask-wearing rules, especially in Berlin, the capital.
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the September 2021 federal election will lead to a CDU/CSU-Greens coalition, with the CDU's chancellor candidate succeeding Mrs Merkel. Armin Laschet, the centrist governor of North Rhine-Westphalia, was chosen as the CDU's new party leader on January 16th (in line with our forecast), but will not necessarily become the party's chancellor candidate, given his unspectacular poll ratings. Markus Söder, the leader of the CSU and governor of Bavaria, has won increasingly strong support among both party members and the general public during the pandemic, and although he has not yet declared his intention to run, we consider him the most likely choice. The decision on a candidate will only be taken after the state elections in March, either by the CDU/CSU leadership or its parliamentary deputies (there is no fixed process).
We would expect a CDU/CSU-Green coalition to be less fractious than the current grand coalition has proved, resulting in a rise in political stability. The parties share similar views on economic and climate change policies, and policy towards Russia. Frictions could be expected on fiscal policy, however, where the CDU/CSU will want to take a more hawkish stance, and relations with China, where The Greens will be more openly critical.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next federal election will take place on September 26th, and will result in a change in German chancellor for the first time since 2005. State elections in Baden-Württemberg and Rhineland-Palatinate on March 14th will provide early insights into voter support for the CDU, the SPD and The Greens. Baden-Württemberg is currently led by The Greens, and polls suggest that they are ahead of the CDU. Polls in Rhineland-Palatinate show the CDU narrowly ahead of the SPD, but the outcome here is far from certain, given the popularity of the state's SPD minister-president, Malu Dreyer. Poor results for the CDU in these elections would increase the likelihood of Mr Söder being chosen as chancellor candidate over Mr Laschet. A third state election will be held in Saxony-Anhalt (currently with a CDU-SPD-Greens coalition) in June.
At the federal level, opinion polls have been fairly consistent in recent months, with the CDU/CSU polling around 35%, the Greens around 19%, the SPD at 15%, the Alternative for Germany (AfD) at 9%, the Left Party at 8% and the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP) at 6%. This suggests that the CDU/CSU should be able to win a majority with The Greens. However, there are two "known unknowns". First, the impending departure of Mrs Merkel, who remains Germany's most popular politician, might not yet be reflected in the CDU's polling numbers. Second, continued slow progress in Germany's coronavirus vaccination programme could work to weaken the CDU's popularity.
Voter fragmentation will continue in 2021, but we expect the parties on the political extremes (the Left Party, and the AfD on the far right) to remain excluded from mainstream debate and from any governing coalition. An SPD-Green-Left Party coalition might be a mathematical possibility, but the uncompromising left-wing views of the Left Party make this unlikely. Should the CDU/CSU-Greens fail to win a majority they could be joined by the FDP or perhaps the SPD-although the latter is keen to avoid another grand coalition.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The European economic recovery fund clears the way for joint debt issuance (worth EUR750bn) to be channelled to EU member states with lower living standards and those hardest hit by the pandemic. From mid-2021 about EUR390bn is to be transferred in grants and the remainder through loans. The size of the fund is modest, but it will help to increase fiscal space in highly leveraged countries; Germany's U-turn on joint debt issuance in May was crucial to the agreement. The fund is a landmark step for the bloc, as it establishes a precedent for the EU to issue debt to fund common needs.
We expect US-EU relations to improve under the new US president, Joe Biden. Mr Biden will prefer diplomacy to tariffs, reducing the threat of a US-EU trade war, and is already returning the US to a number of multilateral platforms, including the Paris Agreement on climate change. However, on other issues-including OECD-level negotiations on a digital services tax, and EU relations with China-relations will remain strained.
Other EU external relations came under strain in late 2020. The poisoning of Alexei Navalny, a Russian opposition activist, prompted an unusually hawkish German response. We do not expect Germany to halt construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in the near term, but it may take other punitive measures against Russia. The EU and China have agreed in principle to conclude negotiations on a Comprehensive Agreement on Investment, but the ratification process by the European Parliament will be challenging, given European concerns about human rights and labour standards, and restrictions on allowing Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, to build fifth-generation (5G) telecoms infrastructure.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends As elsewhere in Europe, Germany is now well into the second wave of the pandemic, which has proved much more severe than the first wave, putting strains on hospital capacity and rendering the test and trace system ineffective. A "lockdown light" was imposed on November 2nd and substantially tightened on December 16th; we expect most of the current restrictions to be extended when they come up for renewal on February 14th. The vaccine rollout has begun, but is proving slow: one week into February Germany had given first doses to just 3.9% of its population, versus 18.8% in the UK.
The European Commission has temporarily relaxed its state-aid rules, in view of the exceptional circumstances this year, and we do not expect these to be reimposed until 2022 or (more likely) 2023. Germany's state-aid disbursements comprise about half of the EU total. Lufthansa, Germany's largest airline, is the biggest recipient, with a EUR9bn bail-out, followed by EUR3.3bn for Adidas, Europe's largest sportswear retailer, and EUR2bn for TUI, a multinational travel company. Firms in receipt of state aid may come under pressure to promote sustainability and to pay taxes in Germany rather than in lower-tax-rate jurisdictions.
Other ongoing areas of policy debate include how to build industrial sovereignty, raise the resilience of supply chains and support the transformation of the automotive sector towards low-emission vehicles. With The Greens all but certain to join the next federal coalition, the CDU and the SPD will both present policy programmes with a green agenda in 2021. The government's decision to support electric vehicles but not the automotive sector more generally in 2020, despite the industry's large lobby and the fact it accounts for about 830,000 jobs, is an indication of the policy direction.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy After six years of fiscal surpluses, the budget shifted into deficit in 2020, at 4.8% of GDP (provisional data). Germany's fiscal support and stimulus programmes are the largest in Europe, with key components including the following:

- the Kurzarbeit programme, a furlough scheme that allows firms to cut employees' working hours without having to lay them off, with the state paying at least 60% of the lost net wage payments until end-2021;
- a EUR50bn solidarity fund to help small businesses and the self-employed, and liquidity support for all companies that need assistance paying loans, irrespective of their size, totalling EUR500bn;
- a EUR3.5bn cash injection into the healthcare system, and transfers to local governments to help manage the crisis;
- a value-added tax (VAT) cut from 19% to 16% for July-December 2020, and a reduction in the VAT rate for the hard-hit hospitality sector to 7% until mid-2021 and until end-2022 for meals in restaurants and cafés.
- cash transfers to businesses that are forced to close under the winter lockdown, along with new tax deductions announced in February.

The government will run another deficit in 2021, albeit a smaller one. The Kurzarbeit programme will remain in place throughout the year and capital expenditure will be higher than before the pandemic. Over the next four years investment will be channelled to everything from artificial intelligence (AI), to the 5G rollout, to innovation in auto manufacturers. The health fund will receive a significant boost and a large chunk of the money will go to Germany's national hydrogen strategy, as part of its energy transition.
We expect Germany's public debt to peak at just over 72% of GDP in 2021, from around 60% in 2019. The government is taking advantage of an exception clause in the country's constitutional debt brake for crisis periods, lifting limits on new borrowing. The debt brake will remain suspended this year, but fiscal consolidation will then return-bringing the public debt/GDP ratio back to about 65% by end-2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The European Central Bank (ECB) has deployed an arsenal of policy weapons to limit the financial and economic fallout from the public health crisis. In addition to the open-ended quantitative easing (QE) programme and negative interest rates, several crisis tools have been brought into play.
Among the most effective are the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) and the boost to refinancing operations for commercial banks. The PEPP was designed to be temporary and flexible in order to allow the ECB to front-load purchases and cater to the countries with higher funding needs. Liquidity facilities have also been revamped, with the ECB formally adopting dual rates and easing rules around its collateral framework. These have prevented a damaging credit crunch by supporting bank lending to non-financial corporations, which was up by 6.3% year on year in November.
In view of the deflationary impact of the second wave of coronavirus in the euro zone, the ECB provided further stimulus in December. This includes a EUR500bn increase in the size of the PEPP, which is now worth EUR1.85trn, and an extension of its duration until March 2022. The ECB remains strongly committed to preventing financial fragmentation in the euro zone, which will keep at bay the risk of sovereign debt crises in highly indebted economies. Funding costs will remain very low in the medium term, and increases to policy rates are not part of our baseline scenario in 2021-25.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The German economy contracted by 5.3% in 2020, the first annual fall since the 5.6% contraction in the wake of the global financial crisis. Nonetheless, this was less severe than in the other major economies in western Europe, which fell by between 8.3% (in France) and an estimated 11.4% (Spain and the UK). Germany's better outturn reflects less stringent lockdowns, massive govern-ment support and a large manufacturing sector-equivalent to 20% of gross value added, and closely tied to the strongly recovering Chinese market-which was able to continue operating with social distancing measures.
We expect real German GDP to return to 98.2% of its 2019 full-year size in 2021, a more rapid recovery than the west European average, with annual growth of 3.7% in 2021 and 4% in 2022 (the latter reflecting strong carry-over effects). Consumers will maintain high precautionary savings this year, but much of the forced savings resulting from lockdowns and deferred investment will be drawn down to satisfy pent-up demand in the second quarter, once restrictions are lifted. Furthermore, the Kurzarbeit scheme has been extended to end-2021, which will support disposable incomes. Construction was a bright spot in 2020, expanding as housebuilding continued, and we expect this trend to be maintained; Germany's export-oriented manufacturing firms will also continue to benefit from growing demand in Asia. However, in-person services will take longer to recover, and the immediate outlook is not promising. Not only will the lockdown curtail consumer spending, but firms' stockpiling at end-2020 to mitigate Brexit-related disruption is now over. Finally, after a fall in 2020 owing to deferred reporting obligations, we expect a rise in bankruptcies this year.
We forecast 1.9% annual average growth in 2023-25. Germany's poor demographic outlook will increasingly constrain potential growth as the working-age population declines, exacerbated by a fall in net immigration during the pandemic. Technological disruption to the automotive sector also represents a structural risk: Germany has been slow to shift emphasis towards electric vehicles. Efforts to reduce supply-chain dependence on China may result in some reshoring of production, but as labour costs in Europe are higher, we do not expect this to result in a surge in job creation. Instead, automation and digitisation will gain pace, and supply-chain linkages with existing suppliers in central and eastern Europe will strengthen.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation Consumer prices rose by just 0.4% in 2020, reflecting low oil prices, the hit to demand from the coronavirus and the cut to the VAT rate in July-December. January 2021 presented a change in trend, with annual inflation rising to 1.6% as a consequence of the end of the VAT cut, new carbon emissions certificates raising transport and heating costs, and a rise in the minimum wage. Annual price growth will remain above the euro zone average in 2021 as a consequence of these changes in administered prices, as well as rising oil prices and a gradual release of pent-up consumer demand as vaccination programmes make progress. This could lead to rising political pressure from Germany regarding the extremely loose monetary policy stance of the ECB. We expect inflation to average 1.8% in 2021, before moderating to an average of 1.6% in 2022-25.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates The euro has experienced high volatility throughout 2020. A depreciation against the US dollar in the early months of the year, when the coronavirus forced European countries into lockdowns, was followed by a rapid appreciation after the EU announced the establishment of a new recovery fund worth EUR750bn. We forecast that the single currency will stabilise at an average of US$1.21:EUR1 in 2021, supported by the ongoing weakness in the US dollar. In 2022 muted inflation and growth prospects in the single-currency area will force the ECB to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy stance for longer than the Federal Reserve (the US central bank), prompting a slight depreciation of the euro against the dollar. The euro will strengthen from 2023 onwards, supported by the euro zone's structural current-account surplus and the gradual unwinding of the ECB's PEPP.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Germany's current-account surpluses were the largest in the world in nominal terms in the four years to 2019, and we expect them to be so again from 2021, after temporarily falling below China last year. They are underpinned by huge trade surpluses, reflecting the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector. This will continue to generate large domestic savings that are mainly invested abroad, leading to a solid primary income surplus.
We expect the recession in 2020 to have resulted in a decline in Germany's trade surplus, as the fall in exports outstripped the fall in imports. We estimate the full-year current-account surplus at the equivalent of 6.8% of GDP-down marginally from over 7% in the previous six years. Trade and primary income surpluses will comfortably outweigh narrow structural deficits on the services and secondary income accounts throughout our forecast period. We expect the current-account surplus to recover in nominal terms in 2021, but to remain unchanged as a share of GDP as the economy also expands. In 2022-25 we forecast that the external surplus will average 6.9% of GDP as world trade volumes and investment flows recover.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+February+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-02-05&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, to retain power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged both economically and politically. In particular, there is a significant risk of regime change stemming form a possible breakdown in the patronage system that sustains the security forces' support of the regime. Under our baseline forecast, we assume that Mr Maduro will avoid this, as oil revenue should pick up from a trough in 2020. However, there are substantial risks to this assumption, given the scale of operational difficulties and the lack of incentives for investment in the Venezuelan oil industry.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the govern-ment has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have aided price stability and thereby increased the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve Venezuela's economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela ranks 82nd out of 82 countries in the global business environ-ment rankings for 2021-25, showing no improvement relative to the 2016-20 historical period. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment remain unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2023-25: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2023-25: Investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2023-25: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2021-22: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2023-25: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2021-22: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2023-25: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2021-22: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2023-25: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2023-25: Investors remain highly cautious about committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2021-22: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2023-25: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his macroeconomic mismanagement, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. In December 2020 the PSUV and its allies regained control of the legislature in an election that was widely regarded as rigged.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$8.6bn in 2019 as a long-term decline in oil exports deepened. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the trade account deteriorated further in 2020, shifting to a deficit of US$995m.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV, the Chavistas), to remain in power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period, despite its failure to stem a long-running socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis. A number of factors underpin our forecast; particularly significant is the regime's strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. This control-together with a patronage system that rewards the loyalty of high-ranking officials-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Following a sham legislative election in December 2020, in which the Chavistas retook control of the National Assembly, the regime enjoys virtually unchecked control over all the levers of power. Meanwhile, the domestic opposition, led by Juan Guaidó (the former head of the legislature and self-declared interim president), has been left scrambling without a clear path forward, its decision to boycott the December election having left it without a voice in any major government institution. Before it lost control of the National Assembly, the opposition moved to unilaterally extend its mandate by one year. However, with many lawmakers abstaining from the vote out of fear of reprisals from the Maduro regime, and with key international players like the EU no longer recognising Mr Guaidó as the interim president (but rather as the main opposition leader), the opposition's attempt to extend its mandate lacks clear support and legitimacy.
In practice, the fallout from the election changes little in terms of policy-making; Mr Maduro has long used the executive's sweeping powers, as well as his influence over the highly politicised judiciary, to approve his policy agenda. However, retaking control of the National Assembly is significant insofar as it all but erases any threat that the Guaidó-led opposition might pose to Mr Maduro.
There is, nonetheless, a high degree of risk attached to our forecast that Maduro will remain in power. The uncontrolled spread of the corona-virus (Covid-19) disease, diminished oil rents-resulting from severe mismanagement of the sector, and more recently from US sanctions and low international oil prices-and persistent goods shortages all present hefty challenges to the survival of the regime. In our view, there are three main paths to a change of government: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia is low. Notwithstanding efforts by the US to increase multilateral engagement, a negotiated transition would also be difficult, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable. Bearing this in mind, we believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and an extremely poor macroeconomic environment will limit the country's ability to draw in US dollar finance. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks and control over the security apparatus. The regime's liquidity problems-along with a deepening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis-could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch On December 6th 2020 Venezuela held a legislative election to select the 277 members of the unicameral National Assembly. No international observers oversaw the vote, and both the EU and the US stated that the election was neither free nor fair. According to the National Electoral Council, the results were over-whelmingly in favour of Gran Polo Patriótico (GPP), an electoral alliance dominated by the PSUV. With 69% of the vote, the GPP took control of 256 seats in the 277-member legislature. The results were unsurprising, given that most of the main opposition parties boycotted the election and did not field candidates, but this was far from a ringing endorsement of the regime. According to the electoral authorities, only 31% of registered voters came out to vote, although the opposition claims that turnout was even lower than that. Some opposition parties did contest the election; the Alianza Democrática coalition (composed of five opposition parties) fared best, with 18% of the vote, but only managed to get 20 seats in the legislature.
Next on the electoral calendar is a regional election (to elect governors and state legislative assemblies), due by end-2021. The regional polls will provide the opposition with an opportunity to regroup and change its political strategy. In our view, electoral participation-even under unfair conditions-would be a useful step for the opposition to begin rebuilding political capital. However, even assuming that the opposition makes some inroads in regional govern-ments, it will not significantly alter the balance of power in the near term, but will instead only edge Venezuela towards a slightly more competitive model of authoritarianism.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The Maduro regime's main foreign policy challenge will centre on managing its combative ties with the US. The administration led by the former US president, Donald Trump (2017-21), instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions as part of a "maximum pressure" campaign designed to undermine the regime's finances (and therefore its patronage system) in order to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. Although the aggressive sanctions policy did not produce its intended outcome, it did accelerate the decline of Venezuela's oil industry. Mr Maduro will look to reset ties with the US under the current president, Joe Biden, but we expect little progress on this front. US policy towards Venezuela has bipartisan support in that country, and Mr Biden is unlikely to provide significant sanctions relief absent major political compromises and commitments to democratic reforms from the Maduro regime (which remain highly improbable). Any changes to sanctions policy by the US would therefore be only on humanitarian grounds, aimed at improving the lived realities of the poorest Venezuelans. For instance, we expect the Biden administration to reverse course on the recently instated sanctions on crude-for-diesel swaps, which are largely used by the Maduro regime to shore up diesel supplies for power generation, agricultural activity, water pumps and public transport.
Iran has recently become Mr Maduro's main international backer. In 2020 Iran sent more than 2.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela (in exchange for gold shipments) to alleviate the country's severe fuel shortages. An additional 400,000 barrels have already been sent in the year to date. Iran is also helping PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, to repair the Paraguaná oil refinery.
Venezuela's other major allies, including Russia and China, seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted both countries but has had little success in securing finance for investment.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The Maduro regime's immediate policy priorities will be to contain the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak and to halt a long-running economic collapse. In order to address the community spread of Covid-19, in January the regime reintroduced the "Fórmula 7+7 Plus" strategy, which involves alternating between a week of tighter restrictions (when non-essential shops and services are closed) and a week of more relaxed restrictions (when those businesses may open). However, we do not expect that this approach will prevent Venezuela's decrepit medical infrastructure from being overwhelmed. The regime has also signed an agreement with Russia to procure enough of its Sputnik V vaccine to inoculate 10m people (about a third of the population) in a first-phase rollout scheduled to begin in the first half of 2021. However, fuel shortages, bureaucratic inefficiencies and weak medical capacities will delay the rollout. As such, we do not expect that enough doses of the vaccine will be distributed to have a significant impact on local transmission until 2023.
Addressing the long-running economic decline will be a similarly difficult task. Mr Maduro will continue a process of gradual economic liberalisation in order to draw in private investment. In October 2020 the regime promulgated an anti-blockade law, which gives the executive branch the unchecked authority to sign confidential new deals with private firms and countries (in a bid to skirt international sanctions). In November 2020 the regime used the law to sell Agropatria, a state-owned agricultural firm, to Grupo Agrollano, a private company of unknown origin. We expect that the regime will similarly seek to reprivatise a number of other businesses that had been expropriated by Mr Maduro's predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but were run aground by cronyism and mismanagement. The regime will also encourage greater private-sector participation in the oil industry, but it will refrain from outright privatisation of PDVSA. These efforts, however, are unlikely to yield significant results; even assuming that the regime is able to get around financial sanctions, it will struggle to attract new investment, given the abysmal business environ-ment and the lack of confidence in the rule of law.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. However, we expect that a high level of inefficient current expenditure, combined with an extremely weak revenue intake, will keep the budget deficit wide and the public debt/GDP ratio astronomical throughout the forecast period. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving extremely high inflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2021-25. The sovereign is in arrears on virtually all of its interest and principal repayments, and we do not expect any debt restructuring in 2021-25. Moreover, the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Monetary policy will remain subservient to fiscal policy, as the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) continues to print money to finance the government's gaping budget deficits. The BCV has, in recent years, taken steps to control growth of monetary aggregates. For instance, in early 2019 it lifted the cash reserve ratio (CRR) to 100%; although it has relaxed the CRR slightly since that peak, as at January it remained at an extremely high 85%. Moreover, far from taming inflation, these measures have only led to the complete destruction of private-sector credit (the latest data show that the stock of private-sector credit contracted by 30% year on year in October).
These factors have accelerated the use of US dollars in the economy. According to private-sector estimates, two-thirds of all financial transactions are now made in US dollars. This is likely to rise further, following Mr Maduro's January announcement that banks would be authorised to expand the use of foreign-currency bank accounts. The Maduro regime has even allowed private companies to issue debt in hard currency in order to raise finance; in November 2020, Ron Santa Teresa became the first company in more than two decades to issue dollar-denominated bonds (worth US$300,000) on the Caracas Stock Exchange. Although progress will be gradual, we believe that Venezuela is ultimately headed towards overall de facto dollarisation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 30.3% in 2020 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 77% since 2013), we forecast an additional 3.7% decline in GDP in 2021. On the supply side, GDP is now strongly correlated with oil production. Having plummeted to an average of 500,000 barrels/day in 2020-its lowest level in several decades-crude production should stabilise in 2021 as global energy demand starts to recover. However, there are several downside risks to this benign assumption. In particular, low crude prices will continue to threaten production. At present, Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. However, US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket traded at an estimated US$33/b in December 2020). As a result, there are currently no active drill rigs in Venezuela. Meanwhile, the non-oil economy will fare little better, especially as an uncontrolled pandemic limits prospects for services activities. On the demand side, both investment and consumption will languish as a result of rampant inflation, weak consumer and business sentiment and a lack of access to finance. Real exports will see some improvement at the margins but will remain hampered by weak domestic productive capacities.
In 2022 we expect economic growth to return on the back of a surge in oil prices. Despite serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs and finding qualified staff) and a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude, oil output will recover partially in the medium term as producers adapt to post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability-driven primarily by an expansion of dollarisation-will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. Nonetheless, we assume that Venezuela's GDP (in real terms) will be only about half of its 2018 level, even in 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A severely reduced domestic goods supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will impede the disinflationary process in 2021-25. The regime has shown little inclination to take on the fiscal and macroeconomic reforms that would address the root causes of inflation. It has, however, lent its support to an ongoing process of de facto dollarisation, which will help to ease price pressures over time.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Strong inflationary pressures will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2021. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility. Even though a number of currency regulations officially remain on the books, the regime has largely stopped enforcing them in its recent embrace of dollar-isation. Although a black market for US dollars continues to operate, the premium is modest compared with previous years. On February 2nd the black-market exchange rate stood at BsS1,800,137:US$1, only marginally above the official exchange rate of BsS1,787,970:US$1.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Balance-of-payments pressures will remain severe throughout the forecast period, contributing to goods shortages and economic inequities. According to the BCV, foreign reserves closed 2020 at US$6.4bn-their lowest level in three decades. The steep decline in reserves, which has been several years in the making, reflects poor policymaking and a lack of economic diversification in the country's external sector.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect reserves to rise modestly over the forecast period, reaching US$7.6bn by end-2025. We expect this result to be driven entirely by trends on the current account, as Venezuela's access to foreign capital will remain extremely limited. We expect the current-account balance to shift from an estimated deficit of 3.2% of GDP in 2020 to a surplus of 0.5% of GDP in 2021. Thereafter, it will remain in surplus, averaging 1.8% of GDP in 2022-25. Our forecast rests on the assumption that export earnings will pick up from a nadir in 2020 as international oil prices recover and the country steps up trade with new markets in Asia. We also expect that workers' remittances from abroad will play a crucial role in propping up the current-account balance, as Venezuelan emigrants are gradually absorbed into the labour markets in their host countries.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data Oil prices: dated Brent
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
US and OECD growth: OECD
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsS:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text: - The right-wing government of the president, Jair Bolsonaro, has built a loose alliance with centrist parties in order to bolster governability in Brazil's highly fragmented Congress, as well as to advance his economic reform and socially conservative agenda. Tensions with the judiciary will simmer as the authorities investigate the affairs of the president's sons.
- Economic policymaking will be guided by the need to return to fiscal sustainability after stimulus in 2020 on the back of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the fiscal deficit widened to an estimated 15.8% of GDP in 2020, lifting the public debt/GDP ratio to nearly 100% by 2021. Assuming recovery and consolidation thereafter, we then expect this ratio to stabilise.
- The economy is recovering since activity hit its lowest point in April (at the height of lockdown restrictions). GDP is estimated to have fallen by 4.4% in 2020, and will recover partially in 2021, growing by 3.2%. GDP growth will average 2% annually in 2022-25. Despite policy accommodation, Brazil's productive capacity will be damaged by the crisis, impairing medium-term potential growth.
- Inflation will ease from 4.5% in 2020 as a surge in food prices eases, and the rate will fluctuate around the declining mid-point target (3.75% in 2021, 3.5% in 2022 and 3.25% in 2023) over the medium term.
- The Real will continue to strengthen from R5.3:US$1 currently to about R4.6:US$1 by 2025, with the start to interest-rate normalisation before mid-2021 lifting interest-rate differentials. Assuming a recovery in imports, the current-account deficit will widen to 3.6% by 2025.
- Following recession in 2020, a projected recovery will expand Brazil's large domestic market above US$2trn by 2025. Notwithstanding some simplifications, the tax system will remain burdensome and will be one of the weakest areas of the business environment. Infrastructure investment through a concessions prog-ramme will help to ease logistical bottlenecks, but upgrades and extensions will materialise only slowly.
