- Fiscal consolidation needs after hefty stimulus during the coronavirus pandemic and the 2022 electoral cycle will complicate government efforts to improve the business environment and enact structural reforms. Brazil's large economy is attractive, but poor government effectiveness, a burdensome tax system, archaic infrastructure, deficiencies in factor markets and skills shortages will impair business.

Country forecast overview: Brazil's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic delays privatisations of several state-owned subsidiaries, but parent companies require legislative approval, blocking divestments. Partial privatisation of Eletrobras, the state-owned energy firm, is possible.
2023-25: Privatisations continue. Fiscal pressures encourage private capital in infrastructure projects. Investment Partner-ships Programme (PPI) advances further, with improved legal framework and regulatory agencies.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Pandemic hits foreign direct investment (FDI). Changes to "pre-salt" oil auction rules and PPI attracts FDI.
2023-25: Brazil's OECD accession boosts foreign investment. Ideological issues within current government put nationalist politics ahead of economic pragmatism in certain situations.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: EU-Mercosul deal not expected to be ratified by EU parliaments.
2023-25: Steps taken to make Real a fully convertible currency.
Taxes 2021-22: Post-coronavirus consolidation needs may lead to higher taxes.
2023-25: Tax simplification unifies three federal, state and municipal taxes into one value-added tax (VAT).
Financing 2021-22: Financial system weathers pandemic; Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) provides emergency credit. BCB gains independence, improving efficiency and competitiveness, reducing borrowing costs. Credit resumes after crisis.
2023-25: Renewed growth in domestic equity and bond issuance as state banks dial back subsidised credit lines.
The labour market 2021-22: Unemployment surges owing to pandemic. Government implements further measures to reduce cost of labour.
2023-25: Steps to boost long-term labour productivity complicated by continued weak education policies.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Infrastructure concessions advance (through PPI), but coronavirus, and political and institutional constraints may cause delays. Corruption and recession weigh on established construction companies, opening industry up for newcomers.
2023-25: Industry newcomers' lack of experience causes project delays.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Fifth-generation (5G) frequencies to be auctioned in 2021. Quality of communications rises as demand expands.
2023-25: Building of 5G infrastructure network commences and is rolled out to consumers.

Background: A new constitution was ratified in 1988 after more than 20 years of military rule. The government of Fernando Henrique Cardoso (1995-2002) ended hyperinflation and advanced reforms to liberalise the economy. Under a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), Brazil reaped the benefits of the reforms and enjoyed a consumer-led, commodities-fuelled boom. When this cycle ended, discontent owing to a weak economy, corruption and poor public services led to street protests. Lula's successor as president, Dilma Rousseff (2011-16), nonetheless won a second four-year term in 2014, but was impeached in 2016 over budget irregularities. Her vice-president, Michel Temer (2016-18), finished her term. Jair Bolsonaro won the October 2018 election and took office as president in January 2019.
Political structure: The president executes policy approved by the 513-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and the 81-seat Senate (the upper house). Constitutional review is conducted by an independent judiciary. Although the president can resort to temporary decrees to push through legislation, the constitution gives Congress ample scope to check the executive. In the lower house, 30 political parties are represented and party discipline has traditionally been weak.
Policy issues: The benefits and entitlements established under the 1988 constitution have contributed to a doubling in central government primary spending, to over 27% of GDP. Congress passed a federal spending cap in 2016 and a robust pension reform in October 2019. The Banco Central do Brasil (the central bank) cut the Selic policy rate to 2% in August, a record low. The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic is leading to expansionary fiscal, monetary and credit policies to offset the hit to the economy and financial system, lifting public debt/GDP above 95%.
Taxation: Brazil has a poorly structured revenue system, characterised by a heavy tax burden, a narrow tax base, complicated levies and widespread evasion. Both foreign and domestic companies employ tax professionals and devote considerable resources to managing their tax affairs. The corporate and indirect tax systems are particularly complex, porous and unwieldy; the income tax system is considered to be relatively efficient, with a top rate of 27.5%.
Foreign trade: The coronavirus-induced recession and a weaker currency are narrowing the current-account deficit, which is an estimated 0.8% of GDP in 2020. Agricultural exports support a moderate structural trade surplus.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The political environment in 2021 will be shaped by the deployment of coronavirus (Covid-19) vaccines and the efforts of the right-wing, populist president, Jair Bolsonaro, to consolidate his alliances with the centrão, a group of centrist parties that hold the key to control of Congress. Their support-in exchange for political favours, including govern-ment posts and budget allocations-will help the president to advance his socially conservative agenda and ward off potential impeachment risks, but will reduce impetus for market reforms espoused by his free-market economy minister, Paulo Guedes. Impeachment risks have subsided after emerging in 2020 as a result of the president's confrontational rhetoric against Congress and the Supreme Court, but could re-emerge given his poor handling of the pandemic and as politicians seek to undermine his probable October 2022 re-election bid. Nonetheless, the president will continue to face challenges from more progressive centre-right parties that aim to secure the leadership of the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) under Baleia Rossi, the president of the Movimento Democrático Brasileiro (MDB) party, in the February leadership election.
Mr Bolsonaro's popularity got a boost in 2020 from emergency cash payments, but the effect has already started to wear off in January, after the relief programme ended. According to XP/Ipespe, a local pollster, Mr Bolsonaro's rejection ratings rose to 40% in January, from 35% in December 2020, while his approval fell to 32% from 38%, returning to pre-pandemic levels. Looking ahead, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Bolsonaro to try to retain the support of his core conservative voters and of his new-found lower-income voters (particularly in the populous north-east) to boost his re-election chances, but he will struggle to do so in the short term. Retaining the support of low-income voters will largely depend on additional economic stimulus, which, even if passed, would see its scope reduced given limited fiscal space. To rally his right-wing supporters, Mr Bolsonaro will seek to push forward his conservative "customs" agenda items, although his ability to do so will largely hinge on the election of Arthur Lira of the Progressistas party as speaker, who will be more favourable to this agenda than Mr Rossi, who depends on support from the left in Congress.
Mr Bolsonaro's proximity to the military (he is a retired army captain) has fuelled tension, especially with the judiciary. Although we expect calm relations for the time being, tensions could resurface given the president's impetuous nature and investigations into both him (relating to alleged political interference in the federal police in 2020) and his sons, Carlos (a local councillor, involved in "fake news" campaigns against political opponents) and Flávio (a senator, implicated in a local assembly graft scheme). Not only has the president put retired military officers in important cabinet positions-including Hamilton Mourão as vice-president-and stacked lower-ranking officials in the state bureaucracy, but in early 2020 he also actively supported bolsonaristas who attacked opponents in Congress (as well as in the judiciary and media) and called for military intervention. However, a rupture of constitutional rule is unlikely, as voters would protest; polls suggest that 75% of Brazilians support democracy as the best form of government. In addition, most high-ranking military officials are reluctant to be closely associated with Mr Bolsonaro.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The November local elections boosted traditional centrist parties, suggesting that, regardless of their opinions of Mr Bolsonaro, voters are unlikely to elect a left-leaning president in October 2022. The field for the presidential race will again be large, but it looks likely to be a close re-run of the 2018 vote, with Mr Bolsonaro probably backed by the centrão-competing against whomever a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), nominates as the Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT) candidate. This assumes that Lula, who was convicted of corruption, does not unexpectedly become eligible to stand. The PT performed poorly in the local elections and leftist parties are unlikely to unite behind a single candidate, which could reduce the chances of the PT candidate (or other emerging leftist rivals) contesting a probable second-round run-off. The surprise factor could come from a centre-right candidate such as João Doria, the governor of São Paulo state, but this third way could suffer a similar fate as the left if it fails to unite. Notwithstanding the advantages of incumbency, a strong centre-right could present a tougher contest for Mr Bolsonaro in a run-off, as the president would not be able to capitalise on anti-PT sentiment as he did in 2018. It is too early to make a call; Mr Bolsonaro's standing could be affected by unexpected developments in Brazil's tumultuous political environment.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The president's anti-globalist rhetoric and facilitation of illegal deforestation in the Amazon rainforest is tarnishing Brazil's international standing. However, as one of the world's ten largest economies and a major commodity exporter, Brazil will remain a significant global player. Under the presidency of Joe Biden in the US, bilateral relations will be cooler while Mr Bolsonaro is president given their divergent stances, particularly regarding climate change and deforest-ation. The relationship has made a bumpy start, as Mr Bolsonaro was the last major world leader to congratulate Mr Biden, but we assume that a pragmatic approach will prevail, with common ground on anti-Chinese sentiment.
Brazil will remain one of the battlegrounds in US-China rivalry; a fifth-generation (5G) licence auction scheduled for 2021 will prove tricky for the government given the local presence of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company. Anti-Chinese rhetoric by nationalist government figures is causing bilateral tensions, but military figures will encourage the president to be pragmatic regarding China's acquisition of assets, as Brazil needs investments in major infrastructure and energy projects. Moreover, Brazil's reliance on the Chinese coronavirus vaccine, Sinovac, will also temper the government's anti-Chinese rhetoric. We do not expect a free-trade agreement (FTA) between the EU and Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) to be ratified soon, owing to EU concerns over Mr Bolsonaro's environmental policies. Now that there is also pressure from Mr Biden on environmental issues, Brazil's efforts to join the OECD face delays.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Policymaking in 2021 will focus on the Covid-19 vaccine rollout and the government's structural reform agenda, which was overshadowed by the pandemic. However, some initiatives will be limited by a need to return to fiscal sustainability and the dialling-down of emergency stimulus. At the same time there is growing pressure from legislatures to extend emergency cash payments that ended in December. Overall, we expect the government to make only piecemeal progress on its agenda, as Mr Bolsonaro's commitment to reforms and to fiscal consolidation appears to be waning; he is prioritising his alliance with centrão parties (which resist Mr Guedes's more ambitious free-market reforms) and his 2022 re-election bid.
The government will focus primarily on passing revenue-neutral tax simplification reforms to unify three or more consumption taxes into a single value-added tax (VAT); Mr Guedes has almost given up on his efforts to levy a new, 0.2% digital payments tax to finance a reduction in payroll costs amid widespread congressional resistance. The government will attempt to make progress on other structural reforms-including streamlining the public sector, bringing greater order and flexibility to budget management, and privatisations. There is a small window of opportunity between the February Congressional leadership elections and mid-2021 to press on with any reforms before attention turns to the 2022 elections; we expect a broadly revenue-neutral tax simplification reform, possibly including changes to tax rates.
Overshadowing policymaking will be the need to consolidate the public finances, given the high and rising public debt/GDP ratio (88% in November 2020) and increasing fears in financial markets that the government could breach its constitutionally mandated public spending cap. Policymakers deployed huge fiscal stimulus in 2020 (about 8% of GDP directly, and even more including below-the-line items and government guarantees) to mitigate the impact of the pandemic, including monthly cash transfers of R600 (US$115) to more than 60m informal workers until September (dialled down to R300 until end-2020). Although Mr Bolsonaro signalled that extending the transfers into 2021 was on the table (as they had buoyed his popularity), the programme ended in 2020 as planned. Instead, the government will study expanding the existing Bolsa Família welfare programme, which is much smaller in scale, as it benefits about 20m people compared with the more than 65m people reached by emergency relief. Negotiations on the expansion will begin after the February congressional elections. In this context, risks that the spending cap will be breached have subsided for now, but (although this is not currently our baseline forecast) there is a chance that debt-sustainability concerns could return if the expansion plans are not aligned with the fiscal rules, especially as the 2022 elections near and social pressure will increase if there is a significant deterioration in the public health crisis.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy After surging to an estimated 95% in 2020 due to pandemic-related support measures, currency depreciation and recession, the public debt/GDP ratio will grow to 96% in 2021 as fiscal revenue only partly recovers. Stopping a more substantial rise will require consolidation; otherwise, concerns about debt sustainability will re-emerge among investors, raising the country risk premium. The government will avoid raising taxes ahead of the 2022 election, but tax increases thereafter cannot be ruled out. The "state of calamity" approved by Congress amid the pandemic allowed the government to sidestep constitution-ally mandated fiscal rules in 2020 and increase spending, but an extension of this in 2021 (a growing possibility, albeit not currently our baseline forecast) would unnerve investors. The fiscal hit from the crisis is apparent in the widening of the 12-month rolling overall deficit, to 13.1% of GDP in November 2020. We expect measures to be mostly removed in 2021; the deficit will narrow to 7.3% of GDP as revenue increases. Consolidation of these trends will narrow the deficit to less than 6% of GDP on average in 2022-25. We anticipate that public debt will stabilise within the forecast period, helped by privatisation proceeds and currency revaluation, but there is a growing risk that debt will exceed 100% if the president yields to an election-related increase in spending.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy As the economy recovers during 2021-25, we expect policy normalisation, beginning by the second quarter, to take the Selic policy rate from 2% currently to 5.5% by 2023 (a real interest rate of 2-3%, which we consider to be neutral, up from over -2% currently). The mid-point inflation target will fall by 25 basis points each year in 2021-23, from 3.75% to 3.25% in 2023 (the 2024 target will be set in 2021 and could fall further). The most significant risk to the environment of low interest rates and inflation is an unexpected abandonment of the spending cap rules, which could trigger a market sell-out that may force the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) to tighten policy sooner, and by more than expected. We expect the BCB to gain formal independence in early 2021 as the legislative agenda gets back on track after the congressional leadership elections.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following an estimated 4.4% contraction in 2020, real GDP will recover partly in 2021, expanding by 3.2%, assuming that major corona-virus lockdowns are avoided. However, growth in 2021 will be mostly due to strong statistical effects from the 2020 rebound, and sequential growth will be quite weak owing to the withdrawal of most fiscal stimulus. Although low interest rates and inflation will be supportive factors (along with a recovering global economy), lasting damage to the productive sector and jobs, and to corporate and household balance sheets, means that we do not expect output to return to pre-coronavirus levels until 2022. The rebound in the third quarter of 2020 (7.7% quarter on quarter) slowed in the fourth quarter (to an estimated 2.4%) as income transfers were dialled down. We now expect growth to contract in the first quarter of 2021 as cash transfers end and amid a deteriorating public health crisis, and to be limited in the second quarter, with a gradual pick-up thereafter, boosted by mass availability of Covid-19 vaccines during the second half of the year. Our forecasts assume the approval of tax simplification reforms and progress on other microeconomic reform agenda items, but we recognise that governability risks could hamper advances.
On the demand side, the upturn in 2021-25 will be driven by stronger investment (buoyed by lower interest rates, privatisations and infrastructure concessions) and by private consumption, supported by lower interest rates and credit growth. The withdrawal of emergency cash transfers in 2021 will initially be offset by the use of household savings (which rose in 2020) until the jobs market strengthens later in the year. On the supply side, commodity exports will accelerate in 2021-25, in line with a recovery in global demand. Manu-facturing has already rebounded owing to stimulus for consumers and a weaker currency, which could continue to make goods more competitive against imports in 2021-25. Positive vaccine news should boost consumer and business confidence, but the recovery of services sectors will not fully materialise until successful deployment of a vaccine beyond vulnerable groups from mid-2021.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A stronger policy framework than in the past will help to anchor inflation expectations, and minimum-wage increases are unlikely to be much above infla-tion (if at all). There is a risk that inflation expectations will become unanchored if pandemic-induced fiscal expansion is unexpectedly not brought under control. We consider that the recent rise in inflation (4.5% at end-2020)-related to higher food and commodity prices, as well as a weaker currency and higher demand created by emergency cash transfers-will be transitory. Assuming a gradual economic recovery in 2021-25, and barring periodic weather-related food shortages, an unexpected surge in oil prices or fiscal slippage, inflation should fluctuate close to the (lower) mid-point targets for 2021 (3.75%), 2022 (3.5%) and 2023 (3.25%). The 2024 target will be set in mid-2021 and could fall to 3%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Swings in global conditions and jitters over fiscal risks will keep the Real volatile, but it should continue to regain some of its 2020 losses over the medium term. The Real made gains in late 2020 as coronavirus-induced risk aversion eased, and ended at R5.2:US$1-about 22% weaker than at end-2019, although it is facing renewed depreciation pressures at the start of 2021 amid deteriorating economic expectations and market jitters over fiscal risks. We expect the Real to strengthen to R4.6:US$1 by 2025, fluctuating in line with Brazil's terms of trade, interest-rate differentials and global risk sentiment. A deeper local capital market for long-term debt will discourage corporate external borrowing, reducing capital inflows. The main forecast risk is the possibility of a market sell-off if confidence in debt sustainability evaporates.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Risks to Brazil's external position will be assuaged by its modest current-account deficit and external debt ratios, comfortable reserves cushion and a Real no longer overvalued by high interest rates (as in the past). Public external debt is low, and most companies have some sort of currency hedge, despite moderate private external debt. The trade balance will post a large structural surplus during 2021-25, owing to stable commodity exports to China, but this will narrow gradually as imports rise following recession-related compression in 2020.
After narrowing in 2020, the current-account deficit will widen gradually during 2021-25 as imports recover in line with the economy, and will exceed 3.5% of GDP by 2025. After dropping to an estimated 3.6% of GDP in 2020, inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) will average 4% of GDP in 2021-25, reflecting sizeable market opportunities.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; unless otherwise stated, The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data
Global data Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Oil prices: Dated Brent import price
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
US consumer price inflation: OECD
US$ effective exchange rate: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IFS, various issues
Budget balance: refers to nominal public-sector borrowing requirement
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Demographic indicators: IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
Exchange rate: IFS, various issues; market rates expressed as Reals per US$1
GDP growth by demand component: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; 1995 prices
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: UNCTAD, World Investment Report; IFS
Inflation: Índice de Preços ao Consumidor Ampliado (IPCA, a national consumer price index based on surveys in ten cities, December 1993=100), calculated by the IBGE; IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Brazil to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average PPP for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Real GDP growth per head: growth in real GDP divided by population growth
Total external debt: sum of long-term and short-term debt, plus arrears; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS, various issues; local currency GDP, converted to US$ at the estimated annual average PPP for consumer products
US$ GDP: IFS, various issues; in current prices, converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rates

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+January+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-01-18&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, to retain power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged both economically and politically. In particular, there is a significant risk of regime change stemming form a possible breakdown in the system of patronage that sustains the security forces' support of the regime. Under our baseline forecast, we expect Mr Maduro to avoid such an outcome, as oil revenues pick up from a low in 2020. However, there are substantial risks to this assumption, given the scale of operational difficulties and the lack of incentives for investment in the Venezuelan oil industry.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have to date aided price stability and therefore increased the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve Venezuela's economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela ranks 82nd out of 82 countries in the global business environ-ment rankings for 2021-25, showing no improvement relative to the 2016-20 historical period. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment remain unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2023-25: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2023-25: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2023-25: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2021-22: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2023-25: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2021-22: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2023-25: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2021-22: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2023-25: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2023-25: Investors remain highly cautious about committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2021-22: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2023-25: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his macroeconomic mismanagement, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. In December 2020 the PSUV and its allies regained control of the legislature in elections that were widely regarded as rigged.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the 2019 current-account surplus was 7.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV, the Chavistas), to remain in power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period, despite its failure to stem a long-running socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis. A number of factors underpin our forecast, key among which is the regime's strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. This control-together with a patronage system that rewards the loyalty of high-ranking officials-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Following sham legislative elections in December 2020, in which the Chavistas retook control of the National Assembly, the regime enjoys virtually unchecked control over all the levers of power. The domestic opposition, meanwhile, has been left scrambling without a clear path forward. Its decision to boycott the December polls has left it without a voice in any key government institutions. Before it lost control of the National Assembly, the opposition, led by Juan Guaidó (former head of the legislature and self-declared interim president) moved to unilaterally extend its mandate by one year. However, with many lawmakers abstaining from the vote out of fear of reprisals from the Maduro regime, and with key international players like the EU no longer recognising Mr Guaidó as the interim president, but rather as the main opposition leader, the opposition's move lacks clear support and legitimacy.
In practice, the fallout from the elections changes little in terms of policy-making; Mr Maduro has long used the executive's sweeping powers, as well as the creation of the Constituent Assembly (ANC, a quasi-legislative body), to approve his policy agenda. However, retaking control of the National Assembly is significant insofar as it all but erases any threat that the Guaidó-led opposition might pose to Mr Maduro.
There is, however, a high degree of risk attached to our forecast. The corona-virus (Covid-19) outbreak continuing uncontrolled, diminished oil rents-resulting from severe mismanagement of the sector, and more recently from US sanctions and low international oil prices-and persistent goods shortages all present hefty challenges to the survival of the regime. In our view, there are three main paths to a change of government: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia is low. Notwithstanding efforts by the US to increase multilateral engagement, a negotiated transition would also be difficult, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable. Bearing this in mind, we believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and an extremely poor macroeconomic environment will limit the country's ability to draw in US dollar finance. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks and control over the security apparatus. The regime's liquidity problems-along with a deepening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis-could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch On December 6th 2020 Venezuela held legislative elections to select the 277 members of the unicameral National Assembly. No international observers oversaw the poll, and both the EU and the US stated that the election was neither free nor fair. According to the National Electoral Council, the results were over-whelmingly in favour of Gran Polo Patriótico (GPP), an electoral alliance dominated by the PSUV. With 69% of the vote, the GPP took control of 256 seats in the 277-member legislature. The results were unsurprising, given that most of the main opposition parties boycotted the election and did not field candidates, but this was far from a ringing endorsement of the regime. According to the electoral authorities, only 31% of registered voters came out to vote, although the opposition claims that turnout was even lower than this. Some opposition parties did contest the election; the Alianza Democrática coalition (comprised of five opposition parties) fared best, with 18% of the vote, but only managed to get 20 seats in the legislature.
The next polls will be state and local elections, which are due by end-2021. These elections will provide the opposition with an opportunity to regroup and change its political strategy. In our view, electoral participation, even under unfair conditions, would be a useful step for the opposition to begin rebuilding political capital. However, even assuming that the opposition makes some inroads in regional governments, it will not significantly alter the balance of power in the near term, but will instead only edge Venezuela towards a slightly more competitive model of authoritarianism.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The Maduro regime's main foreign policy challenge will centre on managing its combative ties with the US. The administration led by the outgoing US president, Donald Trump, instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions as part of a "maximum pressure" campaign designed to undermine the regime's finances (and therefore its patronage system) in order to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. Although the aggressive sanctions policy did not produce its intended outcome, it did accelerate the decline of Venezuela's oil industry. Mr Maduro will look to reset ties with the US under the administration of the incoming president, Joe Biden, but we expect little progress on this front. US policy towards Venezuela has bipartisan support in that country and Mr Biden is unlikely to provide significant sanctions relief absent major political compromises and commitments to democratic reforms from the Maduro regime (which remain highly improbable). Any changes to sanctions policy by the US would therefore be only on humanitarian grounds, aimed at improving the lived realities of the poorest Venezuelans. For instance, we expect the Biden administration to reverse course on the recently instated sanctions on "crude-for-diesel" swaps, which are largely used by the Maduro regime to shore up diesel supplies for power generation, agricultural activity, water pumps and public transport.
Iran has recently become Mr Maduro's main international backer. In 2020 Iran sent more than 2.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela (in exchange for gold shipments) to alleviate the country's severe fuel shortages; more tankers are set to arrive in the coming weeks. Iran is also helping PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, to repair the Paraguaná oil refinery.
Venezuela's other key allies, including Russia and China, seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted both countries, but has had little success in securing finance for investment. Although Russia and China will remain key destinations for Venezuelan crude oil, exports to those countries will largely constitute repayments on previous debt already owed to the two nations.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The Maduro regime's immediate policy priorities will be to contain the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak and to halt a long-running economic collapse. In order to address the former, in January the regime reintroduced the "Fórmula 7+7 Plus" strategy, which involves alternating between a week of tighter restrictions (when non-essential shops and services are closed) and a week of more relaxed restrictions (when those businesses may open), so as to contain community spread of the infection. However, we do not expect that this approach will prevent Venezuela's decrepit medical infrastructure from being overwhelmed. The regime has also signed an agreement with Russia to procure enough of its Sputnik V vaccine to inoculate 10m people (about a third of the population) in a first-phase rollout scheduled to begin in the first half of 2021. However, fuel shortages, bureaucratic inefficiencies and weak medical capacities will delay the rollout. As such, we do not expect that enough doses of the vaccine will be provided to have a significant impact on local transmission until 2022 at the earliest.
Addressing the long-running economic decline will similarly be an uphill task. Mr Maduro will continue a process of gradual economic liberalisation in order to draw in private investment. In October 2020 the regime promulgated the so-called anti-blockade law, which gives the executive branch the unchecked authority to sign confidential new deals with private firms and countries (in a bid to skirt international sanctions). In November 2020 the regime used the law to sell Agropatria, a state-owned agricultural firm, to Grupo Agrollano, a private company of unknown origin. We expect that the regime will similarly seek to reprivatise a number of other businesses that had been expropriated by Mr Maduro's predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but were run aground by cronyism and mismanagement. The regime will also encourage greater private-sector participation in the oil industry, but it will refrain from outright privatisation of PDVSA. These efforts, however, are unlikely to yield significant results; even assuming that the regime is able to get around financial sanctions, it will struggle to attract new investment, given the abysmal business environment and the lack of confidence in the rule of law.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. However, we expect that a high level of inefficient current expenditure combined with an extremely weak revenue intake will keep the budget deficit wide and the public debt/GDP ratio astronomical throughout the forecast period. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving extremely high inflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2021-25. The sovereign is in arrears on virtually all of its interest and principal repayments and we do not expect any debt restructuring in 2021-25. Moreover, the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Monetary policy will remain subservient to fiscal policy, as the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) continues to print money to finance the government's gaping budget deficits. The BCV has, in recent years, taken some steps to control growth of monetary aggregates. For instance, the ordinary reserve ratio and the marginal reserve ratio both stand at an astounding 93%. However, far from taming inflation, these measures have only led to the destruction of private-sector credit.
These factors have accelerated the use of US dollars in the economy. According to private-sector estimates, two-thirds of all financial transactions are now made in US dollars. This is likely to rise further, following Mr Maduro's January announcement that banks would be authorised to expand the use of foreign-currency bank accounts. The Maduro regime has even allowed private companies to issue debt in hard currency in order to raise finance; in November 2020, Ron Santa Teresa became the first company in more than two decades to issue dollar-denominated bonds (worth US$300,000) on the Caracas Stock Exchange. Although progress will be gradual, we believe that Venezuela is ultimately headed towards overall de facto dollarisation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 30.3% in 2020 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 77% since 2013), we forecast an additional 1.8% decline in GDP in 2021. On the supply side, GDP is now strongly correlated with oil production. After having plummeted to an average of 560,000 barrels/day in 2020-its lowest level in several decades-we expect crude production to stabilise in 2021 as global energy demand starts to recover. However, there are several downside risks to this benign assumption. In particular, low crude prices will continue to threaten production. At present, Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. However, US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket traded at an estimated US$27/b as at November 2020). As a result, there are currently no active drill rigs in Venezuela. Meanwhile, the non-oil economy will fare little better, especially as an uncontrolled pandemic limits prospects for services activities. On the demand side, both investment and consumption will languish as a result of rampant inflation, weak consumer and business sentiment and a lack of access to finance. Real exports will see some improvement at the margins, but will remain hampered by weak domestic productive capacities.
In 2022 we expect economic growth to return on the back of a surge in oil prices. Despite serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude, oil output will recover partly in the medium term, as producers adapt to post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability-driven primarily by an expansion of dollarisation-will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. Nonetheless, we assume that Venezuela's GDP (in real terms) will be only about half of its 2018 level, even in 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A severely reduced domestic goods supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will impede the disinflationary process in 2021-25. The regime has shown little inclination to take on the fiscal and macroeconomic reforms that would address the root causes of inflation. It has, however, lent its support to an ongoing process of de facto dollarisation, which will help to ease price pressures over time.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Strong price pressures will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2021. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility. Although a number of currency regulations officially remain on the books, the regime has largely stopped enforcing them, in its recent embrace of dollar-isation. Although a black market for US dollars continues to operate, the premium is modest. On January 18th the black-market exchange rate stood at BsS1,663,064:US$1, just 7% above the official exchange rate of BsS1,548,933:US$1.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Balance-of-payments pressures will remain severe throughout the forecast period, contributing to goods shortages and economic inequities. According to the BCV, foreign reserves stood at just US$6.3bn in November 2020-its lowest level in three decades. The steep decline in reserves, which has been several years in the making, reflects the impact of poor policymaking and a lack of economic diversification on the country's external sector.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect reserves to rise modestly over the forecast period, reaching US$8.6bn by end-2025. We expect that this result will be driven entirely by trends on the current account, since Venezuela's access to foreign capital will remain extremely limited. We expect the current-account deficit to narrow from an estimated 2.5% of GDP in 2020 to 0.5% of GDP in 2021. Thereafter, it will shift into a surplus, averaging 3% of GDP in 2022-25. Our forecast rests on the assumption that export earnings will pick up from a nadir in 2020, as international oil prices recover and the country steps up trade with new markets in Asia and the Middle East. We also expect that workers' remittances from abroad will play a crucial role in propping up the current-account balance, as Venezuelan emigrants (totalling over 6m since 2013) are gradually absorbed into the labour markets in their host countries.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Brazil&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Brazil+January+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-01-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Brazil&amp;rft.issn=09669361&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The right-wing government of the president, Jair Bolsonaro, has built a loose alliance with centrist parties in order to bolster governability in Brazil's highly fragmented Congress, as well as to advance his economic reform and socially conservative agenda. Tensions with the judiciary will simmer as the authorities investigate the affairs of the president's three sons.
- Economic policymaking will be guided by the need to return to fiscal sustainability after stimulus in 2020 on the back of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the fiscal deficit will widen to an estimated 16% of GDP in 2020, lifting the public debt/GDP ratio to nearly 100% by 2021. Assuming recovery and consolidation thereafter, we then expect this ratio to stabilise.
- The economy is recovering since activity hit its lowest point in April (at the height of lockdown restrictions). GDP will fall by an estimated 4.5% in 2020, before recovering partly in 2021, growing by 3.7%. GDP growth will average 2% annually in 2022-25. Despite policy accommodation, Brazil's productive capacity will be damaged by the crisis, impairing medium-term potential growth.
- Inflation will ease from 4.3% in November 2020 as a surge in food prices eases and the rate will fluctuate around the declining mid-point target (3.75% in 2021, 3.5% in 2022 and 3.25% in 2023) over the medium term.
- The Real will continue to strengthen from R5.1:US$1 currently to just below R4.8:US$1 by 2022, with a start to interest-rate normalisation around mid-2021 lifting interest-rate differentials. Import compression will offset weaker exports in 2020, but we estimate that lower profit remittances and a narrower net tourism deficit owing to travel restrictions will reduce the current-account deficit to less than 1% of GDP this year. Assuming a recovery, the deficit will widen to 3% by 2025.
- Following recession in 2020, a projected recovery will expand Brazil's large domestic market above US$2trn by 2025. Notwithstanding some simplifications, the tax system will remain burdensome and one of the weakest areas of the business environment. Infrastructure investment through a concessions prog-ramme will help to ease logistical bottlenecks, but upgrades and extensions will materialise only slowly.

- Fiscal consolidation needs after hefty stimulus during the coronavirus pandemic and the 2022 electoral cycle will complicate government efforts to improve the business environment and enact structural reforms. Brazil's large economy is attractive, but poor government effectiveness, a burdensome tax system, archaic infrastructure, deficiencies in factor markets and skills shortages will impair business.

Country forecast overview: Brazil's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic delays privatisations of several state-owned subsidiaries, but parent companies require legislative approval, blocking divestments. Partial privatisation of Eletrobras, the state-owned energy firm, is possible.
2023-25: Privatisations continue. Fiscal pressures encourage private capital in infrastructure projects. Investment Partner-ships Programme (PPI) advances further, with improved legal framework and regulatory agencies.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Pandemic hits foreign direct investment (FDI). Changes to "pre-salt" oil auction rules and PPI attracts FDI.
2023-25: Brazil's OECD accession boosts foreign investment. Ideological issues within current government put nationalist politics ahead of economic pragmatism in certain situations.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Despite anti-globalisation moves in advanced economies, some bilateral and regional trade negotiations progress. EU-Mercosul deal not expected to be ratified by EU parliaments.
2023-25: Steps taken to make Real a fully convertible currency.
Taxes 2021-22: Post-coronavirus consolidation needs may lead to higher taxes.
2023-25: Tax simplification unifies three federal, state and municipal taxes into one value-added tax (VAT).
Financing 2021-22: Financial system weathers pandemic; Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) provides emergency credit. BCB gains independence, improving efficiency and competitiveness, reducing borrowing costs. Credit resumes after crisis.
2023-25: Renewed growth in domestic equity and bond issuance as state banks dial back subsidised credit lines.
The labour market 2021-22: Unemployment surges owing to pandemic. Government implements further measures to reduce cost of labour.
2023-25: Steps to boost long-term labour productivity complicated by continued weak education policies.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Infrastructure concessions advance (through PPI), but coronavirus, and political and institutional constraints may cause delays. Corruption and recession weigh on established construction companies, opening industry up for newcomers.
2023-25: Industry newcomers' lack of experience causes project delays.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Fifth-generation (5G) frequencies to be auctioned in 2021. Quality of communications rises as demand expands.
2023-25: Building of 5G infrastructure network commences and is rolled out to consumers.

Background: A new constitution was ratified in 1988 after more than 20 years of military rule. The government of Fernando Henrique Cardoso (1995-2002) ended hyperinflation and advanced reforms to liberalise the economy. Under a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), Brazil reaped the benefits of the reforms and enjoyed a consumer-led, commodities-fuelled boom. When this cycle ended, discontent owing to a weak economy, corruption and poor public services led to street protests. Lula's successor as president, Dilma Rousseff (2011-16), nonetheless won a second four-year term in 2014, but was impeached in 2016 over budget irregularities. Her vice-president, Michel Temer (2016-18), finished her term. Jair Bolsonaro won the October 2018 election and took office as president in January 2019.
Political structure: The president executes policy approved by the 513-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and the 81-seat Senate (the upper house). Constitutional review is conducted by an independent judiciary. Although the president can resort to temporary decrees to push through legislation, the constitution gives Congress ample scope to check the executive. In the lower house, 30 political parties are represented and party discipline has traditionally been weak.
Policy issues: The benefits and entitlements established under the 1988 constitution have contributed to a doubling in central government primary spending, to over 27% of GDP. Congress passed a federal spending cap in 2016 and a robust pension reform in October 2019. The Banco Central do Brasil (the central bank) cut the Selic policy rate to 2% in August, a record low. The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic is leading to expansionary fiscal, monetary and credit policies to offset the hit to the economy and financial system, lifting public debt/GDP above 95%.
Taxation: Brazil has a poorly structured revenue system, characterised by a heavy tax burden, a narrow tax base, complicated levies and widespread evasion. Both foreign and domestic companies employ tax professionals and devote considerable resources to managing their tax affairs. The corporate and indirect tax systems are particularly complex, porous and unwieldy; the income tax system is considered to be relatively efficient, with a top rate of 27.5%.
Foreign trade: The coronavirus-induced recession and a weaker currency are narrowing the current-account deficit, which is an estimated 0.8% of GDP in 2020. Agricultural exports support a moderate, structural trade surplus.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The political environment in 2021 will be shaped by the deployment of coronavirus (Covid-19) vaccines and by the efforts of the right-wing, populist president, Jair Bolsonaro, to maintain his new-found popularity among poorer Brazilians (stemming from emergency assistance payments) and consolidate his alliances with the centrão, a group of centrist parties that performed well in the November 2020 municipal elections and that hold the key to control of Congress. Their support-in exchange for political favours, including govern-ment posts and budget allocations-will help the president to advance his socially conservative agenda and ward off potential impeachment risks. These have subsided recently, after emerging in early 2020 owing to the president's confrontational rhetoric against Congress and the Supreme Court, but could re-emerge in the run-up to the October 2022 election. Although his new alliances will bolster his position, the president's loose governing coalition will face challenges from more progressive centre-right parties, who will want to secure the leadership of the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) in the February leadership election in order to control the agenda, and because they will potentially back their own presidential candidate. Meanwhile, Mr Bolsonaro's alliance with the centrão reduces the impetus for market reforms espoused by his free-market economy minister, Paulo Guedes, and could weaken fiscal discipline.
Despite having the world's second-highest Covid-19 death toll (184,000 and rising as at mid-December 2020), the president's ploy of downplaying the pandemic has not resulted in a loss of personal popularity, mostly owing to the income transfers that have attracted support from a new-found low-income base, compensating for lost support from anti-corruption-driven voters that now consider it largely empty. According to a local pollster, Datafolha, the president's approval is still significantly higher than it was at the beginning of the year, and stood at 37% in December 2020 (up from 32% in December 2019). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Bolsonaro to try to retain the support of his core conservative voters and of lower-income voters (particularly in the populous north-east), to boost his re-election chances. However, his popularity is likely to take a hit when cash transfers end from January 2021.
Mr Bolsonaro's proximity to the military (he is a retired captain) has fuelled tension, especially with the judiciary. Although we expect calm relations for the time being, tensions could resurface, given the president's impetuous nature and investigations swirling around him (relating to alleged political interference in the federal police earlier this year) and around his sons, Carlos (a local councillor, involved in "fake news" campaigns against political opponents) and Flávio (a senator, implicated in a local assembly graft scheme). Not only has the president put retired military officers in important cabinet positions-including Hamilton Mourão as vice-president-and stacked lower-ranking officials in the state bureaucracy, but in early 2020 he also actively supported bolsonaristas who attacked opponents in Congress (as well as in the judiciary and media), and called for military intervention. However, a rupture of constitutional rule is unlikely, as voters would protest; polls suggest that 75% of Brazilians support democracy as the best form of government. Meanwhile, most high-ranking military officials are reluctant to associate too closely with Mr Bolsonaro.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The November local elections boosted traditional centrist parties, suggesting that, regardless of their opinions of Mr Bolsonaro, voters are unlikely to elect a left-leaning president in October 2022. The field for the presidential race will again be large, but it looks likely to be a close re-run of the 2018 vote, with Mr Bolsonaro probably backed by the centrão-competing against whomever a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), nominates as the Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT) candidate. This assumes that Lula, who was convicted of corruption, does not unexpectedly become eligible to stand. The PT performed poorly in the local elections and leftist parties are unlikely to unite behind a single candidate, which could reduce the chances of the PT candidate (or other emerging leftist rivals) contesting a probable second-round run-off. The surprise factor could come from a centre-right candidate, such as João Doria, the governor of São Paulo state, but this third-way could suffer a similar fate as the left if it fails to unite. Notwithstanding the advantages of incumbency, a strong centre-right could present a tougher contest for Mr Bolsonaro in a run-off, as the president would not be able to capitalise on anti-PT sentiment as he did in 2018. It is too early to make a call; Mr Bolsonaro's standing could be affected by unexpected developments in Brazil's tumultuous political environment. If the president cannot boost social spending to the poor before the election, his popularity and chances of re-election could weaken.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The president's anti-globalist rhetoric and facilitation of illegal deforestation in the Amazon rainforest is tarnishing Brazil's international standing. However, as one of the world's ten largest economies and a major commodity exporter, Brazil will remain a significant global player. Under the presidency of Joe Biden in the US, bilateral relations will be cooler while Mr Bolsonaro is president given their divergent stances, particularly regarding climate change and deforest-ation. The relationship has made a bumpy start, as Mr Bolsonaro was the last major world leader to congratulate Mr Biden, but we assume that a pragmatic approach will prevail, with common ground on anti-China sentiment.
Brazil will remain as one of the battlegrounds in US-China rivalry; a fifth-generation (5G) licence auction scheduled for 2021 will prove tricky for the government given the local presence of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company. Anti-Chinese rhetoric by nationalist government figures is causing bilateral tensions, but military figures will encourage the president to be pragmatic regarding China's acquisition of assets, as Brazil needs investments in major infrastructure and energy projects. We do not expect a free-trade agreement (FTA) between the EU and Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) to be ratified soon, owing to EU concerns over Mr Bolsonaro's environmental policies. Now that there is also pressure from Mr Biden on environmental issues, Brazil's efforts to join the OECD face delays.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Policymaking in 2021 will focus on the Covid-19 vaccine rollout and the government's structural reform agenda, which was overshadowed by the pandemic. However, some initiatives will be limited by a need to return to fiscal sustainability and the dialling down of emergency stimulus. Overall, we expect the government to make only piecemeal progress on its agenda, as Mr Bolsonaro's commitment to reforms and to fiscal consolidation appears to be waning; he is prioritising his alliance with centrão parties (which resist Mr Guedes's more ambitious, free-market reforms) and his 2022 re-election bid.
The government will focus primarily on passing revenue-neutral tax simp-lification reforms to unify three or more consumption taxes into a single value-added tax (VAT); Mr Guedes has almost given up his efforts to levy a new 0.2% digital payments tax to finance a reduction in payroll costs amid widespread congressional resistance. The government will attempt to make progress on other structural reforms proposed by Mr Guedes-including streamlining the public sector, bringing greater order and flexibility to budget management and privatisations. The government presented a watered-down version of its administrative reform (which includes the elimination of job security for most future public servants) to Congress in September in the latest signal that the economy minister's agenda will be diluted. Although the electoral complication of the municipal polls has now been overcome, there is a very small window of opportunity (until mid-2021) to press on with any reforms before attention turns to the 2022 elections. However, we expect a broadly revenue-neutral tax simplification reform, possibly including changes to tax rates.
Overshadowing policymaking will be the need to consolidate the public finances, given the high and rising public debt/GDP ratio (91% in October 2020) and increasing fears in financial markets that the government will breach its constitutionally mandated public spending cap. Policymakers have deployed huge fiscal stimulus in 2020 (about 8% of GDP directly, and even more including below-the-line items and government guarantees) to mitigate the impact of the pandemic, including monthly cash transfers of R600 (US$115) to more than 60m informal workers until September (dialled down to R300 until end-2020). Although Mr Bolsonaro signalled that extending the transfers into 2021 was on the table (as they had buoyed his popularity), he has officially announced that the programme will end in 2020 as planned. Instead, the government will study expanding the existing Bolsa Família welfare pro-gramme, which is much smaller in scale as it benefits around 20m people, compared with the more than 65m people reached by emergency relief. Negotiations on the expansion will begin after the February congressional elections. In this context, risks that the spending cap will be breached have subsided for now, but (although this is not currently our baseline forecast) there is a chance that debt-sustainability concerns could return if the expansion plans are not aligned with the fiscal rules, especially as the 2022 elections near.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy After surging to an estimated 95% in 2020 owing to pandemic-related support measures, currency depreciation and recession, the public debt/GDP ratio will grow to 96% in 2021 as fiscal revenue only partly recovers. Stopping a more substantial rise will require consolidation; otherwise, concerns about debt sustainability will re-emerge among investors, raising the country risk premium. The government will avoid raising taxes ahead of the 2022 election, but tax increases thereafter cannot be ruled out. The "state of calamity" approved by Congress amid the pandemic allowed the government to sidestep constit-utionally mandated fiscal rules in 2020 and increase spending, but an extension of this in 2021 (a growing possibility, albeit not currently our baseline forecast) would unnerve investors. The fiscal hit from the crisis is apparent in the widening of the 12-month rolling overall deficit, to 13.95% of GDP in October 2020. We expect measures to be mostly removed in 2021; the deficit will narrow to 7.2% of GDP as revenue increases. Consolidation of these trends will narrow the deficit to less than 5% of GDP on average in 2022-25. We anticipate that public debt will stabilise within the forecast period, helped by privatisation proceeds and currency revaluation, but there is a growing risk that debt will exceed 100% if the president yields to an election-related increase in spending.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Policy accommodation during the 2020 crisis will give way to a normalisation process beginning in mid-2021. The Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) cut the Selic policy rate to 2% (a record low) in August 2020. With rates considered close to the lower bound for Brazil, further easing is unlikely. We expect the BCB to gain formal independence in early 2021 as the legislative agenda gets back on track after the congressional leadership elections. As the economy recovers during 2021-25, we expect policy normalisation, beginning after mid-2021, to take the Selic to 5.5% by 2023 (a real interest rate of 2-3%, which we consider to be neutral, up from over -2% currently). The mid-point inflation target will fall by 25 basis points each year in 2020-23, from 4% to 3.25% (the 2024 target will be set in 2021 and could fall further). The most significant risk to the environment of low interest rates and inflation is an unexpected abandonment of the 2016 spending cap rules, as it could trigger a market sell-out that may force the BCB to tighten policy sooner and by more than expected.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following an estimated 4.5% contraction in 2020, real GDP will recover partly in 2021, expanding by 3.7%, assuming that major corona-virus lockdowns are avoided. However, growth in 2021 will be mostly due to strong statistical effects from the 2020 rebound, and sequential growth will be quite weak owing to the withdrawal of most fiscal stimulus. Although low interest rates and inflation will be supportive factors (along with a recovering global economy), lasting damage to the productive sector and jobs, and to corporate and household balance sheets, means that we do not expect output to return to pre-corona-virus levels until 2022. Leading indicators show that the rebound in the third quarter of 2020 (7.7% quarter on quarter) is slowing in the fourth quarter (to an estimated 2.4%) as income transfers are dialled down. Our forecasts assume the approval of tax simplification reforms and progress on other microeconomic reform agenda items, but we recognise that governability risks could hamper advances.
On the demand side, the upturn in 2021-25 will be driven by stronger investment (buoyed by lower interest rates, privatisations and infrastructure concessions) and by private consumption, supported by lower interest rates and credit growth. The withdrawal of emergency cash transfers in 2021 will initially be offset by the use of household savings (which rose in 2020) until the jobs market strengthens later in the year. On the supply side, commodity exports will accelerate in 2021-25, in line with a recovery in global demand. Manu-facturing has already rebounded owing to stimulus for consumers and a weaker currency, which could continue to make goods more competitive against imports in 2021-25. Positive vaccine news should provide a boost to consumer and business confidence, but the recovery of services sectors will not fully materialise until successful deployment of a vaccine beyond vulnerable groups from mid-2021 removes the need for social distancing measures.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A stronger policy framework than in the past will help to anchor inflation expectations, and minimum-wage increases are unlikely to be much above inflation (if at all). There is a risk that inflation expectations will become unanchored if pandemic-induced fiscal expansion is unexpectedly not brought under control. We consider that the recent uptick in inflation (4.3% in November 2020)-related to higher food and commodity prices, as well as a weaker currency and higher demand created by emergency cash transfers-will be transitory. Assuming a gradual economic recovery in 2021-25, and barring periodic weather-related food shortages, an unexpected surge in oil prices or fiscal slippage, inflation should fluctuate close to the (lower) mid-point targets for 2021 (3.75%), 2022 (3.5%) and 2023 (3.25%). The 2024 target will be set in mid-2021 and could fall to 3%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Swings in global conditions and jitters over fiscal risks will keep the Real volatile, but it should continue to regain some of its losses over the medium term; the Real has already made gains in late 2020 as coronavirus-induced risk aversion has eased, and it will end at R5.1:US$1-about 22% weaker than at end-2019. We expect the Real to strengthen towards R4.6:US$1 by 2025, fluctuating in line with Brazil's terms of trade, interest-rate differentials and global risk sentiment. A deeper local capital market for long-term debt will discourage corporate external borrowing, reducing capital inflows. The main forecast risk owes to the possibility of a market sell-off if confidence in debt sustainability evaporates.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Risks to Brazil's external position will be assuaged by its modest current-account deficit and external debt ratios, comfortable reserves cushion and a Real no longer overvalued by high interest rates (as in the past). Public external debt is low and most companies have some sort of currency hedge, despite moderate private external debt. The trade balance will post a large structural surplus during 2021-25, owing to stable commodity exports to China, but this will narrow gradually as imports rise following recession-related compression in 2020.
After narrowing in 2020, the current-account deficit will widen gradually during 2021-25 as imports recover in line with the economy, and will exceed 3.5% of GDP by 2025. After dropping to an estimated 3.6% of GDP in 2020, inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) will average 4% of GDP in 2021-25, reflecting sizeable market opportunities.

Full text: - The tenure of the president, Muhammadu Buhari, will last until 2023 and be blemished by a decline in living standards caused by recession in 2020, a rise in unemployment and (paradoxically) high, policy-induced inflation.
- The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions, leading to chronic insecurity in some regions and the risk of protests in normally stable cities. Pro-market reforms are needed to vitalise the economy, but the political backdrop will obstruct their full implementation.
- A decline in living standards under Mr Buhari, whose tenure has been marked by two recessions, as well as frustrations over pervasive insecurity and poor governance means that the opposition People's Democratic Party is forecast to win the 2023 election.
- Low world oil prices will continue to exert pressure on the multiple-exchange-rate regime and, in 2021, force another devaluation of the official rate. Foreign-exchange supply is then expected to improve, allowing the market to stabilise in 2022-25 and become more liquid. The Central Bank of Nigeria is not expected to relinquish heavy-handed control of the currency.
- Low oil prices in 2021 will coincide with large recurrent government spending commitments and result in another substantial fiscal deficit, by Nigerian standards. The budget shortfall will then broadly edge down as external conditions improve, the domestic economy picks up and revenue rises. Debt-servicing will become more manageable than in 2020, when there was a conflict between staying current on obligations and providing a response to the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic.
- Given a crippling infrastructure deficit, untethered inflation, instability in crucial agricultural regions and high unemployment, we expect growth of just 1.2% in 2021. Only when the exchange rate and inflation stabilise will there be a more meaningful recovery.
- Inflation will stay high in 2021 as devaluation of the naira, price deregulation, instability in agricultural growing areas, monetary loosening and exchange-rate restrictions for staple imports feed into consumer prices. Monetary tightening is expected to start from 2022 to tackle the issue.
- We expect a current-account deficit for a third consecutive year in 2021 (something that has not been seen since the 1990s) despite a modest increase in oil prices. The current account will return to surplus in 2022-25 as the oil market recovers and petrol import volumes decline.
