- Fiscal consolidation needs after hefty stimulus during the coronavirus pandemic and the 2022 electoral cycle will complicate government efforts to improve the business environment and enact structural reforms. Brazil's large economy is attractive, but poor government effectiveness, a burdensome tax system, archaic infrastructure, deficiencies in factor markets and skills shortages will impair business.

Country forecast overview: Brazil's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Vested interests slow down economy ministry's ambitious privatisations programme, although some divestments do materialise.
2023-25: Privatisations continue slowly. Fiscal pressures encourage private capital in infrastructure projects. Investment Partnerships Programme (PPI) advances further, with improved legal framework and regulatory agencies.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic hits foreign direct investment (FDI).
2023-25: Ideological issues within current government put nationalist politics ahead of economic pragmatism in certain situations.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Despite anti-globalisation moves in advanced economies, some bilateral and regional trade negotiations progress. Deal between EU and Mercosul (Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) not expected to be ratified by EU parliaments.
2023-25: Steps taken to make Brazilian Real a fully convertible currency.
Taxes 2021-22: Post-coronavirus consolidation needs may lead to higher taxes.
2023-25: Tax simplification unifies three federal, state and municipal taxes into one value-added tax (VAT).
Financing 2021-22: Financial system weathers pandemic; Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) provides emergency credit. BCB gains independence, improving efficiency and competitiveness, reducing borrowing costs. Credit resumes after crisis.
2023-25: Renewed growth in domestic equity and bond issuance as state banks dial back subsidised credit lines.
The labour market 2021-22: Unemployment surges owing to pandemic. Government implements further measures to reduce cost of labour.
2023-25: Steps to boost long-term labour productivity complicated by continued weak education policies.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Infrastructure concessions advance (through PPI), but coronavirus, and political and institutional constraints may cause delays. Corruption and recession weigh on established construction companies, opening industry up for newcomers.
2023-25: Industry newcomers' lack of experience causes project delays.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Fifth-generation (5G) frequencies to be auctioned in 2021. Quality of communications rises as demand expands.
2023-25: Building of 5G infrastructure network commences and is rolled out to consumers.

Background: A new constitution was ratified in 1988 after more than 20 years of military rule. The government of Fernando Henrique Cardoso (1995-2002) ended hyperinflation and advanced reforms to liberalise the economy. Under a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), Brazil reaped the benefits of the reforms and enjoyed a consumer-led, commodities-fuelled boom. When this cycle ended, discontent owing to a weak economy, corruption and poor public services led to street protests. Lula's successor as president, Dilma Rousseff (2011-16), nonetheless won a second four-year term in 2014, but was impeached in 2016 over budget irregularities. Her vice-president, Michel Temer (2016-18), finished her term. Jair Bolsonaro won the October 2018 election and took office as president in January 2019.
Political structure: The president executes policy approved by the 513-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and the 81-seat Senate (the upper house). Constitutional review is conducted by an independent judiciary. Although the president can resort to temporary decrees to push through legislation, the constitution gives Congress ample scope to check the executive. In the lower house, 30 political parties are represented and party discipline has traditionally been weak.
Policy issues: The benefits and entitlements established under the 1988 constitution have contributed to a doubling in central government primary spending, to over 27% of GDP. Congress passed a federal spending cap in 2016 and a robust pension reform in October 2019. The Banco Central do Brasil (the central bank) cut the Selic policy rate to 2% in August, a record low. The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic is leading to expansionary fiscal, monetary and credit policies to offset the hit to the economy and financial system; The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the public debt/GDP ratio will exceed 95% in 2020.
Taxation: Brazil has a poorly structured revenue system, characterised by a heavy tax burden, a narrow tax base, complicated levies and widespread evasion. Both foreign and domestic companies employ tax professionals and devote considerable resources to managing their tax affairs. The corporate and indirect tax systems are particularly complex, porous and unwieldy; the income tax system is considered to be relatively efficient, with a top rate of 27.5%.
Foreign trade: The pandemic-induced recession and a weaker Real are narrowing the current-account deficit, which we estimate at 0.8% of GDP in 2020. Agricultural exports support a moderate structural trade surplus.

Argentina 4.2 Argentina 6.1
Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The political environment in 2021 will be shaped by the deployment of vaccines to overcome the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and by the efforts of the right-wing, populist president, Jair Bolsonaro, to maintain his new-found popularity among poorer Brazilians (stemming from emergency Covid-19 assistance payments) and consolidate his alliances with the centrão, a group of centrist parties that performed well in the November local elections and that hold the key to control of Congress. Their support-in exchange for political favours, including government posts for their members and budget allocations-will help the president to advance his socially conservative agenda and ward off potential impeachment risks. These risks have subsided recently, after emerging in early 2020 owing to the president's confrontational rhetoric against Congress and the Supreme Court, but could re-emerge as Mr Bolsonaro's political rivals seek to undermine his October 2022 re-election bid. Although his new alliances will bolster his position, the president's loose governing coalition in the legislature will face challenges from more progressive centre-right parties. These parties will want to secure the leadership of the lower house when an election for that position is held in February 2021 in order to control the legislative agenda and exert their influence, and because they will potentially back their own presidential candidate. Meanwhile, Mr Bolsonaro's alliance with the centrão reduces the impetus for market reforms espoused by his free-market economy minister, Paulo Guedes, and could weaken fiscal discipline.
Despite having the world's second-highest Covid-19 death toll (173,000 and rising as at end-November), the president's ploy of outsourcing the handling of the pandemic to other levels of government has not resulted in a loss of personal popularity, as state governors and local officials implementing social distancing measures have absorbed most of the associated political costs and income losses. According to a local pollster, XP Ipespe, the president's approval rating rose to 39% in October, from about 32% before the coronavirus outbreak. This was mostly due to government income transfers that have attracted support from a new-found low-income base; this has compensated for lost support from voters who were attracted by the president's anti-corruption election rhetoric but now consider it largely empty. In this context, Mr Bolsonaro appears to believe that if he retains the support of his core conservative voters and of lower-income voters through cash transfer programmes (particularly in the populous Northeast), he has a good chance of securing re-election in 2022. However, fiscal pressures will limit social spending.
Mr Bolsonaro's proximity to the military (he is a retired captain) has caused tension, especially with the judiciary. Although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects calm relations for the time being, tensions could flare again, given the president's impetuous nature and investigations swirling around him (relating to alleged political interference in the federal police earlier this year) and around his sons, Carlos (a local councillor, involved in "fake news" campaigns against political opponents) and Flávio (a senator, implicated in a local assembly graft scheme). Not only has the president put retired military officers in important cabinet positions-including Hamilton Mourão as vice-president-and stacked lower-ranking officials in the state bureaucracy, but in early 2020 he also actively supported bolsonaristas who attacked opponents in Congress (as well as in the judiciary and media), and called for military intervention. However, a rupture of constitutional rule is unlikely, as voters would protest; polls suggest that 75% of Brazilians support democracy as the best form of government. Meanwhile, most high-ranking military officials are reluctant to associate too closely with Mr Bolsonaro's political interests.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The November local elections delivered gains for traditional centrist parties, suggesting that, whatever their opinions of Mr Bolsonaro, voters are unlikely to elect a left-leaning president in October 2022. The field for the presidential race will again be large, but it looks likely to be a re-run of the 2018 vote, with Mr Bolsonaro-probably backed by the centrão-competing against whomever a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), nominates as the candidate of the Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT). This assumes that Lula himself, who was convicted of corruption, does not unexpectedly become eligible to stand. However, the PT performed poorly in the local elections. The PT and other leftist parties are unlikely to unite behind a single candidate, which could reduce the chances of the PT candidate (or other emerging leftist rivals) contesting a probable second-round run-off. This could benefit centrist figures such as João Doria, the governor of São Paulo state. That scenario could lead to a tougher contest for Mr Bolsonaro, although he will have the huge advantages of incumbency. It is too early to make a call; Mr Bolsonaro's standing could be affected by unexpected, negative developments in Brazil's tumultuous political environment. If the president cannot extend well-received cash transfers, his popularity is likely to weaken, diminishing both his ability to broker agreements on structural reforms in Congress in 2021 and his re-election prospects.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The president's anti-globalist rhetoric and facilitation of illegal deforestation in the Amazon rainforest is tarnishing Brazil's international standing. However, as one of the world's ten largest economies and a major commodity exporter, Brazil will remain a significant global player. Under the presidency of Joe Biden in the US, bilateral relations will be cooler while Mr Bolsonaro is president of Brazil given their divergent stances, particularly regarding climate change and deforestation. We assume that a pragmatic approach will prevail, with common ground on anti-China sentiment.
Brazil will continue to be one of the battlegrounds in US-China rivalry; a fifth-generation (5G) licence auction scheduled for 2021 is likely to prove tricky for the Brazilian government given the local presence of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company. Anti-Chinese rhetoric by nationalist government figures is causing bilateral tensions, but military figures will encourage the president to be pragmatic regarding China's acquisition of assets, as Brazil needs investments in major infrastructure and energy projects. We do not expect a free-trade agreement (FTA) between the EU and Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) to be ratified soon, owing to EU concerns over Mr Bolsonaro's environmental policies. Now that there is also pressure from Mr Biden on environmental issues, Brazil's efforts to join the OECD could be delayed.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Policymaking in 2020 has focused on containing the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic, which is showing signs of picking up again after easing from the June-July peaks; this suggests the risk of a second wave, potentially bringing renewed social distancing restrictions. Pandemic-related emergency economic measures will remain in place to some extent next year, but we expect attention to broadly return to the government's structural reform agenda in the next year, after being overshadowed by the pandemic response. Overall, we expect the government to make only piecemeal progress, as Mr Bolsonaro's own commitment to these reforms and to fiscal consolidation appears to be waning; he is prioritising his alliance with centrão parties (which resist Mr Guedes's more ambitious, free-market reforms) and his 2022 re-election bid.
The government will focus primarily on passing revenue-neutral tax simp-lification reforms to unify three or more consumption taxes into a single value-added tax (VAT); Mr Guedes has almost entirely given up his efforts to levy a new 0.2% digital payments tax to finance a reduction in payroll costs amid widespread congressional resistance. The government will attempt to make progress on other structural reforms proposed by Mr Guedes-including streamlining the public sector, bringing greater order and flexibility to budget management and carrying out privatisations. The government presented a watered-down version of its administrative reform (which includes the elimination of job security for most future public servants) to Congress in September in the latest signal that the economy minister's agenda will be diluted. Although the electoral complication of the municipal polls has now been overcome, there is a very small window of opportunity (until mid-2021) to press on with any reforms before attention turns to the 2022 presidential race. However, we expect a broadly revenue-neutral tax simplification reform, possibly including changes to tax rates.
Overshadowing any government initiative will be the need to consolidate the public finances, given the high and rising public debt/GDP ratio (91% in September) and increasing fears in financial markets that the government will breach its constitutionally mandated public spending cap. Policymakers have deployed huge fiscal stimulus in 2020 (about 8% of GDP directly, and even more including below-the-line items and government guarantees) to mitigate the impact of the pandemic, including monthly cash transfers of R600 (US$115) to more than 60m informal workers until September (now dialled down to R300 for the rest of 2020). As the transfers have buoyed Mr Bolsonaro's popularity among the poor, he has sensed an opportunity to boost his chances of re-election in 2022 by continuing the programme in 2021. With limited room in the budget to do so, there is an increasing risk that Brazil's fiscal rules will be broken. Although this is not currently our baseline forecast, such a development would risk triggering much greater debt-sustainability concerns, along with higher inflation and interest rates than we currently forecast.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy After surging to an estimated 96% in 2020 owing to pandemic-related support measures, currency depreciation and recession, the public debt/GDP ratio will grow to 98% in 2021 as fiscal revenue only partly recovers. Stopping a more substantial rise will require consolidation measures; otherwise, concerns about debt sustainability will re-emerge among investors, raising the country risk premium. The government will want to avoid raising taxes ahead of the 2022 election, but tax increases before the end of our 2021-25 forecast period cannot be ruled out. The "state of calamity" approved by Congress amid the pandemic allows the government to sidestep constitutionally mandated fiscal rules in 2020 and increase spending, but an extension of this in 2021 (a growing possibility, albeit not currently our baseline forecast) would unnerve investors. The fiscal hit from the crisis is apparent in the widening of the 12-month rolling overall deficit, to 13.7% of GDP in September. We expect measures to be mostly removed in 2021; the deficit will narrow to 7.5% of GDP as revenue increases. Consolidation of these trends will narrow the deficit to less than 5% of GDP on average in 2022-25. We anticipate that public debt will stabilise within the forecast period, helped by privatisation proceeds and currency revaluation, but there is a growing risk that debt will exceed 100% if the president yields to an election-related increase in spending.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Policy accommodation during the 2020 crisis will give way to a normalisation process beginning later in 2021 as the economy begins to recover. The Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) cut the Selic policy rate to 2% (a record low) in August. With rates considered close to the lower bound for Brazil, further easing is unlikely. We expect the BCB to gain formal independence soon (the upper house approved the bill on November 3rd and it now passes to the lower house). As the economy recovers over 2021-25, we expect policy normalisation, beginning after mid-2021, to take the Selic close to 5% by 2021 (a real interest rate of 2%, which we consider to be neutral, up from nearly -2% currently). The mid-point inflation target will fall by 25 basis points each year in 2020-23, from 4% to 3.25% (the 2024 target will be set in 2021 and could fall further). The most significant risk to the environment of low interest rates and inflation is an unexpected abandonment of the 2016 spending cap rules.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following an estimated 5% contraction in 2020, real GDP will recover partially in 2021, when we expect an expansion of 3.7%, assuming that major corona-virus lockdowns are avoided until a vaccine is deployed. However, growth in 2021 will be mostly due to strong statistical effects from the 2020 rebound and sequential growth will actually be quite weak, owing to the withdrawal of most pandemic-related fiscal stimulus. Although low interest rates and inflation will be supportive factors (along with a recovering global economy), lasting damage to the productive sector and jobs, and to corporate and household balance sheets means that we do not expect output to return to pre-coronavirus levels until 2023. Leading indicators show that the rebound in the third quarter of 2020 (estimated at 7.5% quarter on quarter) is slowing in the fourth (to 3%) as income transfers are dialled down.
Our forecasts assume the approval of tax simplification reforms and progress on other microeconomic reform agenda items, but we recognise that governability risks could hamper advances. The upturn in 2021-25 will be driven by stronger investment (buoyed by lower interest rates, privatisations and infrastructure concessions) and by private consumption, supported by lower interest rates and credit growth. The withdrawal of emergency cash transfers in 2021 will initially be offset by the use of household savings (which actually rose in 2020) until the jobs market strengthens later in the year. Commodity exports will accelerate in 2021-25, in line with a recovery in global demand. Manufacturing has already rebounded from the coronavirus hit owing to stimulus for consumers and a weaker currency-a factor that will continue to make goods more competitive against imports over the forecast period. The recovery of services sectors will not fully materialise until successful deployment of a vaccine in 2021 removes the need for social distancing measures.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A stronger policy framework than in the past will help to anchor inflation expectations, and minimum-wage increases are unlikely to be much above inflation (if at all). Fiscal expansion amid the pandemic will need to be brought under control or inflation expectations will become unanchored. We consider that the recent uptick in inflation (3.9% in October)-related to higher food and commodity prices, as well as a weaker currency and higher demand created by emergency cash transfers-will be transitory. Assuming a gradual economic recovery in 2021-25, and barring periodic weather-related food shortages, an unexpected surge in oil prices or fiscal slippage, inflation should fluctuate close to the (lower) mid-point targets for 2021 (3.75%), 2022 (3.5%) and 2023 (3.25%). The 2024 target will be set in mid-2021 and could fall to 3%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Swings in global conditions and jitters over fiscal risks will keep the Real volatile, but it should regain some of its recent losses over the medium term. After ending 2020 at R5.3:US$1-about 25% weaker than at end-2019-we expect the Real to trade mostly around R4.9-5.2:US$1 in 2021-25, fluctuating in line with Brazil's terms of trade, interest-rate differentials and global risk sentiment. A deeper local capital market for long-term debt will discourage corporate external borrowing, reducing capital inflows. The main risk to our forecast stems from the possibility of a market sell-off if confidence in debt sustainability evaporates.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Risks to Brazil's external position will be assuaged by its modest current-account deficit and external debt ratios, a comfortable reserves cushion and a Real no longer overvalued by high interest rates (as in the past). Public external debt is low and most companies have some sort of currency hedge, despite moderate private external debt. The trade balance will post a large structural surplus during 2021-25, owing to stable commodity exports to China, but this will narrow gradually as imports rise following recession-related compression in 2020.
After narrowing in 2020, the current-account deficit will widen gradually during the forecast period as imports recover in line with the economy, and will exceed 3.6% of GDP by 2025. After dropping to an estimated 3.8% of GDP in 2020, inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) will average 4.2% of GDP in 2021-25, reflecting sizeable market opportunities.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; unless otherwise stated, The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data
Global data Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Oil prices: Dated Brent import price
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
US consumer price inflation: OECD
US$ effective exchange rate: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IFS, various issues
Budget balance: refers to nominal public-sector borrowing requirement
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Demographic indicators: IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
Exchange rate: IFS, various issues; market rates expressed as Reals per US$1
GDP growth by demand component: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; 1995 prices
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: UNCTAD, World Investment Report; IFS
Inflation: Índice de Preços ao Consumidor Ampliado (IPCA, a national consumer price index based on surveys in ten cities, December 1993=100), calculated by the IBGE; IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Brazil to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average PPP for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Real GDP growth per head: growth in real GDP divided by population growth
Total external debt: sum of long-term and short-term debt, plus arrears; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS, various issues; local currency GDP, converted to US$ at the estimated annual average PPP for consumer products
US$ GDP: IFS, various issues; in current prices, converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rates
Abbreviations FGV: Fundação Getúlio Vargas
IBGE: Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística
IFS: IMF, International Financial Statistics
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+November+2020+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2020-11-14&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela to retain power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged both economically and politically. Low international crude prices, combined with US sanctions on the regime, mean that Venezuela is struggling to place its oil exports abroad. We therefore forecast that domestic crude production will average less than 400,000 barrels/day in the coming months. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control. That said, his position will strengthen in 2021, as the opposition is set to lose control of the legislature in January following rigged legislative elections on December 6th 2020.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have to date aided price stability and therefore increase the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve Venezuela's economic crisis within the forecast period.

Country forecast overview: Business environment rankings                
Value of index a     Global rank b     Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25   2016-20 2021-25   2016-20 2021-25
3.29 2.94   80 82   12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.

- Venezuela is ranked 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environ-ment rankings for 2021-25, having been in 80th place in the 2016-20 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2023-25: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2023-25: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2023-25: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2021-22: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2023-25: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2021-22: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2023-25: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2021-22: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2023-25: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2023-25: Investors remain highly cautious about committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2021-22: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2023-25: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly (AN). In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the AN.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country) has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2019 current-account surplus at 2.4% of GDP.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), to retain power throughout 2021 despite social and economic shocks. However, the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, diminished oil rents-resulting from US sanctions and low international oil prices-and goods shortages all represent hefty challenges to the survival of the military regime. In addition, social unrest is prevalent and protests could intensify in the coming months owing to severe fuel shortages. Nonetheless, Mr Maduro has a number of factors working in his favour. The regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces; this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Another reason to believe that Mr Maduro will retain power is the state of the opposition, led by the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó. It has lost the momentum that it had in 2019 and lacks consensus on its approach to the forthcoming legislative elections in December. Mr Guaidó's political capital is currently low-a recent poll by Datanálisis (a local pollster) gave him an approval rating of just 17%-and the legislative elections will impair his claim to power. Most opposition forces will boycott the December elections and are likely to seek to extend the current legislative term. However, there is no constitutional basis for an extension, and the PSUV's victory in the forthcoming rigged elections will complicate the opposition's strategy and Mr Guaidó's claim to power, leaving Mr Maduro in a stronger position than a year prior.
Mr Maduro's recent actions illustrate his strong hand relative to the opposition. A new electoral council, inaugurated in June, was packed with Mr Maduro's allies. Even more audaciously, the Supreme Court ejected the leadership of several prominent opposition parties (including Acción Democrática and Voluntad Popular-Mr Guaidó's own party) and replaced them with a group of politicians who claim to be part of the opposition but who are in reality loyal to the regime. The brazenness of these actions shows that Mr Maduro is unperturbed by the prospect of retaliation by the opposition and that political pressure on him is wavering. In a sign that he feels in control of the political environment, he released and/or pardoned more than 100 opposition figures in late August, after talks mediated by Turkey between the regime and Henrique Capriles (a former presidential candidate) and Stalin González (a congressman).
Despite all of this, we recognise that there is a high risk to our forecasts, and that the deteriorating economic situation could prompt some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to a change of government: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia is low, and that a negotiated transition would also be difficult, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable. Bearing this in mind, we believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink US dollar inflows further. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems-along with a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis-could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch Legislative elections will take place on December 6th. These elections will be neither free nor fair, and the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly. Most opposition forces plan to boycott the polls, given the lack of electoral guarantees. However, some notable opposition figures-including Mr Capriles and Mr González-have publicly expressed their intention to take part (the opposition parties have boycotted polls in the past, but this only reduced their visibility, influence and legitimacy).
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US will utilise sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections; however, the latter is unlikely to succeed in the medium term. The forthcoming US administration of Joe Biden will remain hawkish in its approach to Venezuela, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely. We expect most US sanctions to remain in place owing to strong bipartisan support; however, some-such as the recently approved ban on diesel swaps-could be lifted. We also anticipate that diplomatic efforts to reach a negotiated exit for Mr Maduro will increase under a Biden administration.
Iran has recently become Mr Maduro's main international backer. Since April, Iran has sent more than 2.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela (in exchange for gold shipments) to alleviate the country's severe fuel shortages; more tankers are set to arrive in the coming weeks. Iran is also helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to repair the Paraguaná oil refinery.
Nevertheless, Russia and China (both strong Venezuelan allies) seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries but has had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The Maduro regime will focus on weathering ongoing fuel shortages that have crippled the economy and on containing the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Despite community spread and an accelerating number of Covid-19 cases, Mr Maduro has eased nationwide quarantine measures to some degree. Measures will remain in place over the short to medium term, as Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The country's medical infrastructure is poor, and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity.
Given its potential to ignite large-scale protests, Mr Maduro has taken some steps to alleviate fuel scarcity. In May the regime announced a two-tiered petrol distribution system. Drivers are subject to a monthly quota of subsidised petrol. When this has been reached, petrol will be available at internationally indexed prices. The quota system seeks to regularise black-market activity so that the regime (rather than a third party) benefits from the gains. Concurrently, the Maduro regime is seeking to switch on domestic petrol production. PDVSA is currently only able to produce an estimated 20,000 barrels/day (b/d) of petrol (at its peak it could refine 1.3m b/d) and efforts to boost production are often marred by infrastructure breakdowns. However, these actions will only work to an extent, as arbitrage opportunities are still possible under the new subsidy system and domestic petrol production meets only a slim proportion of local demand (about 25% of current demand).
Based on our view that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our 2021-25 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the regime's survival. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the current regime.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2021, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2021-25. However, in the medium term, growing remittance inflows will somewhat offset the need to monetise budget deficits. We currently assume no debt restructuring in 2021-25. Venezuela's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. Indeed, a US court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications, as some international firms are seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. Bondholders of the PDVSA 2020 are currently unable to seek to attach assets owing to an ongoing suspension by the US Treasury. Nevertheless, there is a strong possibility that the Venezuelan opposition, which currently holds Citgo, will lose control of it to bondholders in early 2021.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyperinflationary pressures in 2019-20. This trend will continue in 2021, but hyperinflationary pressures will remain significant owing to the monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages. Hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. It has quickened the pace of dollar-isation of the economy (more than 60% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 30.3% in 2020 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 77% since 2013), we forecast an additional 1.7% decline in GDP in 2021. GDP is now strongly correlated with oil output and export. Following plummeting oil exports in 2019-20, crude production will stabilise as global energy demand starts to recover. Concurrently, the non-oil economy will benefit from the lifting of social distancing measures in 2021 and from larger fuel supplies (even though domestic petrol production will not fully cover local demand). From a demand-side perspective, the GDP contraction will be driven by falling real incomes, hyperinflation and continued mass emigration (fuelled by unemployment, violence and social instability). Low crude prices and weak oil exports will continue to threaten crude production. Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket traded at an estimated US$25/b as at end-October). The current circumstances have inevitably led to production cuts; according to OPEC, oil output fell to 350,000 b/d in October 2020, from 700,000 b/d in October 2019 and 1.3m b/d a year earlier. We believe that average output will remain below 400,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2022 we expect economic growth to return on the back of a surge in oil prices. Despite serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude, oil output will recover partly in the medium term as producers adapt to post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. Nonetheless, we assume that Venezuela's GDP (in real terms) will be only about half of its 2018 level, even in 2025. There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout 2021-25.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A severely reduced domestic goods supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will continue to stoke hyperinflation in 2021. Social distancing measures, dollarisation and heavy credit restrictions imposed by the regime have helped to subdue inflation this year, keeping it at bay. Consumer prices rose by 23.8% month on month in October; however, inflationary pressures will strengthen in the short term, owing to fuel scarcity, price controls, the ramping-up of money printing by the government and the latest minimum wage increment. In early November the Maduro regime trebled the monthly minimum wage-to which wages of a sizeable share of the labour force are directly or indirectly linked-to BsS1.2m (US$1.90).
In the medium term, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook. However, dollarisation will tame hyperinflationary pressures, and inflationary pressures will ease gradually over the coming years.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Hyperinflation will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2021. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We still believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On November 13th the official exchange rate was BsS645,000:US$1 (against a black-market rate of BsS690,000:US$1). The current premium (7%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit of 1% of GDP in 2021, owing to weak oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from the global recession. Official BCV figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019-20 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the export collapse was mostly covered by growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019).
We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 4.4% of GDP in 2022-25. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. The recovery in the current account will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Full text: - The tenure of the president, Muhammadu Buhari, will last until 2023 and be blemished by a decline in living standards caused by recession in 2020, a rise in unemployment and (paradoxically) high, policy-induced inflation.
- The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This potent mixture has the potential to cause mass protests and will halt the advancement of pro-market reforms.
- A decline in living standards under Mr Buhari, whose tenure has been marked by two recessions, as well as frustrations over pervasive insecurity and poor governance means that the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP) is forecast to win the 2023 election.
- The Economist Intelligence Unit expects some reregulation of electricity pricing under a PDP government. Although this would be bad news for the power sector, we do not expect a return to distortive pricing in the petroleum sector.
- Low world oil prices will continue to exert pressure on the multiple-exchange-rate regime and, in 2021, force another devaluation of the official rate. Foreign-exchange supply is then expected to improve, allowing the market to stabilise in 2022-25.
- Low oil prices in 2021 will coincide with large recurrent government spending commitments and result in another substantial fiscal deficit, by Nigerian standards. The budget shortfall will then broadly edge down as external conditions improve, the domestic economy picks up and revenue rises.
- Given a crippling infrastructure deficit, high inflation, instability in crucial agricultural regions and high unemployment, we expect growth of just 1.1% in 2021. Only when the exchange rate and inflation stabilise will there be a more meaningful recovery.
- Inflation will stay high in 2021 as devaluation of the naira, price deregulation, instability in agricultural growing areas, monetary loosening and exchange-rate restrictions for staple imports feed into consumer prices. Monetary tightening is expected to start from 2022 to tackle the issue.
- We expect a current-account deficit for a third consecutive year in 2021 (something that has not been seen since the 1990s) despite a modest increase in oil prices. The current account will return to surplus in 2022-25 as the oil market recovers and petrol import volumes decline.

- Nigeria's business environment score worsens slightly for the forecast period (2021-25) as the macroeconomic and security environment remains highly challenging. As a result, its global and regional rankings fall.

Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: The overarching policy objective is to promote self-sufficiency and local industrialisation through protectionism. As a result, the non-oil sector is be largely shielded from external competition.
2023-25: A new government (which is likely to be opposition-led) is likely to remain wary of opening up the economy.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: A reduction is made to royalties for offshore oil activity introduced in 2020 in an attempt to prevent divestment from oil majors operating in Nigeria. Outside the oil sector, concerns over the foreign-exchange regime deter investment.
2023-25: Energy firms remain hesitant about increasing their presence in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore, but concerted efforts are made to clean up the national oil company (which is in joint venture with oil majors).
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Movement of goods is highly regulated to prevent smuggling, but people will be allowed to cross land borders once the coronavirus pandemic is brought under control.
2023-25: A spread between the official and the parallel-market exchange rates persists as oil prices rise and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) is again able to defend an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxes 2021-22: The focus on boosting tax compliance intensifies, but the weak state of the economy and upcoming elections prevent tax increases.
2023-25: Value-added tax (VAT) is raised from 7.5% to cut the budget deficit amid persistently high debt-servicing costs.
Financing 2021-22: The government returns to the sovereign debt market, and capital projects are restarted.
2023-25: Credit conditions become tighter as the CBN moves to control high inflation.
The labour market 2021-22: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2023-25: Employers continue to struggle to find qualified staff; unemployment stays high and the labour market loose.
Infrastructure 2021-22: A reduction in consumer subsidies (for petrol) frees up resources for higher public capital investment, but government spending remains small relative to the size of the economy, at under 7%.
2023-25: A large private refinery starts up, reducing Nigeria's near-total dependency on imported petrol.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Nigeria retains a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2023-25: Research spending remains low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multi-party democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. In 2015 Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari, who secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 7.5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Muhammadu Buhari, to stay in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. He will be under immense pressure to stabilise Nigeria, but myriad security threats will prove unmanageable. The military and police are overstretched and unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will be triaged, with military resources deployed to whichever is considered the most pressing.
This shaky system will keep the government in power but leave the country highly dysfunctional and, in many regions, extremely insecure. Protests against police brutality in October morphed into an expression of wider political and economic malaise, which proved capable of galvanising mass action. Mr Buhari was able to appease the central demand of the campaign by disbanding a particular police unit and promising security reform. Conciliation would be harder to repeat should a fresh, co-ordinated movement harness the other grievances that the protests tapped into, including unemployment, poor governance and a general decline in living standards. High inflation, partly resulting from petrol and electricity price deregulation, stands to be a particular driver of renewed unrest in 2021, with a strong risk of organised mass protests in normally stable cities such as the commercial capital, Lagos, and the administrative capital, Abuja. Government buildings but also private enterprise could be targeted by a violent minority, as was the case in recent unrest. Should protests grow in size, they would probably push Mr Buhari's administration to make policy compromises. The president's commitment to pro-market reforms is already judged to have wilted following recent protests, and a planned electricity tariff increase has been already softened.
Besides dealing with economic crisis, the government will remain embroiled in a conflict with Boko Haram and Islamic State West Africa Province (ISWAP), Islamist terrorist groups that are causing havoc in north-eastern Nigeria. As the region is a stronghold of the ruling party, the All Progressives Congress (APC), the president will be committed to asserting control, irrespective of how difficult this will be. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east-particularly Borno state-will remain a low-level conflict zone, and the campaign there will divert security forces away from other insecure parts of Nigeria.
One hotspot that is likely to remain insecure and neglected is the agricultural Middle Belt, where violent conflict between farmers and herdsmen over increasingly scarce land and water resources has killed thousands in recent years. Formal land-titling is a potential solution to the crisis; however, as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. As with the north-east, the direct effects of the conflict will be localised, but the entire country will feel the fallout in the form of reduced local food production and high prices.
The military and police will be too poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping, particularly in the north-west. Widespread poverty and unemployment are feeding a cycle of crime that will be difficult (if not impossible) to break, given a bleak economic outlook for 2021 at least.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next national elections are due in 2023. In the most recent presidential election, in 2019, the candidates of both main parties were from the north, and custom dictates that the candidates in 2023 will be from the south. This should lead to an improvement on the abysmally low turnout in 2019 in the south, which is a stronghold of the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP). Frustration with high prices, declining living standards and perpetual instability will be directed at the APC, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations Nigeria will remain a major player in Sub-Saharan Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Exasperation over smuggling, which policymakers view as undermining local industry, led the government to close all of Nigeria's land borders to goods traffic in late 2019. Given rising local prices in Nigeria for agricultural goods (and so declining international competitiveness), there will be no rush to reopen the borders to regional trade in 2021, and potentially for longer. Protectionism (underpinned by foreign-exchange restrictions) also makes Nigeria's adoption of a common West African currency, the eco, highly unlikely.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends As part of its response to the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, the government has sought about US$6.9bn (about 2% of GDP) from multilateral lenders to finance a US$1.4bn healthcare fund, a public works programme and support for businesses. Not all the loans are low-conditionality, encouraging Mr Buhari to enact the boldest economic reforms since his coming to office. A cap on pump prices has been removed, allowing petrol prices to rise to record levels (for Nigeria) in September. Ending petrol price caps is essential for freeing up fiscal space, and new refineries that are either being built or at the planning stage (including a 650,000-barrel/day facility currently under construction) will require pricing to be suitable for supply to the domestic market. Electricity tariffs are also being raised for usage exceeding 12 hours a day. Attaining cost-reflective electricity tariffs is crucial for alleviating the burden of bad debts that have been run up along the power supply chain, which have hindered investment and resulted in regular outages.
However, political pressures mean the government may well fail to keep prices liberal on a permanent basis. Negotiations with the World Bank, which has demanded such reforms as a precondition for a possible US$3bn financial package, have dragged on well beyond official expectations. As the brunt of the coronavirus crisis has probably passed for Nigeria we no longer expect a finance package with the World Bank to be achieved. The government will prefer policy independence and instead issue debt internationally in 2021 (market perception of credit risk has been in decline, as judged by default swap spreads). Recent protests in southern Nigeria are partially a product of price reforms, fitting into a wider exasperation over declining living standards, and political pressure has already prompted a scaling down of electricity price increases. Reinstatement of price controls for petrol is made less likely by a new Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB), which has a good chance of passing through parliament. The legislation would scrap the current price regulator in the process of creating a new, profit-oriented national oil company. The PIB will encourage upstream oil investment by making fiscal terms clearer for multinationals. The downstream industry should also become commercially viable from this reorganisation of the sector, allowing Nigeria to wean itself off petrol imports as new refinery capacity comes on stream (which we expect to happen by 2022). However, it is relatively easier to keep electricity tariffs regulated. We do not expect sustained price increases-which would be needed to make the sector financially sound-and the power sector is therefore expected to remain dysfunctional, with electricity undersupply continuing to hinder industry.
Management of the naira is another sticking point for the World Bank. Low foreign-exchange inflows-reflecting low global oil prices-has provided scope for unifying the overvalued official exchange rate and the more market-determined Nigerian autonomous foreign-exchange fixing (NAFEX) rate, raising local-currency fiscal receipts from sales of crude oil. Once foreign-exchange availability improves and the current account returns to surplus, however, which we expect in 2022, the official rate is likely to again be quoted at a discount to the NAFEX. The idea of a single market rate has been proposed before (most recently in 2016) only to be jettisoned once foreign reserves increased, and the government only plans to manage the exchange-rate regime "sustainably" in the long run. An overvalued official exchange rate allows sectors deemed economically important, namely agriculture and manufacturing, to be subsidised, and fits an agenda of job creation and self-sufficiency through protectionism. A ban on accessing foreign exchange to purchase various imports (currently covering 45 items) is another arm of this strategy. From an investor perspective, the exchange-rate regime and its convertibility restrictions pose a threat of capital controls, which were temporarily imposed in 2016. We expect the long-term impact of the currency regime on investor confidence to keep foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows below 1% of GDP throughout the 2021-25 forecast period (and mostly in the hydrocarbons sector).
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy We expect the fiscal balance to stay in deficit in 2021-25. Crude oil receipts comprise more than 50% of the federal government's retained income, indicating a continued revenue crunch as oil prices stay low in 2021. High debt-servicing costs, pressing security needs and personnel outlays related to overstaffing will elevate expenditure throughout the forecast period. Widespread tax avoidance and low oil prices compared with the 2010-14 super-cycle will keep federally retained revenue below 4% of GDP throughout 2021-25.
Capital expenditure for the purposes of stimulus will be emphasised in 2021 now that subsidies (which are taken from revenue) have been reduced. This increase in fixed investment will be relatively small, but given low oil prices and so fiscal receipts, we expect a deficit equivalent to 3.1% of GDP. Higher oil prices will stabilise the deficit in 2022, despite a pre-election increase in spending, particularly on security. With a probable rise in value-added tax (VAT) rates (to curb a hazardously high debt-revenue ratio) after the 2023 elections, and oil prices continuing to rise, the deficit will shrink to 2.9% of GDP in 2023 and 2.7% in 2024, before widening to 3% of GDP in 2025 as oil prices fall.
As interest rates are currently low for the sovereign, domestic debt will be more attractive in the near-to-medium term. The government also wants to secure multilateral loans, but as these fall short of the officially expected quantum, we expect the government to return to the international capital market from 2021.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will fail to prevent inflation from exceeding its target ceiling of 9% over much of the forecast period, and its policy decisions are likely to be erratic. In the context of a probable recession and limited fiscal firepower, it decided to cut the policy rate by 100 basis points to 11.5% in September (after an 100-basis-point cut in May), despite an upward trend in annual inflation, to 13.2% in August. The strategy is to boost the supply side of the real economy to bring inflation back under control. In our view this is misguided; high and rising inflation will frustrate an economic recovery, and issues such as inadequate public infrastructure and rampant instability need to be addressed before sectors with high potential for returns (such as agriculture) can make full use of cheaper capital. Because we do not expect the supply-side improvements to bring inflation down, the CBN will have to raise interest rates once the economic crisis passes. We expect this to happen in 2022, with easing resuming only in 2024 when inflation has fallen appreciably.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The economy is expected to exit recession in 2021 as the impact of lockdown in 2020 fades, but high inflation will impede improvement in business sentiment and dampen real purchasing power amid low productivity, underemployment and low nominal wage growth. Fiscal stimulus will be an inadequate counterforce, given budget constraints, and loose monetary policy (despite high inflation) will contribute to exchange-rate pressures and further undermine macroeconomic stability. Oil production will, however, rise slightly as quotas agreed by OPEC+ (comprising OPEC and a group of non-OPEC countries) are relaxed, and given an uptick in oil exports we expect growth of 1.1% in 2021.
The CBN is expected to tighten monetary policy from 2022, which will circumscribe the nascent economic recovery, but the exchange rate will stabilise and inflation ease. As non-business financial penetration is low, private consumption will recover alongside disinflation even as interest rates rise. OPEC+ quotas will be raised from April that year and new refining capacity is expected to come on stream in earnest, boosting real exports (with some output for the regional market) and reducing imports. Consequently, we expect growth of 3.1% in 2022. As refinery output continues to ramp up, crude oil exports rise, inflation falls and real incomes rise, growth will pick up to an annual average of 3.8% in 2023-24. However, these rates of growth are well below potential. The economy will continue to lack dynamism owing to high interest rates, low FDI, high unemployment, pervasive instability in agricultural regions and infrastructure deficiencies, particularly regarding stable power supply. A more challenging year is forecast for 2025 as oil prices fall sharply and macroeconomic uncertainty rises, with growth slipping back to 1.6%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation Looser monetary policy (which will lead to currency adjustments), combined with higher fuel and electricity tariffs, foreign-exchange restrictions on various imported goods-including staple foods-and devaluation of the naira will raise inflation to an average of 16% in 2021. Assuming that oil prices rise, stabilising the exchange rate, and the CBN eventually reverses monetary easing, we expect the annual rate to fall throughout 2022-25, to 8.5% at end-2025. Conflict and agricultural supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-as well as foreign-exchange controls on imported goods will prevent a faster fall.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates An illusion of stability in the naira has recently held; the CBN is supplying foreign exchange to regulated trading windows but only fitfully, and a large unmet order-book for foreign exchange from exporters and investors has prevented a drawdown of foreign reserves. Assuming that oil prices stay low in 2021 and with low domestic interest rates sustaining capital outflow pressures, we expect a devaluation of the official rate that year (following two adjustments in 2020). This will take the naira from N379:US$1 at end-2020 to N450:US$1 at end-2021. The official and NAFEX rates will be broadly unified in the process. For the remainder of the forecast period the official exchange rate to the US dollar is expected to be kept relatively stable. Monetary tightening in Nigeria will encourage hot money inflows, higher oil prices will boost foreign exchange inflows (and lessen concerns over capital controls), and the current account is also forecast to return to surplus. Divergence between official and NAFEX rates is likely to re-emerge, but the CBN should be able to supply adequate foreign-exchange liquidity to regulated trading windows, broadly stabilising the market even as world oil prices (and so net foreign-exchange inflows) fluctuate.
Forecasting the naira Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of its data presentations, as this is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. The official rate also best represents exchange-rate policy. Indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued, which is in line with official calculations.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector An export slump due to low world oil prices and OPEC+ production quotas will keep the current account in deficit in 2021, for a third consecutive year (a stretch unseen since the early 1990s), with a shortfall of 2% of GDP expected. This is despite a slight uptick in imports of goods and services as the economy recovers and coronavirus-related travel restrictions imposed in 2020 are lifted, with a devalued naira restraining the increase. Over the remainder of the forecast period a current-account surplus is expected. Oil prices are projected to rise in 2022-23, which will expand exports, while lower petroleum import volumes as new domestic refinery capacity comes on stream will constrain the import bill. Remittances from the large Nigerian diaspora should also increase as the coronavirus crisis passes globally. This will all contribute to an annual average current-account surplus of 1.1% of GDP in 2022-24. The surplus will then ebb to 0.8% of GDP in 2025 as falling oil prices push down export earnings and continued real effective exchange-rate appreciation and monetary easing cause imports to continue to rise. The deficit in 2021 will be financed largely by debt inflows, with loose monetary policy discouraging portfolio investment.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
