Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+October+2020+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2020-10-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela to retain power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged both economically and politically. Low international crude prices, combined with US sanctions on the regime, mean that Venezuela is struggling to place its oil exports abroad. We therefore forecast that domestic crude production will average less than 400,000 barrels/day in the coming months. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control. That said, his position will strengthen in 2021, as the opposition is set to lose control of the legislature in January following a rigged legislative election on December 6th 2020.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have so far aided price stability and therefore increase the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is ranked 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environ-ment rankings for 2021-25, having been in 80th place in the 2016-20 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2023-25: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2023-25: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2023-25: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2021-22: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2023-25: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2021-22: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2023-25: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2021-22: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2023-25: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2023-25: Investors remain highly cautious about committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2021-22: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2023-25: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly (AN). In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the AN.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country) has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2019 current-account surplus at 1.2% of GDP.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), to retain power throughout 2021 despite social and economic shocks. However, the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, diminished oil rents-resulting from US sanctions and low international oil prices-and goods shortages all represent hefty challenges to the survival of the military regime. In addition, social unrest is prevalent and protests could intensify in the coming months owing to severe fuel shortages. Nonetheless, Mr Maduro has a number of factors working in his favour. The regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces; this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Another reason to believe that Mr Maduro will retain power is the state of the opposition, led by the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó. It has lost the momentum that it had in 2019 and lacks consensus on its approach to the upcoming legislative elections in December. Mr Guaidó's political capital is currently low-a recent poll by Datanálisis (a local pollster) gave him an approval rating of just 17%-and the legislative elections will impair his claim to power. Most opposition forces will boycott the December elections and are likely to seek to extend the current legislative term. However, there is no constitutional basis for an extension, and the PSUV's victory in the upcoming rigged elections will complicate the opposition's strategy and Mr Guaidó's claim to power, leaving Mr Maduro in a stronger position than a year prior.
Mr Maduro's recent actions illustrate his strong hand relative to the opposition. A new electoral council, inaugurated in June, was packed with Mr Maduro's allies. Even more audaciously, the Supreme Court ejected the leadership of several prominent opposition parties (including Acción Democrática and Voluntad Popular-Mr Guaidó's own party) and replaced them with a group of politicians who claim to be part of the opposition but who are in reality loyal to the regime. The brazenness of these actions shows that Mr Maduro is unperturbed by the prospect of retaliation by the opposition and that political pressure on him is wavering. In a sign that he feels in control of the political environment, he released and/or pardoned more than 100 opposition figures in late August, after talks mediated by Turkey between the regime and Henrique Capriles (a former presidential candidate) and Stalin González (a congressman).
Despite all of this, we recognise that there is a high risk to our forecasts, and that the deteriorating economic situation could prompt some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to a change of government: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia is low, and that a negotiated transition would also be difficult, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable. Bearing this in mind, we believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink US dollar inflows further. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems-along with a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis-could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch Legislative elections will take place on December 6th. These elections will be neither free nor fair, and the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly. Most opposition forces plan to boycott the polls, given the lack of electoral guarantees. However, some notable opposition figures-including Mr Capriles and Mr González-have publicly expressed their intention to take part (the opposition parties have boycotted polls in the past, but this only reduced their visibility, influence and legitimacy).
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future; for example, it plans to impose sanctions on diesel imports before end-October. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given the aversion of the US president, Donald Trump, to such adventurism. Nonetheless, we expect the US to further intensify diplomatic pressure before the next US general election and the next Venezuelan legislative elections, which are set to take place in November and December respectively. If tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted. Looking ahead, regardless of whether Mr Trump or his opponent, Joe Biden of the Democratic Party, wins the US election (our baseline forecast is for a Biden victory), we expect US sanctions to remain in place owing to strong bipartisan support. We anticipate that efforts to reach a negotiated exit for Mr Maduro would increase under a Biden administration.
Iran has recently become Mr Maduro's main international backer. Between April and June Iran sent 1.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela (in exchange for gold shipments) to alleviate the country's severe fuel shortages; more tankers are set to arrive in the coming weeks. Iran is also helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to repair the Paraguaná oil refinery. Nevertheless, Russia and China (both strong Venezuelan allies) seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries but has had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The Maduro regime will focus on weathering ongoing fuel shortages that have crippled the economy and on containing the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Despite community spread and an accelerating number of Covid-19 cases, Mr Maduro has eased nationwide quarantine measures to some degree. Measures will remain in place over the short to medium term, as Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The country's medical infrastructure is poor, and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity.
Given its potential to ignite large-scale protests, Mr Maduro has taken some steps to alleviate fuel scarcity. In May the regime announced a two-tiered petrol distribution system. Drivers are subject to a monthly quota of subsidised petrol. When this has been reached, petrol will be available at internationally indexed prices. The quota system seeks to regularise black-market activity so that the regime (rather than a third party) benefits from the gains. Concurrently, the Maduro regime is seeking to switch on domestic petrol production. PDVSA is currently able to produce only an estimated 20,000 barrels/day of petrol (at its peak it could refine 1.3m b/d) and repair existing refineries (although efforts to boost production are often marred by infrastructure breakdowns). However, these actions will only work to an extent, as arbitrage opportunities are still possible under the new subsidy system and domestic petrol production meets only a slim proportion of local demand (about 25% of current demand).
Based on our view that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our 2021-25 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the regime's survival. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the current regime.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2021, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb govern-ment spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2021-25. However, in the medium term, growing remittance inflows will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. We currently assume no debt restructuring in 2021-25. Venezuela's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. Indeed, a US court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications, as some international firms are seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. Bondholders of the PDVSA 2020 are currently unable to seek to attach assets owing to an ongoing suspension by the US Treasury. Nevertheless, there is a strong possibility that the Venezuelan opposition, which currently holds Citgo, will lose control of it to bondholders in early 2021.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyper-inflationary pressures in 2019, a trend that has continued in 2020. However, we expect that hyperinflationary pressures will build again in 2021, owing to the monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages.
Hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 60% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 30.3% in 2020 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 77% since 2013), we forecast an additional 1.7% decline in GDP in 2021. GDP is now strongly correlated with oil output and export. Following plummeting oil exports in 2019-20, crude production will stabilise as global energy demand starts to recover. Concurrently, the non-oil economy will benefit from the lifting of social distancing measures in 2021 and from larger fuel supplies (even though domestic petrol production will not fully cover local demand). From a demand-side perspective, the GDP contraction will be driven by falling real incomes, hyperinflation and continued mass emigration (fuelled by unemployment, violence and social instability).
Low crude prices and weak oil exports will still continue to threaten crude production. Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket traded at an estimated US$25/b as at end-August). The current circumstances have inevitably led to production cuts; according to OPEC, oil output fell to 340,000 b/d in August 2020, from 800,000 b/d in August 2019 and 1.3m b/d a year earlier. We believe that average output will remain below 400,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2022 we expect economic growth to return on the back of a surge in oil prices. Despite serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude, oil output will recover partially in the medium term as producers adapt to post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. Nonetheless, we assume that Venezuela's GDP (in real terms) will be only about half of its 2018 level, even in 2025. There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout 2021-25.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A severely reduced domestic goods supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will continue to stoke hyperinflation in 2021. Social distancing measures, dollarisation and heavy credit restrictions imposed by the regime have helped to subdue inflation this year, keeping it at bay. Consumer prices rose by 25% month on month in August; however, as the economy reopens, inflationary pressures will grow, owing to fuel scarcity, price controls and the ramping-up of money printing by the government.
In the medium term, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook. However, dollarisation will tame hyperinflationary pressures.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Hyperinflation will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2021. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We still believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On September 22nd the official exchange rate was BsS386,000:US$1 (against a black-market rate of BsS411,000:US$1). The current premium (6%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit of 0.8% of GDP in 2021, owing to weak oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from the global recession. Official BCV figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019-20 the collapse of goods export earnings (due to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the export collapse was mostly covered by growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019).
We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 3.6% of GDP in 2022-25. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. The recovery in the current account will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data Oil prices: dated Brent
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
US and OECD growth: OECD
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsS:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
